Question 1 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Which of the following Study design is most appropriate for investigating the cause effect relationship between an site and an outcome provided no ethical issue is involved?

Options:
  Case-control study
  Cohort study
  Cross sectional study
  Ecological study
✓ Randomized controlled trial

Explanation:
Randomized Controlled Trials (RCTs) are considered the gold standard for establishing cause-effect relationships because they minimize bias through random assignment and allow for direct comparison between intervention and control groups.

================================================================================
Question 2 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A researcher wants to study the risk factors of a rare disease like sarcoidosis. Which study design is best suited for identifying risk factors for a rare Disease?

Options:
✓ Case control study
  Cohort study
  Cross sectional study
  Ecological study
  Randomized controlled trial

Explanation:
Case-control studies are particularly well-suited for investigating risk factors of rare diseases because they begin by identifying individuals with the disease (cases) and then compare their past exposures to those of individuals without the disease (controls), making them efficient for rare outcomes.

================================================================================
Question 3 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A researcher wants to study prevalence of protein energy malnutrition in children under three years of age in a village which study design is most useful for studying the prevalence of a disease in a population?

Options:
  Case- control study
  Cohort study
✓ Cross sectional study
  Ecological study
  Randomized controlled study

Explanation:
Cross-sectional studies are the most useful design for determining the prevalence of a disease or health condition (like protein energy malnutrition) in a population at a single point in time, as they assess both exposure and outcome simultaneously.

================================================================================
Question 4 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A renowned pharmacologist claimed that his new drug for type 2 diabetes mellitus is showing more promising results in control of diabetes than older drugs available. Which of the following study design is most appropriate for evaluating the effectiveness of a new drug therapy?

Options:
  Case- control study
  Cohort study
  Cross -Sectional study
  Ecological study
✓ Randomized controlled trial

Explanation:
Randomized controlled trials (RCTs) are the most appropriate and rigorous study design for evaluating the effectiveness and safety of a new drug therapy, as they provide the strongest evidence for causality.

================================================================================
Question 5 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Which of the following study design is most appropriate for studying the natural history of a disease?

Options:
  Case control study
✓ Cohort study
  Cross sectional study
  Ecological study
  Experimental study

Explanation:
Cohort studies are most appropriate for studying the natural history of a disease because they involve following a group of individuals over time to observe the development and progression of the disease in relation to various factors.

================================================================================
Question 6 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Which of the following study design is most appropriate for assessing the impact of an intervention in a community?

Options:
  Case control study
  Cohort study
  Cross sectional study
  Ecological study
✓ Experimental study

Explanation:
Experimental studies, such as randomized controlled trials or community trials, are the most appropriate designs for assessing the impact of an intervention in a community as they involve manipulating an exposure (the intervention) and observing the resultant outcome.

================================================================================
Question 7 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A study was conducted on 10,000 antenatal women from first trimester visit till their term delivery to see the effect of smoking on birth weight of new born. Out of 10,000 women 3000 were smokers. 100 low birth weight children were born in both groups. What type of study design is this?

Options:
  Case control
✓ Cohort
  Cross sectional
  Quasi experimental
  Randomized controlled study

Explanation:
This is a cohort study design because it involves following a defined group of individuals (antenatal women, categorized by smoking status) forward in time to observe the development of an outcome (low birth weight).

================================================================================
Question 8 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A researcher wanted to study the time sequence to prove the concept of causality. He started studying the healthy people. Researcher wanted to see if high fat diet consumption has any role in ischemic heart disease development. Which design of study should be preferred by the researcher?

Options:
  Case report
  Case series report
  Cross sectional
✓ Longitudinal
  Quasi experimental

Explanation:
A longitudinal study, which is essentially a prospective cohort study, is preferred when a researcher wants to establish a time sequence to prove causality by following healthy individuals over time to observe the development of disease in relation to their exposures.

================================================================================
Question 9 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Smoking leads to esophageal carcinoma. Alcohol intake is related to smoking and also has its role in esophageal carcinoma development. This factor can distort the results of the study which intends to prove an association between smoking and esophageal cancer. What type of effect is this?

Options:
✓ Confounding
  Dose response relation
  Multiple causation
  One to one relationship
  Strength of association

Explanation:
This describes confounding, where a third factor (alcohol intake) is associated with both the exposure (smoking) and the outcome (esophageal carcinoma) and can distort or mask the true association between smoking and esophageal cancer.

================================================================================
Question 10 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
An expert in the field of public health is required to estimate the magnitude of a health problem for adequate provision of hospital facilities, logistics, finance and human resources. Which rate would he calculate for this purpose?

Options:
  Case fatality
  Cause specific mortality
  Incidence
✓ Prevalence
  Proportionate mortality

Explanation:
Prevalence measures the total number of existing cases of a disease or health problem in a population at a specific time, thus providing an estimate of its overall magnitude, which is crucial for health resource planning.

================================================================================
Question 11 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
HPV is the major cause of cervical carcinoma. What is the probable contribution of HPV in Ca. Cervix?

Options:

Explanation:
Human Papillomavirus (HPV) is recognized as the major etiological agent for cervical carcinoma, responsible for over 99% of all cases.

Question 12 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
In 1993 WHO promoted a program to improve infant and young children nutritional health known as:

Options:
  OMNCI
  MNCH
✓ BFHI
  WASH
  MAMI

Explanation:
The Baby-Friendly Hospital Initiative (BFHI) was launched by WHO and UNICEF in 1991 to promote exclusive breastfeeding and appropriate complementary feeding, directly improving the nutritional health of infants and young children.

Question 13 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 23 year old para 1 delivered a baby boy last month. She wants to plan for contraception. She is feeding her baby is breast fed, feeding frequency is more at night. What is the best to way to avoid conception in first 4 months of delivery?

Options:
  Oral contraception
  Male pills
  Injectable contraceptive
  IUCD
✓ No contraception (Lactational Amenorrhea Method implied if exclusive)

Explanation:
Given that the mother is breastfeeding frequently, especially at night, and her baby is less than 6 months old, the Lactational Amenorrhea Method (LAM) can be an effective natural contraception method for the first six months postpartum, provided her menses have not returned.

================================================================================
Question 14 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 28-year-old female patient with history of primary infertility, dysmenorrhea, painful stool defecation and abnormal bleeding. Laparoscopic findings show ectopic endometrial tissue with red hemorrhagic spots at the site outside the uterus. What will be the most likely diagnosis?

Options:
  Adenomyosis
✓ Endometriosis
  Molar pregnancy
  Oophoritis
  Salpingitis

Explanation:
The constellation of symptoms (infertility, dysmenorrhea, painful defecation, abnormal bleeding) and laparoscopic findings of ectopic endometrial tissue with hemorrhagic spots outside the uterus are classic for endometriosis.

Question 15 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
48 years female under goes laparotomy because of a pelvic mass intraoperative it was unilateral ovarian mass a complete by omental involvement on frozen section serous cystadeno Carcinoma was found most appropriate action will be:

Options:
  Bilateral salpingoophorectomy + omentectomy
  Total abdominal hysterectomy + bilateral salpingoophorectomy
  Ovarian cystectomy and omentectomy
  Unilateral oophorectomy + omental resection
✓ Peritoneal washing + Total abdominal hysterectomy + Bilateral salpingoophorectomy + Omental resection

Explanation:
For suspected or confirmed ovarian carcinoma with omental involvement, the most appropriate surgical action is a comprehensive staging laparotomy, which typically includes peritoneal washings, total abdominal hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, and omentectomy, along with other biopsies or debulking if necessary.

================================================================================
Question 16 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 58 years female complaint of pain abdomen on workup there is 4 cm bilateral ovarian mass with septations were present on ultrasound, next step of management is:

Options:
  OCPS and anti-inflammatory
✓ Send tumor markers and decide accordingly
  Surgery
  Ultrasound guided aspiration
  Wait for three months and decide on follow up

Explanation:
In a postmenopausal woman with bilateral ovarian masses and septations, there is a higher suspicion for malignancy. The next crucial step is to obtain tumor markers (e.g., CA-125) to help assess the risk of malignancy and guide further management, which may include surgery.

================================================================================
Question 17 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A G2P1 34 years at 29 weeks came to emergency department with sudden acute abdominal pain on workup there is 5.6 cm right ovarian mass. What is the most common ovarian tumor in pregnancy?

Options:
  Brenner's tumor
✓ Dermoid cyst
  Dysgerminoma
  Serous cystadenoma
  Krukenberg tumor

Explanation:
Mature cystic teratomas, commonly known as dermoid cysts, are the most common ovarian tumors found in pregnancy.

================================================================================
Question 18 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
An adolescent girl with complaint of lower abdominal fullness, on and of pain came to OPD on ultrasound 10.8 cm ovarian mass was found. Serum LDH is raised. What preferred mode of treatment you still suggest?

Options:
  Cystectomy with radiotherapy
  Oophorectomy+ radiotherapy
✓ Surgery with preservation of uterus and normal ovary followed by chemotherapy
  Ultrasound aspiration followed by chemotherapy
  Total abdominal hysterectomy+ bilateral salpingectomy

Explanation:
Given the large ovarian mass in an adolescent, a raised LDH (which can indicate germ cell tumors like dysgerminoma), and the desire to preserve fertility, the preferred mode of treatment would be conservative surgery (e.g., unilateral oophorectomy or cystectomy) with preservation of the uterus and contralateral ovary, followed by chemotherapy if indicated by histopathology.

================================================================================
Question 19 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 32 years old patient came to OPD with ultrasound report which shows bilateral ovarian masses with increased vascularity, and septations. She also gives history of weight loss and bloating there is family history of ovarian cancer on her maternal side. What is the percentage of malignant ovarian tumors having genetic predisposition?

Options:
  5-10% if only one 1st degree relative
✓ 10-15% if two 1st degree relative upto 40% risk
  22-25%
  40-50%
  1-2%

Explanation:
Approximately 10-15% of ovarian cancers are associated with an inherited genetic predisposition, such as BRCA1/2 mutations. The risk increases significantly with the number of affected first-degree relatives, potentially reaching up to 40% or more.

================================================================================
Question 20 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
There are different treatment modalities for cervical malignancy the decision is based on staging of CX cervix, we can proceed towards radical surgery before chemo and radio. Which of the following stage?

Options:
✓ Stage Ia and Stage Ib
  Stage 2a
  Stage 3a
  Stage 3b
  Stage 2b

Explanation:
Radical hysterectomy (radical surgery) is the primary treatment for early-stage cervical cancer, specifically Stage IA2 and Stage IB1/IB2, where the tumor is confined to the cervix or small enough to be surgically resectable.

================================================================================
Question 21 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
To prevent cervical cancer cervical screening program had been started. All women should be screened at the following age group:

Options:
  12-50 years
  15-60 years
✓ 25-64 years
  18-60 years
  20-64 years

Explanation:
Current international and national guidelines (e.g., WHO, CDC, ACOG) generally recommend cervical cancer screening for women starting around age 21 or 25 and continuing until age 64 or 65. The option '25-64 years' aligns well with these recommendations.

================================================================================
Question 22 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
You are sitting in gynae clinic a patient para 6 has visited you with the report of cervical screening which showed moderate dyskaryosis with positive HPV testing. What will you do next?

Options:
  Counsel patient & call for routine follow up visit
  Advise hysterectomy
  Repeat smear testing
✓ Referral for colposcopy
  Give symptomatic treatment only

Explanation:
A cervical screening report showing moderate dyskaryosis (moderate squamous intraepithelial lesion, or HSIL/CIN2) along with positive HPV testing indicates a significant abnormality requiring further investigation. The next step is a referral for colposcopy to visually examine the cervix and obtain targeted biopsies.

================================================================================
Question 23 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
56 years old para 7 presented with the complaint of post-menopausal spotting along with foul smelling discharge and also complaining of dysuria and urinary hesitancy along with lower abdominal pain, patient husband has been in gulf country for many years. On per speculum examination patient she has marked pallor and she is quite anxious. What is most probable diagnosis?

Options:
  Menopause symptoms
  Pelvic inflammatory disease
✓ Cervical malignancy
  Cervical polyp
  Fibroid uterus

Explanation:
Post-menopausal bleeding, foul-smelling discharge, dysuria, and lower abdominal pain, especially with marked pallor and anxiety, are highly concerning symptoms for cervical malignancy in a 56-year-old. While other conditions can present with some of these, the combination strongly points to cancer until proven otherwise.

================================================================================
Question 24 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 47 years old para 5 presented to OPD with postcoital bleeding, intermenstrual bleeding and dysuria on per speculum examination there is fleshy growth that is involving the cervix biopsy was taken and histopathology came out to be cervical malignancy. How will you proceed further to stage the disease?

Options:
  Staging is done mainly radiologically
  CX cervix is staged surgically
✓ Staging is done clinically
  Staging is done histopathologically
  None of the above

Explanation:
Cervical cancer is primarily staged clinically, based on physical examination (including speculum and bimanual exam), colposcopy, biopsy results, and sometimes imaging like MRI for evaluation of local spread. This clinical staging system (FIGO staging) is universally accepted.

================================================================================
Question 25 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
The following selective medium is used to isolate Neisseria Gonorrhea.

Options:
  Blood agar
  Chocolate agar
  MacConkey's medium
  Mannitol salt agar
✓ Modified Thayer-Martin medium

Explanation:
Modified Thayer-Martin medium is a selective medium specifically designed for the isolation of pathogenic *Neisseria* species, including *Neisseria gonorrhoeae*, by inhibiting the growth of commensal bacteria and fungi.

================================================================================
Question 26 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 26 year old female is using injectable medroxy progesterone acetate as a method of contraception. Which of the following adverse effects is a concern if she wishes to use this therapy long term?

Options:
  Hyperkalemia
  Male pattern baldness
✓ Osteoporosis
  Weight loss
  Hypokalemia

Explanation:
Long-term use of injectable medroxyprogesterone acetate (DMPA) is associated with a decrease in bone mineral density, which can increase the risk of osteoporosis.

================================================================================
Question 27 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Which of the following is drug of choice for pregnant female suspected of having a baby with congenital adrenal hyperplasia?

Options:
  Betamethasone
  Beclomethasone
✓ Dexamethasone
  Hydrocortisone
  Prednisolone

Explanation:
Dexamethasone is the drug of choice for antenatal treatment of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) in a pregnant female because it effectively crosses the placenta in its active form to suppress fetal adrenal androgen production, minimizing virilization of a female fetus.

================================================================================
Question 28 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 60 year old male patient taking medicine for treatment of BPH for 6 months. Which may cause reflex tachycardia or postural hypotension initial administration?

Options:
  Atenolol
  Hydrochlorothiazide
  Metoprolol
✓ Prazosin
  Verapamil

Explanation:
Prazosin is an alpha-1 adrenergic receptor blocker commonly used for BPH. Its initial administration can cause significant vasodilation, leading to first-dose postural hypotension and compensatory reflex tachycardia.

================================================================================
Question 29 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Which of the following is a selective estrogen receptor modulator that improve bone mineral density in a postmenopausal women?

Options:
  Clomiphene citrate
✓ Raloxifene
  Ormeloxifene
  Alendronate
  Both a & b

Explanation:
Raloxifene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that acts as an estrogen agonist in bone, helping to improve bone mineral density and reduce the risk of vertebral fractures in postmenopausal women.

================================================================================
Question 30 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Addiction of progestin for 10-12 days each month of estrogen replacement therapy in a postmenopausal women is recommended because of progestin.

Options:
  Block the increased risk of myocardial infarction due to estrogen endometrial
✓ Block the increased risk of endometrial carcinoma due to estrogen
  Reverse vulval atrophy occurring in postmenopausal women
  Both a & b
  All are correct

Explanation:
When estrogen replacement therapy is given to a postmenopausal woman with an intact uterus, progestin is added for 10-12 days each month to counteract the estrogen's proliferative effect on the endometrium, thereby blocking the increased risk of endometrial carcinoma.

================================================================================
Question 31 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 19 year old medical student presented with complaints of weight loss, polyuria and polydipsia. He was otherwise stable. His lab were as under: FBS 397mg/dL, HBAIC >15%. what will be the treatment strategy?

Options:
  Metformin
  Sulfonylureas
  DDP4 inhibitors
✓ Insulin
  Diet and life style modification

Explanation:
The patient's symptoms (weight loss, polyuria, polydipsia), very high Fasting Blood Sugar (FBS 397mg/dL), and extremely high HbA1c (>15%) are classic for newly diagnosed Type 1 diabetes (or severe Type 2 diabetes with significant insulin deficiency). Insulin therapy is the immediate and most appropriate treatment strategy to control hyperglycemia and prevent diabetic ketoacidosis.

================================================================================
Question 32 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
35 years old female presented to emergency department with polyuria. She is diabetic for past 2 years and using glimepiride 4 mg. Now, she got pregnant with gestational amenorrhea of 4 months. Her labs are as under: RBS 250 msg/dL, HbA1C 7.4%. What will be the treatment strategy?

Options:
  Continue glimepiride and add Metformin
  Stop glimepiride and add GP-1 analogue
  Continue glimepiride and add DDP 4 inhibitor
✓ Stop glimepiride and switch to insulin
  Continue glimepiride and add insulin

Explanation:
Glimepiride (a sulfonylurea) is generally contraindicated in pregnancy due to the risk of fetal hyperinsulinemia and hypoglycemia. Given her pregnancy, elevated RBS, and HbA1c, the most appropriate treatment strategy is to stop glimepiride and switch to insulin, which is the preferred and safest medication for glycemic control in pregnant diabetic patients.

================================================================================
Question 33 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 50 year old male patient presented with costovertebral pain, palpable Mass & hematuria. He also complained with fever, weight loss & malaise. On biopsy of renal mass, the diagnosis of clear cell carcinoma was made. Which gene mutation is responsible for clear cell carcinoma?

Options:
✓ Loss of VHL
  Mutated BHD gene
  Mutated FH gene
  Mutated MET gene
  VEGF inhibition

Explanation:
Renal clear cell carcinoma, the most common type of kidney cancer, is strongly associated with inactivation or loss of function mutations in the von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) tumor suppressor gene.

================================================================================
Question 34 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
In IGA nephropathy , histological finding is;

Options:
  Podocyte fusion
  Thick glomerular basement membrane
  Segmental glomerulosclerosis
✓ Increase mesangial matrix
  Segmental sclerosis in glomeruli

Explanation:
The characteristic histological finding in IgA nephropathy is an increase in the mesangial matrix and mesangial cellularity, with prominent IgA immune complex deposits within the mesangium.

================================================================================
Question 35 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 75 year old woman being investigated for recurrent UTIs (Proteus on culture report) has a stag horn calculus on CT scan what is the most likely Stone composition?

Options:
  Cystine
  Uric acid
✓ Struvite
  Calcium oxalate
  Hydrogen

Explanation:
Recurrent urinary tract infections, especially with urease-producing bacteria like *Proteus* species, create an alkaline urine environment that facilitates the formation of struvite (magnesium ammonium phosphate) stones. These stones are known to form large casts of the renal pelvis, called staghorn calculi.

================================================================================
Question 36 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Which one of the following symptoms is not related to urinary tract infection?

Options:
  Burning micturition
  Fever (low grade)
  Strong persistent urge to urinate
  Cloudy urine
✓ None

Explanation:
All the listed symptoms—burning micturition (dysuria), fever, a strong persistent urge to urinate (urgency), and cloudy urine—are common clinical manifestations associated with urinary tract infections.

================================================================================
Question 37 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
30 year old lady has obesity, infertility hirsutism and depression. What is the most likely condition she suffering from?

Options:
  Hypothyroidism
  Morbid obesity
✓ Polycystic ovary syndrome
  Polyglandular syndrome
  Type I diabetes mellitus

Explanation:
The constellation of symptoms including obesity, infertility, hirsutism, and often depression is highly characteristic of Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS), a common endocrine disorder in women of reproductive age.

================================================================================
Question 38 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 30 year old female presented with solitary thyroid nodule. She complained of hoarseness of voice. On clinical examination cervical lymph node is also palpable. On thyroid scan it was cold solid nodule. FNAC of nodule showed intranuclear inclusions of aspirated cells. On biopsy the tumor cells showed orphan Annie eye nuclei. What is the diagnosis?

Options:
  Anaplastic carcinoma
  Follicular carcinoma
  Hurthle cell carcinoma
  Medullary carcinoma
✓ Papillary carcinoma

Explanation:
The presence of hoarseness of voice and palpable cervical lymph nodes (suggesting invasion/metastasis), a cold nodule on scan (more suspicious for malignancy), and especially the FNAC/biopsy findings of intranuclear inclusions and 'Orphan Annie eye' nuclei are pathognomonic for papillary thyroid carcinoma.

================================================================================
Question 39 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A patient presented with weight loss, sweating, palpitation, lid lag, exophthalmos, Tachycardia tremors and a goiter. Upon thyroid scan, there appears to be increased intake of iodine. What is the pathogenesis of this disease?

Options:
  Infection
  Immune complex mediated
  Hashimoto's thyroiditis (Implied but option says 'Hashimoto's thyroid')
  Idiopathic
✓ Autoimmune mediated

Explanation:
The clinical presentation (weight loss, sweating, palpitations, lid lag, exophthalmos, tachycardia, tremors, goiter) and increased iodine uptake on thyroid scan are classic for Graves' disease, which is an autoimmune disorder where antibodies stimulate the TSH receptor, leading to excessive thyroid hormone production.

================================================================================
Question 40 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A patient who is presented with increased growth of skeletal and soft tissues, hypertension, arthritis, menstrual disturbance, and diabetes mellitus. When oral glucose administered, which one of the following level will increase? (Note: Context implies Acromegaly/GH excess where GH doesn't suppress, but question asks what will increase, normally insulin increases, but in acromegaly GH fails to suppress. The wording is tricky. Alternatively, it might be asking which level is elevated in the condition generally. IGF-1 is chronically elevated. Or perhaps 'fail to decrease' was intended for GH). Given options:

Options:
  Growth hormone
  Antidiuretic hormone
✓ Insulin like growth factor
  None of the above
  Both a & b

Explanation:
The symptoms (increased growth of skeletal/soft tissues, hypertension, arthritis, menstrual disturbance, diabetes) are characteristic of acromegaly, caused by excessive growth hormone (GH) secretion. While GH itself is elevated and fails to suppress, GH mediates most of its growth-promoting effects indirectly through the production of Insulin-like Growth Factor 1 (IGF-1). IGF-1 levels are chronically elevated in acromegaly and serve as a key diagnostic and monitoring tool. In an oral glucose tolerance test, while GH fails to suppress, insulin levels will increase in response to glucose. However, the question is likely asking about a chronically elevated marker related to the disease itself, which is IGF-1. If it's asking what *increases* after glucose, insulin would, but IGF-1 is the more direct measure of the disease's chronic activity.

================================================================================
Question 41 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Patient with diabetes have an increased risk for all of the following except?

Options:
  Cataracts
  Infection
  Increased atherosclerosis
  Peripheral Neuropathy
✓ Pancreatic carcinoma (Actually, diabetes is a risk factor for pancreatic cancer, but relative to complications, this is often the 'except' distractor in older contexts or implies a specific type. However, commonly: Diabetes increases risk of all A-D. Pancreatic Ca is also increased. Perhaps the intended answer is based on a specific context or error in question construction).
  Pancreatic carcinoma

Explanation:
Diabetes significantly increases the risk for cataracts, various infections, accelerated atherosclerosis, and peripheral neuropathy. While there is a recognized link and increased risk of pancreatic cancer in individuals with long-standing diabetes, the question seeks the *least* likely or 'except' item in a list of common, direct diabetes complications. In many older medical education contexts or poorly constructed 'except' questions, pancreatic carcinoma might be intended as the answer, even though contemporary understanding recognizes diabetes as a risk factor for it. If the question implies direct complications of diabetes, pancreatic carcinoma is less direct than the others.

================================================================================
Question 42 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Which of the following is true for papillary thyroid carcinoma?

Options:
✓ May have psammoma bodies
  Least common type
  Worst prognosis
  Associated with MEN-II
  Most common in elderly population

Explanation:
Papillary thyroid carcinoma is the most common type of thyroid cancer and is characterized by distinct nuclear features (Orphan Annie eye nuclei, nuclear grooves, intranuclear inclusions) and often the presence of psammoma bodies (concentric calcifications). It generally has a good prognosis and is not typically associated with MEN-II (which is linked to medullary thyroid carcinoma).

================================================================================
Question 43 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
The most common cause of hypothyroidism in third world countries in which of the following?

Options:
  Pituitary dysfunction
  Dequervain's thyroiditis
  Graves disease
  Hashimoto's thyroiditis
✓ Iodine deficiency

Explanation:
In many third-world (developing) countries, iodine deficiency remains the most common cause of hypothyroidism, leading to goiter and impaired thyroid hormone production.

================================================================================
Question 44 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Cushing's triad is;

Options:
✓ Increase ICP, HTN Bradycardia
  Increase ICP Hypotension Bradycardia
  Increase ICP, Hypotension , Tachycardia
  Increase ICP, HTN, Tachycardia
  Decrease ICP, HTN , Tachycardia

Explanation:
Cushing's triad is a clinical sign of increased intracranial pressure (ICP) and consists of three components: hypertension (increased systolic blood pressure), bradycardia (slow heart rate), and irregular respiration.

================================================================================
Question 45 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
The most common type of thyroid carcinoma is?

Options:
  Anaplastic carcinoma
  Follicular carcinoma
  Medullary carcinoma
✓ Papillary carcinoma
  Small cell carcinoma

Explanation:
Papillary thyroid carcinoma is the most common type of thyroid cancer, accounting for approximately 80% of all thyroid malignancies.

================================================================================
Question 46 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Which gland is under direct neural regulation of hypothalamus?

Options:
  Adrenal gland (Medulla) or Posterior Pituitary
  Anterior pituitary gland
  Parathyroid glands
✓ Posterior pituitary gland
  Thyroid gland

Explanation:
The posterior pituitary gland (neurohypophysis) is under direct neural regulation of the hypothalamus. Hypothalamic neurons synthesize oxytocin and antidiuretic hormone (ADH) and transport them down their axons for release from the posterior pituitary. The adrenal medulla is also under neural control, but typically from the sympathetic nervous system, not direct hypothalamic neurons for hormone release.

================================================================================
Question 47 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Iodine deficiency can cause:

Options:
✓ Goiter
  Thyroid cancer
  Solitary Nodules
  Thyroiditis
  None of the above

Explanation:
Iodine deficiency is a well-known cause of goiter (enlargement of the thyroid gland) as the thyroid attempts to compensate for insufficient iodine to produce thyroid hormones.

================================================================================
Question 48 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Hyperparathyroidism causes

Options:
  Heat intolerance
  High blood sugar
✓ Increased urination (Polyuria due to hypercalcemia)
  Headache
  Both a & b

Explanation:
Hyperparathyroidism leads to hypercalcemia, which can cause polyuria (increased urination) due to impaired renal concentrating ability. Heat intolerance and high blood sugar are not direct effects of hyperparathyroidism.

================================================================================
Question 49 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Most common cause of Cushing syndrome:

Options:
  ACTH Secreting tumor
  Adrenal adenoma
✓ Exogenous steroids
  Adrenal carcinoma
  All of the above

Explanation:
The most common cause of Cushing syndrome (exogenous Cushing syndrome) is the long-term, high-dose administration of exogenous glucocorticoids (steroids) for medical conditions.

================================================================================
Question 50 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A patient presents with polyuria and increase thirst serum glucose is not elevated serum osmolality is low. Upon water deprivation test. Which one of the following is correct?

Options:
✓ Problem in pituitary
  Problem in kidneys
  Patient with diabetes mellitus
  Serum ADH is high
  (Option missing or implied related to DI type)

Explanation:
The combination of polyuria, increased thirst, normal serum glucose, and low serum osmolality (implying dilute urine despite dehydration) points towards diabetes insipidus (DI). A water deprivation test differentiates between central DI (problem in pituitary/hypothalamic ADH production) and nephrogenic DI (problem in kidney response to ADH). If the problem is in the pituitary, it signifies central diabetes insipidus due to lack of ADH.

================================================================================
Question 51 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Which of the following is a common complication following thyroid (total thyroidectomy) surgery?

Options:
  Diabetes
  Hypertension
✓ Hypocalcemia
  Hypokalemia
  None of the above

Explanation:
Hypocalcemia is a common and potentially serious complication following total thyroidectomy due to inadvertent damage to or removal of the parathyroid glands during surgery, leading to temporary or permanent hypoparathyroidism.

================================================================================
Question 52 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
15 year old female presented to emergency department in the state of coma and fever. She has air hunger and dehydrated her GCS is 9/15, pulse 100, BP 100/60, blood sugar level are 450 mg/dl. What is the best treatment option for this patient?

Options:
  Metformin
  Gliclazide
  Long acting insulin
✓ Hydration with saline & Humulin R (DKA protocol)
  DPP4 inhibitor

Explanation:
The patient's presentation (coma, fever, air hunger, dehydration, hyperglycemia (450 mg/dl), and low GCS) is classic for diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). The immediate and best treatment involves aggressive intravenous hydration with saline and intravenous regular insulin (Humulin R) according to DKA protocols to correct dehydration, hyperglycemia, and acidosis.

================================================================================
Question 53 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
30 year old diabetic patient presented with polyuria, burning micturition. Her blood glucose levels are 250 mg/dl despite on oral medications. She has this urinary complaints for the last few months. What are the best investigation plans for her management?

Options:
  Urine routine analysis/RBC
  Fasting blood glucose daily
  Blood culture, RBC
✓ Urine culture HbA1c, RBC (likely intended to include Urine R/E)
  Ultrasound abdomen pelvis

Explanation:
Given the patient's diabetic status, polyuria, and burning micturition (suggesting a urinary tract infection), the best investigation plan involves a urine culture (to identify infection), HbA1c (to assess long-term glycemic control which is poor), and urine routine examination (implied by RBC in the option for general urinary assessment).

================================================================================
Question 54 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A young asthmatic previously taking exogenous steroids came to emergency with vomiting, abdominal pain, low BP, dry mucous membranes blood sugar 120mg/dl most likely DX is:

Options:
  Cushing syndrome
  Diabetes mellitus
  Diabetes insipidus
✓ Addisonian crisis
  None of the above

Explanation:
A patient on chronic exogenous steroids who presents with vomiting, abdominal pain, hypotension, and dry mucous membranes (signs of volume depletion and shock), often with a relatively normal or slightly low blood sugar, is highly suggestive of an Addisonian crisis. This occurs when exogenous steroids are abruptly withdrawn or during stress, leading to acute adrenal insufficiency.

================================================================================
Question 55 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
The most common cause of permanent congenital hypothyroidism is:

Options:
  Dyshormonogenesis
✓ Thyroid dysgenesis
  Iodine deficiency
  Defect of iodine transport
  Pendred syndrome

Explanation:
Thyroid dysgenesis, including aplasia, hypoplasia, or ectopy of the thyroid gland, is the most common cause of permanent congenital hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient areas.

================================================================================
Question 56 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Which one is not an appropriate treatment for graves disease?

Options:
  Beta blockers
  Surgical removal of thyroid gland
  Radio-active iodine
  Antithyroid drugs
✓ Thyroxin

Explanation:
Thyroxin (levothyroxine) is thyroid hormone replacement therapy used to treat hypothyroidism. Graves' disease is a hyperthyroid condition, so administering additional thyroid hormone (thyroxin) would exacerbate the condition and is thus not an appropriate treatment. Beta-blockers, surgery, radioactive iodine, and anti-thyroid drugs are all treatment options for Graves' disease.

================================================================================
Question 57 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 50 year old woman complained of post menopausal bleeding. On examination her cervix was eroded and ulcerative. Biopsy was taken and diagnosis of squamous intraepithelial neoplasm was made on the basis of nuclear changes along with cytoplasmic halos having perinuclear vacuoles termed koilocytic atypia. Which of the following is associated with koilocytic atypia?

Options:
  EBV
  High Ki-67
  High CEA level
✓ HPV protein E5
  Keratin formation

Explanation:
Koilocytic atypia (koilocytosis) is the cytopathic effect characteristic of human papillomavirus (HPV) infection on squamous epithelial cells. HPV proteins, including E5, are involved in the pathogenesis and cellular changes associated with the infection.

================================================================================
Question 58 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 32 year old female patient with diagnosis case of ovarian tumor with ascites and pleural effusion. All these findings are present in which of the following condition?

Options:
  Basal cell carcinoma
  Carcinoid tumor
  Krukenberg tumor
✓ Meigs syndrome
  Pseudomyxoma peritonei

Explanation:
Meigs syndrome is a specific clinical triad characterized by the presence of a benign ovarian tumor (typically a fibroma), ascites (fluid in the abdominal cavity), and pleural effusion (fluid around the lungs), which resolves after surgical removal of the tumor.

================================================================================
Question 59 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
In pregnancy, enlargement of uterus at pubic level is seen in the following weeks.

Options:
  4 weeks
  8 weeks
✓ 12 weeks
  24 weeks
  36 weeks

Explanation:
The uterus becomes palpable at the pubic symphysis (pubic level) around 12 weeks of gestation. Before this, it is largely confined within the pelvis.

================================================================================
Question 60 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
False virgin is who has.

Options:
✓ Elastic hymen
  No hymen
  Imperforated hymen
  Annular hymen
  Septate hymen

Explanation:
A 'false virgin' refers to a woman who has had sexual intercourse but whose hymen remains intact, often due to a highly elastic or resilient hymen that stretches rather than tears during penetration.

================================================================================
Question 61 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A habituated female (i.e female who had frequent sexual intercourse) shows torn hymen known as.

Options:
  Carunculae hymenalis
  Linea Nigra
✓ Carunculae myrtiformes
  Marginal hymen
  Imperforated hymen

Explanation:
In a female who has experienced multiple acts of sexual intercourse or childbirth, the torn remnants of the hymen can heal into small, fleshy nodules known as carunculae myrtiformes.

================================================================================
Question 62 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A female who had given birth to child exhibits only remnants of hymen known as.

Options:
  Carunculae hymenalis
  Linea Nigra
✓ Carunculae myrtiformes
  Marginal hymen
  Imperforated hymen

Explanation:
Following childbirth, the hymen is often severely torn and its remnants retract, forming small, irregular nodules called carunculae myrtiformes.

================================================================================
Question 63 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
The spermatozoa in a case of sexual intercourse can be seen in vagina till .

Options:
✓ 1-7 days
  10 days
  2 weeks
  4 weeks
  8 weeks

Explanation:
Spermatozoa can typically be detected in the vagina for up to 1-7 days (approximately 24 hours to 7 days) after sexual intercourse, although motility rapidly decreases.

================================================================================
Question 64 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Sin of Gomorrah is.

Options:
✓ Anal coitus
  Buccal coitus
  Incest
  Lesbianism
  Indecent assault

Explanation:
The 'Sin of Gomorrah' is an archaic term often used to refer to acts of sodomy, particularly anal coitus.

================================================================================
Question 65 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
The pregnancy caused by rape can be terminated under the following ground.

Options:
  Therapeutic
  Eugenic
✓ Humanitarian
  Social
  None

Explanation:
Termination of pregnancy resulting from rape is typically considered under humanitarian grounds, acknowledging the severe psychological trauma and violation experienced by the victim.

================================================================================
Question 66 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 45 years old women presents with hypertension, and metabolic alkalosis. She has no history of renal disease or heart failure. Her plasma renin activity is low and her serum aldosterone level is high. What is the most likely cause of her condition?

Options:
  Renal artery stenosis
✓ Aldosterone -producing adrenal adenoma
  Renin- producing tumor
  Ectopic aldosterone - secreting tumor
  Familial hyperaldosteronism type 1

Explanation:
The clinical presentation of hypertension, hypokalemia (leading to metabolic alkalosis), low plasma renin activity, and high serum aldosterone is classic for primary hyperaldosteronism. The most common cause of primary hyperaldosteronism is an aldosterone-producing adrenal adenoma (Conn's syndrome).

================================================================================
Question 67 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 30 years old women presents with abdominal pain and distension for the last two months. On physical examination, she has multiple angiofibromas on her face and ash-leaf spots on trunk. A pelvic examination reveals an enlarged uterus. Laboratory tests show normal renal function and negative pregnancy test. A pelvic ultrasound shows multiple cysts in both ovaries. A renal ultrasound shows multiple cysts in both kidneys and multiple solid masses in the cortex and medulla. A contrast enhanced CT scan confirms the presence of bilateral renal angiomyolipomas. Which of the following cells are most likely to be found in these tumors?

Options:
✓ Mature adipose cells
  Immature cartilage cells
  Malignant epithelial cells
  Eosinophilic granular cells
  Multiple giant cells

Explanation:
The constellation of angiofibromas, ash-leaf spots, renal cysts, and bilateral renal angiomyolipomas is highly characteristic of Tuberous Sclerosis Complex (TSC). Angiomyolipomas are benign tumors composed of blood vessels, smooth muscle, and adipose (fat) cells. Thus, mature adipose cells would be found.

================================================================================
Question 68 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 65 year old man presents with hematuria and a palpable Mass in lower abdomen. Cystoscopy reveals a large , irregular, and ulcerated tumor involving posterior Wall of urinary bladder. Biopsy shows a high grade urothelial carcinoma with extensive squamous differentiation. What is the most likely stage of this tumor according to the TNM system?

Options:
  Ta
  T1
  T2
✓ T3
  T4 (Options implied/missing context, but T4 often used for 'most likely stage' questions with extensive involvement, however snippet cuts off)

Explanation:
A large, irregular, ulcerated tumor with extensive squamous differentiation, involving the posterior wall of the urinary bladder and likely extending beyond the bladder wall (implied by palpation and 'extensive squamous differentiation' often indicating aggressive features), suggests an advanced stage. T3 describes a tumor that has invaded the perivesical tissue (fat surrounding the bladder) but not adjacent organs, which aligns with significant local extension implied by the description and could manifest as a palpable mass.

================================================================================
Question 69 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 55 year old woman undergoes transurethral resection of a small papillary tumor in the bladder. Histologic examination shows a low grade urothelial carcinoma with thin fibrovascular cores and orderly arrangement of cells. Immunohistochemistry shows positive staining for CK20 in the superficial cells and negative staining for CK7 in the basal cells. What is the most appropriate diagnosis for this tumor?

Options:
  Papilloma
  Papillary urothelial neoplasm of the low malignant potential
✓ Low grade papillary urothelial carcinoma
  High grade papillary urothelial carcinoma
  Invasive urothelial carcinoma

Explanation:
The histological findings (papillary tumor, low grade, thin fibrovascular cores, orderly cells) are characteristic of a low-grade papillary urothelial carcinoma. The immunohistochemistry pattern (CK20 positive superficial, CK7 negative basal) is also consistent with low-grade urothelial lesions.

================================================================================
Question 70 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
In live person the kidney transplantation , what investigations you will not do?

Options:
  Blood grouping
  HLA
  RFTs
✓ Renin hormone
  Renal tract study

Explanation:
For live donor kidney transplantation, essential investigations include blood grouping, HLA matching, assessment of renal function (RFTs) in both donor and recipient, and a comprehensive renal tract study in the donor. Renin hormone levels are not a standard or necessary investigation for routine transplant workup, although they might be relevant in specific hypertension cases.

================================================================================
Question 71 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Neprorectomy is primarily indicated in which of the following conditions?

Options:
  Polycystic kidney disease
✓ Renal cell carcinoma
  Nephrolithiasis
  UTI
  Both c&d

Explanation:
Nephrectomy (surgical removal of the kidney) is primarily indicated for renal cell carcinoma (kidney cancer) as the main curative treatment. While it might be performed in some severe cases of polycystic kidney disease or complicated nephrolithiasis, it's the primary definitive treatment for RCC.

================================================================================
Question 72 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
What is the primary treatment goal for small kidney stones that can be passed naturally?

Options:
  Surgical removal
✓ Pain management
  Prevention of future stones
  Advice to increase fluid intake
  None

Explanation:
For small kidney stones that are expected to pass spontaneously, the primary treatment goal is pain management. This involves analgesics to control the severe pain (renal colic) as the stone navigates the ureter. Increasing fluid intake is also advised to aid passage, and prevention of future stones is a long-term goal, but immediate pain relief is paramount.

================================================================================
Question 73 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Undescended testes is also referred to as

Options:
  Inguinal hernia
  Varicoele
✓ Cryptorchidism
  Hydrocele
  Both b& c

Explanation:
Cryptorchidism is the medical term for undescended testes, a condition where one or both testicles fail to descend into the scrotum.

================================================================================
Question 74 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Which one of the following can cause urinary retention?

Options:
  Direct inguinal hernia
  Benign prostate hyperplasia
  Urethral structure
  Bladder stone
✓ All except A

Explanation:
Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), urethral strictures, and bladder stones are all common causes of urinary retention by creating obstruction to urine flow. A direct inguinal hernia, while a mass, typically does not directly obstruct the urinary tract to cause retention.

================================================================================
Question 75 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Which of the following is accurate regarding urine studies in nephrotic syndrome?

Options:
  A 2+ reading on urinalysis via dipstick represents 300 mg/dl of urinary protein or more, correlating with a daily loss of 3g or more
  The presence of 4 or more red blood cells per high -power field in urine sediment examination is required for a diagnosis of micro hematuria
  A measurement of 100-150 mg of total protein present in a 24-hour urine collection suggest early nephrotic syndrome
✓ A ratio of urine protein to urine creatinine>2g/g indicates nephrotic -range proteinuria
  None of the above

Explanation:
Nephrotic-range proteinuria is defined as a urine protein excretion of >3.5 g/day. A urine protein to creatinine ratio of >2g/g (or >3g/g in some contexts) is generally indicative of nephrotic-range proteinuria. A 2+ dipstick is roughly 100-300 mg/dL, but not directly correlating to >3g/day. Microhematuria is typically >3 RBCs/hpf.

================================================================================
Question 76 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
In uncentrifuged sample of urine, definition of significant polyuria is.

Options:
  >3 leukocytes per high power field
  >10 leukocytes per high power field
  >10 leukocytes/cu mm
  >5 leukocytes/cu.mm
✓ None of the above

Explanation:
The question defines *polyuria*, which is increased urine output (typically >2.5-3 liters/24 hours). The options relate to pyuria (leukocytes in urine), not polyuria. None of the given options accurately define significant polyuria or even a standard threshold for pyuria in an uncentrifuged sample without additional context.

================================================================================
Question 77 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 30 year old female presents to the clinic with symptoms of a urinary tract infection (UTI), including dysuria, frequency, and cloudy urine. She has a history of penicillin allergy. The urine culture confirms the presence of Escherichia coli. Which antibiotic would be the most appropriate choice for treating her UTI?

Options:
✓ Ciprofloxacin
  Amoxicillin
  Trimethoprim -sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX)
  Doxycycline
  Erythromycin

Explanation:
Given the patient has a penicillin allergy and *E. coli* is a common cause of UTI, ciprofloxacin (a fluoroquinolone) is a highly effective and appropriate choice for treatment. Amoxicillin is a penicillin, and TMP-SMX can also have cross-reactivity with some sulfa allergies, although penicillin is specified. Doxycycline and erythromycin are generally not first-line for uncomplicated *E.coli* UTIs.

================================================================================
Question 78 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 25 years adult man was brought to forensic medicine department who was said to be a victim of an unlawful sexual act sodomy. What is the most appropriate position for the examination of such case?

Options:
  Knee elbow position
✓ Left lateral position
  Lithotomy position
  Prone position
  Right lateral position

Explanation:
The left lateral (Sim's) position is often considered the most appropriate and comfortable position for the examination of the anal region in cases of alleged sodomy or sexual assault, allowing for proper visualization and collection of evidence.

================================================================================
Question 79 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A doctor was called by the prosecutor for cross examination during a court proceeding. The prosecutor questioned a physician about the way the abortion stick works during criminal abortion The acceptable answer is?

Options:
✓ Necrosis and infection of uterine wall
  Nerve stimulation of uterus
  Relaxation of Uterine Muscles
  Separation of placenta
  Uterine contraction

Explanation:
Abortion sticks used in criminal abortions are unsanitary and cause injury, leading to necrosis and infection of the uterine wall. This trauma and infection eventually lead to the expulsion of the fetus, but with severe risks to the woman.

================================================================================
Question 80 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A young married woman who was 4 weeks pregnant but does not want to continue the pregnancy because of her studies. There is no health issues to the mother other wise However, her husband is also not willing to abort the baby. Aborting a fetus according to the above scenario in Pakistani law, is considered as?

Options:
✓ Criminal abortion
  Has to be decided in the court
  Optional abortion
  Therapeutic abortion
  Upon mutual family decision

Explanation:
In Pakistani law, abortion is generally considered permissible only to save the life of the pregnant woman or to provide necessary treatment. Terminating a pregnancy solely for reasons related to studies, without a medical indication for the mother's health and against the husband's wishes, would be considered a criminal abortion.

================================================================================
Question 81 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A wife of a young adult male reported to their family doctor that her husband is found to have abnormal sexual behaviors during intimacy. She said that her husband feels pleasure for being pained and frequently asks to torture and bite him. What type of sexual perversion is this?

Options:
  Bondage
  Exhibitionism
  Fetishism
✓ Masochism
  Sadism

Explanation:
Masochism is a sexual perversion characterized by deriving sexual pleasure or gratification from suffering physical or psychological pain, humiliation, or abuse, often at the hands of a sexual partner.

================================================================================
Question 82 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A middle age 12 weeks pregnant women on her routine checkup found out during ultra sound that she is having a double sac with two fetuses. Initially in early days of her pregnancy there was only one fetus and sac What is this condition called?

Options:
  Dizygotic twins
  Monochorionic dizygotic twins
  Monozygotic twins
  Secretion
✓ Superfetation

Explanation:
Superfetation is a rare phenomenon where a second, new pregnancy is established in a woman who is already pregnant. This would result in two fetuses of different gestational ages within the same uterus, usually with different sacs.

================================================================================
Question 83 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 30 years old male patient presented with 30 mm renal pelvis stone. What treatment will you offer to patient?

Options:
  ESWL
  Conservation treatment
✓ PCNL
  URS
  Pyelolithotomy

Explanation:
For a large renal pelvis stone (30 mm = 3 cm), Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy (PCNL) is generally considered the treatment of choice. ESWL (Extracorporeal Shock Wave Lithotripsy) is less effective for stones of this size, and URS (Ureteroscopy) is more commonly used for ureteral stones.

================================================================================
Question 84 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 70 years old male presented e hesitancy , intermittent urination and nocturia , has USG shows 40 grams prostate. What treatment will you advise to patient ?

Options:
  Uretheral catheterization
  Anticholinergies drugs
✓ Alpha blockage drugs
  TURP
  Antibiotics

Explanation:
The patient's symptoms (hesitancy, intermittent urination, nocturia) are classic for lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) secondary to benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). Alpha-blockers (alpha-1 adrenergic antagonists) are typically the first-line pharmacological treatment for BPH, as they relax the smooth muscles of the prostate and bladder neck, improving urine flow.

================================================================================
Question 85 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 20 years old male presented with actual urinary retention. Urethral catheterization tried in emergency department but no sucessful. What will be next stip of management ?

Options:
  Retrograde uretherogram
✓ Suprapubic catheterization
  Optical urethrotomy
  Urethroplasty
  Laparotomy

Explanation:
In a patient with acute urinary retention where urethral catheterization is unsuccessful (e.g., due to severe urethral stricture or other obstruction), the next immediate step in management is suprapubic catheterization to decompress the bladder and relieve the retention.

================================================================================
Question 86 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 60 years old male presented with painless hematuria with passage of clots, he is also having irritative lower urinary tract symptoms, and he is smoker for the last 40 years. What is probable diagnosis?

Options:
  Enlarged prostate
✓ Bladder tumor
  Bladder stone
  Urinary tract infection
  Urethral stricture

Explanation:
Painless gross hematuria with passage of clots, especially in an older male smoker with irritative lower urinary tract symptoms, is highly suspicious for bladder tumor (urothelial carcinoma of the bladder). Smoking is the leading risk factor.

================================================================================
Question 87 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 20 year old man was reffered for pink discolouration of his urine. Three days ago he complained of a sore throat and was given a course of amoxicillin and ibuprofen by the GP but those symptoms have resolved now. urine dipstick showed blood ++, protein +, nitrites negative. What is the most likely diagnosis:

Options:
  Crescentic glomerulonephritis
  Wegener's granulomatosis
✓ IgA nephropathy
  Post streptococcal Glomerulonephritis
  Nephrotic syndrome

Explanation:
The presentation of gross hematuria (pink urine) following a recent upper respiratory tract infection (sore throat), with blood and protein on dipstick but negative nitrites, in a young man is highly suggestive of IgA nephropathy. This condition often presents as synpharyngitic hematuria.

================================================================================
Question 88 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 14 years old boy presented with three days history of abdominal pain, rash on the trunk buttocks and legs, his blood pressure is 140/90. Laboratory investigations: CBC: Hb 12g/dl TLC 9000 PLT 320000 Random blood glucose 120mg/ dl Anti Nuclear Antibodies : Negative Urea: 100mg/dl Creatinine : 2mg/dl Chest Xrays : Unremarkable Urine RE: RBCs++ Protein++ Pus cells 2-4/hpr. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Options:
  Post streptococcal glomerulonephritis
  IgA Nephropathy
✓ Henoch Schonlein syndrome
  SLE
  Minimal change disease

Explanation:
The classic triad of abdominal pain, palpable purpuric rash (especially on buttocks and legs), and renal involvement (hypertension, hematuria, proteinuria, elevated urea/creatinine) in a child is diagnostic of Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP), which is an IgA vasculitis.

================================================================================
Question 89 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Commonest cause of chronic Kidney Disease?

Options:
  Hypertension
✓ Diabetes mellitus
  Kidney stone
  SLE
  NSAIDs

Explanation:
Diabetes mellitus is the most common cause of chronic kidney disease (CKD) worldwide, leading to diabetic nephropathy. Hypertension is the second most common cause.

================================================================================
Question 90 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A boy with recurrent UTIs, who cann't pass urine in single stream, can have:

Options:
✓ Posterior urethral valves
  Horse shoe kidney
  Single kidney
  All of above
  None of above

Explanation:
In boys, recurrent urinary tract infections and an inability to pass urine in a single stream (indicating obstructive voiding) are highly suggestive of posterior urethral valves (PUV), which are congenital obstructive membranes in the male urethra.

================================================================================
Question 91 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 45 years old unmarried female presented in surgical OPD having painless lump in right upper outer quadrant of breast for last 3 months gradually increasing in size. Examination reveals hard mass, immobile attached to deeper tissue. What is likely diagnosis?

Options:
  Mammography
  Ultrasound breast
  Open biopsy
✓ FNAC
  MRI

Explanation:
For a suspicious breast lump (hard, immobile, attached to deeper tissue), particularly in a 45-year-old, tissue sampling is essential for diagnosis. Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology (FNAC) is a quick and less invasive initial biopsy technique to assess for malignancy. This would typically be part of a triple assessment including imaging.

================================================================================
Question 92 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 30 years old male patient presented with infertility. When sperm ejaculate analysis was done it came to be azoospermia and when further investigated it was found that there is obstruction in the ejaculatory duct. Which hormonal essay is done in this case?

Options:
  Serum testosterone
  Serum prolactin
  Luteinsing hormone
  prostate specific antigen
✓ Follicle stimulating hormone

Explanation:
In a male patient with azoospermia due to ejaculatory duct obstruction (obstructive azoospermia), FSH (Follicle Stimulating Hormone) levels are typically normal because the testes are still producing sperm (and inhibin B) and are responsive to FSH. Elevated FSH would suggest primary testicular failure, which is not the case here.

================================================================================
Question 93 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A young lady is diagnosed with breast carcinoma. One of her aunt died of breast cancer and her elder sister has ovarian tumor. Which of the following gene should be tested for mutation in this patient?

Options:
  P53
✓ BRCA
  ERBB
  ER/PR
  (Option missing)

Explanation:
A strong family history of breast and ovarian cancer in first-degree relatives (aunt, sister) significantly increases the suspicion of a hereditary cancer syndrome. Mutations in the BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes are the most common genetic cause of hereditary breast and ovarian cancer syndrome, making BRCA testing highly indicated.

================================================================================
Question 94 (GMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 30-year -old lady came with lumpy bumpy breast with breast pain during premenstrual time. If we take biopsy microscopy will reveal ...

Options:
✓ Cysts, fibrosis and adenosis
  Epithelial hyperplasia
  Invasive ductal carcinoma
  Invasive lobular carcinoma
  Ductal papilloma

Explanation:
The description 'lumpy bumpy breast with breast pain during premenstrual time' is classic for fibrocystic changes (also known as fibrocystic disease or condition) of the breast. Histologically, this benign condition is characterized by the presence of cysts, fibrosis, and adenosis.

================================================================================
Question 95 (GMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Which of the following is a feature of benign prostatic hyperplasia?

Options:
  Urinary frequency
  Urinary urgency
  Hesitancy
  Straining and dribbling
✓ All of the above

Explanation:
Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) is the enlargement of the prostate gland, which can compress the urethra and cause a variety of lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS). These include storage symptoms like urinary frequency and urgency, as well as voiding symptoms like hesitancy, straining to urinate, and post-void dribbling. Therefore, all the options listed are features of BPH.

================================================================================
Question 96 (GMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Which of the following is not a treatment option for Prostate cancer?

Options:
  EBRT
  TURP
  Brachytherapy
  Orchiectomy
✓ Gleason score

Explanation:
EBRT (External Beam Radiation Therapy), Brachytherapy (internal radiation), and Orchiectomy (removal of testicles to reduce testosterone) are all treatments for prostate cancer. TURP (Transurethral Resection of the Prostate) can be used to relieve urinary symptoms but is not a curative treatment for the cancer itself. The Gleason score is a grading system used to assess the aggressiveness of prostate cancer from a biopsy sample; it is a diagnostic and prognostic tool, not a treatment.

================================================================================
Question 97 (GMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 45 year old presented to surgical opd with history of 2x3 cm lump in right breast for 4 months how will you proceed to reach the diagnosis?

Options:
  Ultrasound breast
  Mammogram
  Core needle biopsy
✓ Tripple assessment
  None of the above

Explanation:
The standard of care for diagnosing a breast lump is the 'triple assessment'. This comprehensive approach includes three components: clinical breast examination, breast imaging (such as a mammogram and/or ultrasound), and a tissue sample for histology (like a core needle biopsy). Relying on only one of these methods is insufficient for a definitive diagnosis.

================================================================================
Question 98 (GMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 30 year old lady presented in opd with a 1x1 cm nodule over the scar of Modified radical mastectomy .she is a known case of carcinoma breast and underwent MRM 2 years back.how will you confirm or refute the diagnosis of recurrent carcinoma breast?

Options:
  Ultrasound Breast
  MRI Breast
  CT Scan Chest
✓ Biopsy
  None of the above

Explanation:
While imaging techniques like ultrasound, MRI, or CT scans can identify and characterize the nodule, a definitive diagnosis of cancer recurrence requires histological proof. A biopsy of the suspicious nodule is essential to examine the cells under a microscope and confirm whether they are malignant.

================================================================================
Question 99 (GMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 28 years old nulliparous lady with hirsuitism, oligomennorhoea and inability to conceive. She diagnosed as having polycystic ovaries on transvaginal ultrasound. "What is the correct option of her cancer in future?"

Options:
  Increased risk of breast cancer
  Increased risk of ovarian cancer
✓ Increased risk of endometrial hyperplasia and endometrial cancer
  Increased risk of large gut cancer
  None of them

Explanation:
Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) is characterized by chronic anovulation, which leads to prolonged exposure of the endometrium to estrogen without the opposing effects of progesterone. This unopposed estrogen stimulation can cause the endometrial lining to thicken excessively (endometrial hyperplasia), which is a precursor to endometrial cancer.

================================================================================
Question 100 (GMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Ovarian artery is a branch of which main artery:

Options:
  Internal iliac artery
  External iliac artery
✓ Aorta
  Femoral artery
  Both C and D

Explanation:
The ovarian arteries are paired arteries that arise directly from the anterolateral aspect of the abdominal aorta, typically inferior to the renal arteries at the L2 vertebral level.

================================================================================
Question 101 (GMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
In uncentrifuged sample of urine, definition of significant pyuria is:

Options:
  >3 leukocytes per high power field
✓ >10 leukocytes per high power field
  >10 leukocytes/cu.mm
  >5 leukocytes/cu.mm
  None of the above

Explanation:
Pyuria, the presence of white blood cells (leukocytes) in the urine, is a sign of inflammation, typically due to a urinary tract infection.
