An endometrial biopsy is the first-line and most important diagnostic step to obtain a tissue sample for histological analysis.

================================================================================
Question 192 (GMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Which of the following factors is protective against endometrial hyperplasia?

Options:
  Obesity
✓ Oral Contraceptive Pills
  Tamoxifen
  Early Menarche or Late Menopause
  Unopposed estrogen therapy

Explanation:
Combined Oral Contraceptive Pills (OCPs) contain both estrogen and progestin. The progestin component opposes the proliferative effect of estrogen on the endometrium, causing it to remain thin and stable. This regular progestin exposure is protective against the development of endometrial hyperplasia and cancer.

================================================================================
Question 193 (GMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A patient has diagnosed with endometrial cancer by endometrial biopsy. During her counseling regarding the disease , staging and prognosis the patient is told that most endometrial cancer are diagnosed at which of the following stages.

Options:
✓ I
  II
  III
  IV
  Recurrent

Explanation:
Endometrial cancer typically presents with an early and obvious symptom: postmenopausal or abnormal uterine bleeding. This symptom prompts women to seek medical attention early. As a result, approximately 70-80% of endometrial cancers are diagnosed at Stage I, when the cancer is still confined to the uterus, leading to a generally good prognosis.

================================================================================
Question 194 (GMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
In addition to personal history of hypertension or diabetes and family history of breast or ovarian cancer. Which of the following is a risk factor for CA endometrium?

Options:
  USE of OCPS
✓ Obesity
  history of STDs
  nulliparity
  HPV Infection

Explanation:
Obesity is a major risk factor for endometrial cancer. Adipose (fat) tissue is a site of peripheral conversion of androgens to estrogens. In obese women, this leads to higher circulating levels of unopposed estrogen, which stimulates the endometrium and increases the risk of hyperplasia and carcinoma. Nulliparity (d) is also a risk factor, but obesity is one of the strongest.

================================================================================
Question 195 (GMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 60 years old women develops post-menopausal. An endometrial biopsy shows endometrial carcinoma. She undergoes TAH with pelvic lymph node sampling. The final pathology shows tumor extending from the uterus in to the cervix but no other invasion. Lymph nodes were negative for metastasis. Stage of the cancer is,

Options:
  0
  I
✓ II
  III
  IV

Explanation:
According to the FIGO staging system for endometrial cancer, Stage II is defined as a tumor that invades the cervical stroma but does not extend beyond the uterus. Since the pathology shows the tumor extending into the cervix, the correct stage is II.

================================================================================
Question 196 (GMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 34 years G3P2 presented to outdoor with gestational amenorrhea of 4 months and PV spotting for 3 days .On examination abdomen was large for dates. Ultrasound examination showed snow storm appearance resemb: ing complete molar pregnancy. Bilateral theca luteal cysts. Her beta HCG was 20000 IU/L. The most appropriate treatment for her,

Options:
  D and C
  Cytotoxic drugs
  conservative/radio
  TAH with BSO
✓ Suction evacuation

Explanation:
The standard and preferred treatment for a molar pregnancy (hydatidiform mole) is to empty the uterus as soon as possible to prevent complications. Suction evacuation (also called suction curettage) is the method of choice because it effectively removes the molar tissue while minimizing the risk of uterine perforation and trophoblastic embolization compared to sharp curettage (D&C).

================================================================================
Question 197 (GMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 35 years G5P4 comes to the OPD with the molar pregnancy. You do suction evacuation and on histopathology it came out to be complete mole. Serum beta HCG is more than one lacs. Her previous pregnancy was full term. Chest x-ray shows cannon ball appearance. Chemo therapy for her?

Options:
✓ EMA/CO
  Methotrexate only
  Methotrexate with folinic acid
  Radiotherapy
  None of the above

Explanation:
This patient has developed high-risk gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN) following a molar pregnancy. The 'cannon ball' appearance on chest X-ray indicates lung metastases, and a very high beta-hCG level puts her in the high-risk category. The standard chemotherapy regimen for high-risk GTN is a multi-agent combination therapy, with EMA/CO (Etoposide, Methotrexate, Actinomycin D, Cyclophosphamide, and Oncovin/Vincristine) being the most common.

================================================================================
Question 198 (GMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Patient presents with molar pregnancy . All the workup was done and histopathology report there was no sign of malignancy.Which of the following includes further management

Options:
✓ Weekly beta HCG
  Ultrasound monitoring
  Hysterectomy
  Reassurance
  Annual beta HCG

Explanation:
After evacuation of a molar pregnancy, it is crucial to monitor for the development of persistent gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN). This is done by serially measuring serum beta-hCG levels. The standard protocol involves weekly beta-hCG tests until the levels are undetectable for three consecutive weeks, followed by monthly tests for at least six months to ensure there is no recurrence.

================================================================================
Question 199 (GMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Evacuation done after molar pregnancy, in which cause do we start single agent chemotherapy?

Options:
  Rise in HCG
  Liver mets
  Brain mets
  Lung mets
✓ HCG Plateau

Explanation:
Chemotherapy is indicated for post-molar gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN). Diagnostic criteria for GTN include a plateau of hCG levels (remaining static over 3 weeks), a rise in hCG levels (over 2 weeks), or the presence of metastases. A plateau in hCG levels when they are expected to be falling is a key indicator for initiating treatment, typically with single-agent chemotherapy (like methotrexate) for low-risk disease.

================================================================================
Question 200 (GMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Which of the following is a risk factor for developing a molar pregnancy?

Options:
✓ Being under 20 years old
  History of miscarriages
  Avoiding antenatal multi vitamins
  History of high blood pressure during pregnancy
  Not maintaining healthy weight during pregnancy

Explanation:
The risk of molar pregnancy is highest at the extremes of maternal age. Women who are very young (teenagers, particularly under 20) and women of advanced maternal age (over 35-40) have a significantly increased risk compared to women in their 20s and early 30s.

================================================================================
Question 201 (GMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 22- years old patient with her husband 28 years old non smoker . married for last 3 months presented to the OPD with chief complaints of unable to conceive. her menstural cycle is regular with no significant findings her management plan is ?

Options:
  MRI scan
  pelvic ultra sound
  semen analysis
✓ reassurance
  None of the above

Explanation:
Infertility is generally defined as the inability to conceive after 12 months of regular, unprotected intercourse. This couple is young, has only been trying for 3 months, and has no significant risk factors. The vast majority of healthy young couples will conceive within the first year. Therefore, the most appropriate management at this stage is reassurance and education about timed intercourse, with no need for invasive investigations.

================================================================================
Question 202 (GMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 35-years-old woman presented to gynae OPD with her husband age 56year old, non-smoker, truck driver with normal semen analysis, primary subfertility for the last 10 years. She had a history of pain during menstruation and lower abdominal pain on and off. She experiences marked pain during coitus. Ultrasound sound shows left adenaxal mass with ground glass appearance. What could be the most probable cause of her infertility?

Options:
  Adenomyosis
✓ Endometriosis
  Fibroid
  Dermoid cyst
  None of the above

Explanation:
The patient's symptoms of dysmenorrhea (painful periods), chronic pelvic pain, and dyspareunia (painful intercourse) are classic for endometriosis. Furthermore, an adnexal mass with a 'ground glass' appearance on ultrasound is the characteristic finding of an endometrioma (a 'chocolate cyst'), which is a cyst on the ovary filled with old blood that forms as a result of endometriosis.

================================================================================
Question 203 (GMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
The maximum external dimension of uterine cavity is:

Options:
  7 x 7.5 x 4.5 cm
✓ 7.5 x 5 x 3 cm
  7.5 x 5 x 5 cm
  8.5 x 6 x 4 cm
  7.5 x 5 x 2 cm

Explanation:
The average dimensions of a normal, nulliparous adult uterus are approximately 7.5 to 8 cm in length (fundus to cervix), 5 cm in width at the fundus, and 2.5 to 3 cm in anteroposterior thickness. Option B most closely matches these standard anatomical measurements.

================================================================================
Question 204 (GMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 20- year-old , weight 50Kg , presents with history of something coming out of vagina since 2 years. On vaginal examination she is having 3rd degree U/V prolapse. What treatment option will you give?

Options:
✓ Sacro- colpopexy / Sacro- hysteropexy
  Vaginal hysterectomy
  Manchester repair
  Colporrhaphy
  Ring pessary

Explanation:
In a very young woman (20 years old) with severe uterine prolapse who wishes to preserve her uterus for future fertility, a hysterectomy is not appropriate. A sacrocolpopexy (if the uterus is removed) or sacrohysteropexy (if the uterus is preserved) is the best surgical option. This procedure uses a mesh to suspend the apex of the vagina or the uterus to the sacrum, providing strong, durable apical support while preserving the organs. It is considered the gold standard for apical prolapse, especially in young, active patients.

================================================================================
Question 205 (GMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
The MOST common cause of permanent congenital hypothyroidism is

Options:
  Dyshormonogenesis
✓ Thyroid dysgenesis
  IODINE deficiency
  Defect of iodide transport
  Pended syndrome

Explanation:
Thyroid dysgenesis, which refers to an abnormality in the development of the thyroid gland (including agenesis, hypoplasia, or an ectopic gland), accounts for approximately 85% of cases of permanent congenital hypothyroidism and is the most common cause worldwide.

================================================================================
Question 206 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
The national zero hunger programme launched in Pakistan with the approval of vision 2025, which prioritize food security and among main areas of focus.

Options:
  Food
  Malnutrition
  Nutrients
✓ Nutrition
  Water

Explanation:
The National Zero Hunger Programme aims to achieve not just food security but also improved nutrition, encompassing the broader aspects of dietary quality and health outcomes.

================================================================================
Question 207 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
The national zero hunger is aligned with which sustainable development goal?

Options:
  SDG1
✓ SDG2
  SDG3
  SDG4
  SDG5

Explanation:
The National Zero Hunger Programme is directly aligned with Sustainable Development Goal 2 (SDG 2), which specifically targets ending hunger, achieving food security and improved nutrition, and promoting sustainable agriculture.

================================================================================
Question 208 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
The depth of the food deficit indicates how many ____ would be needed to lift the undernourished from their status, everything else being constant.

Options:
✓ Calories
  Energy
  Joules
  Kilojoules
  Nutrient

Explanation:
The depth of the food deficit is a measure that indicates the average number of calories that would be needed to lift the undernourished population to a minimum dietary energy requirement.

================================================================================
Question 209 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
_____ has been a major constraint for purchasing and consuming quality foods for majority of the population.

Options:
  Economic issues
  Food insecurity
  Food security
  Economic issues
✓ Household income

Explanation:
Low household income is a direct and major economic constraint that limits the ability of a majority of the population to afford and consume quality and nutritious foods.

================================================================================
Question 210 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Which option should be chosen by HIV-positive mother in India for feeding her baby?

Options:
  Exclusive Breast Feeding
✓ Exclusive Formula Milk
  Maxed (Breast plus Formula)
  Cow Milk
  No Breastfeeding at all

Explanation:
For HIV-positive mothers, exclusive formula feeding, when acceptable, feasible, affordable, sustainable, and safe (AFASS), is recommended to completely eliminate the risk of HIV transmission through breast milk.

================================================================================
Question 211 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A mother has sufficient breast milk supply. She wants to give her child 1-2 cups of animal milk per day over & above the food she is giving. Appropriate time to do so will be after the baby is:

Options:
  6 month
✓ 1 year
  18 months
  2 years
  4-36 months

Explanation:
It is generally recommended to introduce animal milk, such as cow's milk, as a primary drink only after a baby is 1 year old, as their digestive system is more mature and better able to handle its components.

================================================================================
Question 212 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
The process of burning municipal solid waste at high temperature is called:

Options:
✓ Incineration
  Compositing
  Land filling
  Shredding
  Tyndalization

Explanation:
Incineration is the process of burning municipal solid waste at high temperatures in controlled conditions to reduce its volume and mass and to destroy hazardous components.

================================================================================
Question 213 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
To protect RTA for Pedestrian, What should you wear to seen easily by traffic at night?

Options:
  Dark field
✓ Bright florescent
  Pale Colored clothes
  Trendy Cloth
  Not Attempted

Explanation:
Wearing bright fluorescent or reflective clothing significantly increases a pedestrian's visibility to traffic, especially at night or in low-light conditions, thereby enhancing safety and protecting against road traffic accidents.

================================================================================
Question 214 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
During antenatal checkup abdominal examination is important to check for gestational age and fetal condition, the obstetrician can do this abdominal examination:

Options:
  Between 14 to 34 weeks only
  During last trimester only
  From first week of pregnancy
  From 12 weeks onward
✓ From 16 weeks onward

Explanation:
Abdominal examination, including palpation for fundal height and fetal parts, becomes reliably informative for assessing gestational age and fetal condition from approximately 16 weeks of gestation onward.

================================================================================
Question 215 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Hemoglobin measurement is an important part of antenatal checkup, A woman has hemoglobin 12.5 before conception, during first trimester of pregnancy her hemoglobin value drops to 11, it is truly described as:

Options:
  Iron deficiency anemia
  Mild anemia
  Moderate anemia
✓ Physiological anemia
  Severe anemia

Explanation:
A slight drop in hemoglobin levels during the first trimester of pregnancy, such as from 12.5 to 11 g/dL, is often considered physiological anemia due to the disproportionate increase in plasma volume (hemodilution) compared to red blood cell mass.

================================================================================
Question 216 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
In addition to other important causes, abortion is also a leading cause of maternal mortality in developing countries, women die due to abortion when:

Options:
✓ Abortion is illegal/unsafe
  Gestational age is below 6 weeks
  Gestational age is 4 weeks
  Gestational age is above 10 weeks
  No blood is transfused

Explanation:
Unsafe or illegal abortions performed by untrained individuals or in unhygienic conditions are a leading cause of maternal mortality in developing countries, often resulting from complications like hemorrhage, infection, and trauma.

================================================================================
Question 217 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Post abortion care includes curative care and preventive care, the second one mainly focuses on Prevention of:

Options:
  Abortion being done by untrained
  Chances of bleeding after abortion
  Chances of fever after abortion
  Introducing unnecessary medications
✓ Future unwanted pregnancy

Explanation:
Preventive post-abortion care primarily focuses on preventing future unwanted pregnancies by providing comprehensive counseling on family planning and ensuring access to appropriate contraceptive methods.

================================================================================
Question 218 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Demographic transition is:

Options:
  Birth rate timeline of population
✓ High difference between CBR and CDR
  Gap in sex percentage
  Gap in extreme age
  No gap between birth rate and death rate

Explanation:
Demographic transition is a model describing the historical shift from high birth and death rates to low birth and death rates. A key characteristic of the expanding stages of this transition is a significant difference between the Crude Birth Rate (CBR) and Crude Death Rate (CDR), leading to population growth.

================================================================================
Question 219 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Sex ratio is:

Options:
  One female per 1000 male
  One male per 1000 female
  1000 female per 1000 male
✓ Number of female per 1000 male
  Average male to female ratio

Explanation:
The sex ratio is commonly defined as the number of females per 1000 males (or sometimes males per 100 females) in a population.

================================================================================
Question 220 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
The age and sex structure of a population may be described by:

Options:
  Bar chart
  Correlation efficient
  Life table
✓ Population pyramid
  Sex ratio

Explanation:
A population pyramid is a graphical illustration that shows the distribution of various age groups in a population, which also provides insights into the sex ratio for each age cohort, effectively describing the age and sex structure.

================================================================================
Question 221 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
The carrying capacity of any given population is determined by its:

Options:
  Birth rate
  Death rate
  Eco system
  Population growth rate
✓ Limiting resource

Explanation:
The carrying capacity of a population refers to the maximum population size that the environment can sustain indefinitely, given the available resources. This capacity is primarily determined by the most limiting resource (e.g., food, water, habitat).

================================================================================
Question 222 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
HIV (human immunodeficiency virus) destroys human immune parasitizes:

Options:
  B-cells
  X-helper cells
  T-cells
✓ T-helper cells
  Y-helper cells

Explanation:
Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) specifically targets and destroys CD4+ T-helper cells, which are crucial components of the human immune system, leading to its progressive weakening and AIDS.

================================================================================
Question 223 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Currently, Pakistan is in which stage of the demographic cycle:

Options:
  Early stationary
  High stationary
✓ Late stationary
  Low stationary
  Stable

Explanation:
Pakistan is generally considered to be in the 'late expanding' or 'third stage' of the demographic transition, characterized by declining birth rates and already low death rates, resulting in continued but slowing population growth. Among the given options, 'Late stationary' would imply a stage moving towards stabilization after significant expansion.

================================================================================
Question 224 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
52 years old lady had her last menstrual period 12 months back, presented in out-patient department with a complaint of hot flushes, abdomen and irritability. Which one of the following hormones is responsible for these Vasomotor changes?

Options:
  Decreased levels of ILH
  Decreased levels of progesterone
  Increased level of FSH
  Increased level of prolactin
✓ Reduced estrogen level

Explanation:
The vasomotor symptoms (hot flashes, night sweats) associated with menopause, along with irritability, are primarily caused by the decline and fluctuation of estrogen levels in the body.

================================================================================
Question 225 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 50 years old para 6 has experienced a complaint of mood changes, hot flushes, irritability and loss of libido. She is very anxious about her symptoms and wants to get them treated. Which one of the following is an absolute contraindication to hormone replacement therapy (HRT)?

Options:
  Chronic Liver disease
  Increased bone mineral density
  Previous history of benign breast disease
✓ Uncontrolled hypertension
  Uterine fibroid

Explanation:
Uncontrolled hypertension is an absolute contraindication to Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) due to the increased risk of cardiovascular events. While other options like chronic liver disease are important, uncontrolled hypertension carries immediate and severe risks.

================================================================================
Question 226 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
55 years old women who has gone through her menopause, is very concerned that she may develop bone fractures. What is the most effective way of preventing pathological fractures in post menupausal women?

Options:
  Clonidine
✓ Combined oral estrogen and progesterone pills
  Phytoestrogen
  Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor
  Vaginal estrogen

Explanation:
Combined oral estrogen and progesterone therapy (systemic HRT) is the most effective pharmacological treatment for preventing bone loss and reducing the risk of osteoporotic fractures in postmenopausal women, especially when initiated around menopause.

================================================================================
Question 227 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
49 years old lady who is amenorrheic for the last 12 months, is complaining of increased sweating at night, hot flushes and disturb sleep patterns? She went to her GP where her laboratory tests were done in which she had raised FSH levels. Which one of the following is most appropriate for the diagnosis of menopause?

Options:
✓ Absent menstruation for 1 year at this age.
  Bloating and irritability
  Changes in sleep pattern
  History of night sweats
  Raised level of FSH

Explanation:
The most appropriate clinical criterion for diagnosing menopause is the cessation of menstruation for 12 consecutive months without any other obvious pathological or physiological cause. The raised FSH levels provide biochemical confirmation.

================================================================================
Question 228 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 22 years old girl has a secondary amenorrhea of 12 months. She is being diagnosed with premature ovarian insufficiency. Which one of the following is responsible for this condition?

Options:
  Increased estradiol level
  LH reduced and FSH increased
  Low FSH, Raised LH
✓ Raised FSH, low estradiol level
  Raised Gonadotrophins

Explanation:
Premature ovarian insufficiency (POI) is characterized by ovarian dysfunction leading to amenorrhea before age 40. Hormonally, it presents with elevated follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) levels and low estradiol levels, reflecting the ovaries' diminished response to gonadotropin stimulation.

================================================================================
Question 229 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 20 years old patient presents in outpatient department with a history of 2 months amenorrhea and vaginal bleeding. Her ultrasound report shows 8 weeks single viable intrauterine pregnancy. Per speculum examination shows close cervical Os with no active bleeding. What is your management in this case?

Options:
  Oral antibiotics
  Oral misoprostol
  Oral mifepristone
  Oral tranxamic acid
✓ Supportive treatment

Explanation:
This clinical picture describes a threatened miscarriage: vaginal bleeding in early pregnancy with a viable intrauterine pregnancy and a closed cervical os. The most appropriate management is supportive treatment, including rest and close observation, as there is no intervention proven to stop a threatened miscarriage.

================================================================================
Question 230 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 25 years old patient is presented in out-patient department with history of irregular menstrual bleeding. Her urine pregnancy test is positive and her ultrasound report shows 7 weeks intrauterine pregnancy with absent cardiac activity. What is your diagnosis?

Options:
  Ectopic pregnancy
  Incomplete abortion
  Inevitable abortion
✓ Missed abortion
  Threatened abortion

Explanation:
A missed abortion (or missed miscarriage) is diagnosed when an intrauterine pregnancy is identified, but fetal cardiac activity is absent, and the products of conception are retained within the uterus without spontaneous expulsion.

================================================================================
Question 231 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 28 years old patient in emergency with a complaint of amenorrhea of 2 months, lower abdominal pain and heavy vaginal bleeding. Her urine pregnancy test is positive. Her blood pressure is 80/60 mmHg, pulse is feeble and speculum examination shows open cervical os with a passage of clots and fleshy protruding through the cervical os. What is your management?

Options:
  Bed rest and reassurance
✓ Immediate evacuation and curettage
  Intravenous antibiotics
  Intravenous tranxamic acid
  Oral misoprostol

Explanation:
This patient is presenting with signs of an inevitable or incomplete abortion (amenorrhea, abdominal pain, heavy bleeding, positive UPT, open cervical os with tissue) and is hemodynamically unstable (BP 80/60, feeble pulse). Immediate evacuation and curettage is the priority to stop the bleeding and stabilize her condition.

================================================================================
Question 232 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 22 years old nulliparous patient presents in outpatient department with a history of complete miscarriages at 8 weeks gestation. What is the most common aetiological factors for first trimester miscarriage?

Options:
✓ Chromosomal abnormalities
  Drugs/ Chemical
  Medical disorder
  Perinatal infections
  Uterine abnormalities

Explanation:
Chromosomal abnormalities (e.g., aneuploidy) are by far the most common etiological factor for first-trimester miscarriages, accounting for 50-70% of all pregnancy losses during this period.

================================================================================
Question 233 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 26 years old patient with vaginal bleeding and positive pregnancy test. Her ultrasound report shows a 8 weeks intrauterine pregnancy. What would it be reasonable to offer her, choose single best answer?

Options:
  Laparoscopy
  Methotrexate
  Misoprostol
  Progesterone
✓ Serum HCG measurements

Explanation:
For a patient with vaginal bleeding and a confirmed 8-week intrauterine pregnancy, monitoring serial serum hCG measurements can help assess pregnancy viability and rule out complications like ectopic pregnancy, especially if there's any ambiguity in the ultrasound findings or a concern for threatened abortion. Progesterone may be offered in some cases but requires clinical judgment.

================================================================================
Question 234 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 55 year old woman with a history of obesity and hypertension visits her gynaecologist for a routine check up. She reports having irregular vaginal bleeding for the past two months. She is not taking any medications and his no family history of cancer. The gynaecologist suspects that she may have endometrial cancer and order a biopsy of her endometrium. What type of endometrial cancer is most likely in this case?

Options:
  Adenoacanthoma
  Adenoacanthoma with squamous differentiation
  Clear cell carcinoma
✓ Endometrioid adenocarcinoma
  Uterine serous carcinoma

Explanation:
Given the patient's age, obesity, hypertension, and presentation with irregular vaginal bleeding, the most likely type of endometrial cancer is endometrioid adenocarcinoma (Type I). This type is estrogen-dependent and is commonly associated with hyperestrogenic states and metabolic risk factors.

================================================================================
Question 235 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 60 year old woman presents to her gynaecologist with postmenopausal bleeding. She has no history of hormone replacement therapy. What is the most common clinical feature of endometrial carcinoma?

Options:
  Abdominal pain
  Dyspareunia
✓ Postmenopausal bleeding
  Urinary incontinence
  Vaginal discharge

Explanation:
Postmenopausal bleeding is the most common and often the earliest clinical symptom of endometrial carcinoma. Any bleeding after menopause warrants prompt investigation to rule out this malignancy.

================================================================================
Question 236 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 52 year old woman with a history of obesity and diabetes is diagnosed with stage I endometrioid adenocarcinoma after experiencing abnormal uterine bleeding. She undergoes a total hysterectomy with bilateral salpingoophorectomy. The pathology report shows a grade 1 Tumor with no myometrial invasion. No cervical or ovarian involvement is seen. What is the most appropriate adjuvant therapy for her case?

Options:
  Chemotherapy
  Combined chemotherapy and radiotherapy
  External beam pelvic radiotherapy
✓ No adjuvant therapy is required
  Vaginal brachytherapy

Explanation:
For Stage I, Grade 1 endometrioid adenocarcinoma with no myometrial invasion and no involvement of cervix or ovaries (indicating a very low-risk tumor confined to the endometrium), often no adjuvant therapy is required after total hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy.

================================================================================
Question 237 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 45 year old woman with a history of breast cancer is prescribed tamoxifen, a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM), as part of her adjuvant therapy. She is aware that tamoxifen can reduce the risk of breast cancer recurrence, but also increase the risk of endometrial cancer. She asks her oncologist what she can do to prevent endometrial cancer while taking tamoxifen. What is the best advice that the oncologist can give her?

Options:
  Avoid consuming alcohol
✓ Maintain a healthy weight and exercise regularly
  Stop taking tamoxifen & switch to another medication
  Should take a low dose aspirin daily
  Undergo regular endometrial biopsies to detect

Explanation:
Maintaining a healthy weight and engaging in regular exercise are crucial lifestyle modifications that can help reduce the risk of endometrial cancer, even in women taking tamoxifen, by mitigating other risk factors like obesity-related estrogen production. Regular endometrial biopsies are for screening/detection, not prevention.

================================================================================
Question 238 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 15 years old unmarried girl presented with marked anemia and haemoglobin of 5 gm/dl. She gave history of heavy irregular cycle since menarche, her Blood clotting profile is normal with normal platelet count. The most probable diagnosis is?

Options:
  Chronic anemia
  Hemophilia
✓ Pubertal menorrhagia
  Vwb factor deficiency
  Worm infection

Explanation:
Heavy irregular cycles (menorrhagia) since menarche, especially leading to severe anemia, in an adolescent with normal clotting factors, strongly suggests pubertal menorrhagia, which is often due to anovulatory cycles and unopposed estrogen leading to excessive endometrial proliferation and bleeding. Von Willebrand factor deficiency would affect clotting profile.

================================================================================
Question 239 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 35 years old women presented with heavy irregular menses she has experienced spontaneous miscarriages over past 5 years, her pelvic examination demonstrates an enlarged irregular uterus. Her haemoglobin is 8gm/dl. Her urine pregnancy test is negative. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?

Options:
  Adenaxal torsion
  Ovarian teratoma
  Endometriosis
  Pregnancy
✓ Fibroid uterus

Explanation:
The symptoms of heavy, irregular menses, spontaneous miscarriages (due to uterine distortion), an enlarged, irregular uterus on examination, and anemia are highly characteristic of uterine fibroids.

================================================================================
Question 240 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 20 years old obese unmarried girl presented with amenorrhea for two months, she give history of infrequent menses with scanty flow. She developed facial hairs and temporal baldness. On ultrasound her uterus is normal with enlarged polycystic ovaries. What the diagnosis?

Options:
  Cushing syndrome
  Ovarian cysts
✓ Polycystic ovarian syndrome
  Pregnancy
  Miscarriage

Explanation:
The clinical picture of amenorrhea, infrequent menses with scanty flow (oligomenorrhea), hirsutism (facial hairs, temporal baldness), obesity, and polycystic ovaries on ultrasound are classic diagnostic features of Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome (PCOS).

================================================================================
Question 241 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 34 years old female para 4 had contraceptive injection one month ago she presented with continuous per vaginal spotting there is no bleed free days she is very worried what could be the possible treatment?

Options:
  Tab primolut N
  Tab Panadol
✓ Reassure and cap transamin
  No treatment
  Admit patient give iv antibiotics

Explanation:
Continuous per vaginal spotting is a common side effect of progesterone-only injectable contraceptives (like DMPA). The initial management usually involves reassurance, counseling about this common side effect, and potentially prescribing tranexamic acid (cap transamin) to reduce the bleeding if it's bothersome.

================================================================================
Question 242 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 46 years old patient para 5 presented with irregular bleeding her family is completed and she wants cure for her disease. She had history of blood transfusion twice. She had multiple fibroids on ultrasound. Wants the treatment?

Options:
  No treatment
  Myomectomy
✓ Hysterectomy
  Dnc
  Cap transamin

Explanation:
Given her age (46), completed family, severe symptoms (irregular bleeding requiring transfusions), and presence of multiple fibroids, hysterectomy is often the definitive and curative treatment of choice for symptomatic uterine fibroids in women who do not desire future fertility.

================================================================================
Question 243 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Fibroid uterus is a:

Options:
✓ Benign tumor of smooth muscle of uterus
  Malignant tumor of smooth muscle of uterus
  Benign tumor of ovaries
  Malignant tumor of ovaries
  None of the above

Explanation:
Uterine fibroids, also known as leiomyomas or myomas, are benign (non-cancerous) tumors that arise from the smooth muscle cells of the uterus.

================================================================================
Question 244 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
The most common benign gynecological of women's of reproductive age is:

Options:
  Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia
  Follicular ovarian cyst
✓ Leiomyoma
  Endometrial carcinoma
  None of the above

Explanation:
Uterine leiomyomas (fibroids) are the most common benign gynecological tumors in women of reproductive age.

================================================================================
Question 245 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Fibroids uterus are usually:

Options:
✓ Asymptomatic
  Symptomatic
  Lethal
  Aggressive in nature
  None of the above

Explanation:
Many uterine fibroids are asymptomatic and are discovered incidentally during routine pelvic exams or imaging. However, when symptomatic, they can cause significant issues like heavy bleeding and pain.

================================================================================
Question 246 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Growth of fibroid is dependent on:

Options:
  Estrogen
  Progesterone
  Cortisol
✓ Estrogen and progesterone
  None of the above

Explanation:
The growth of uterine fibroids is primarily influenced by both estrogen and progesterone, with both hormones playing crucial roles in their development and proliferation.

================================================================================
Question 247 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
What is diagnostic test used for fibroids?

Options:
✓ Ultrasound PELVIS
  MRI
  X-ray
  CT SCAN
  None of the above

Explanation:
Pelvic ultrasound is the primary and most commonly used diagnostic test for identifying and characterizing uterine fibroids due to its accessibility, cost-effectiveness, and ability to visualize the uterus. MRI is also highly effective but usually reserved for more complex cases.

================================================================================
Question 248 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 28 years old women trying to conceive for the last 8 years is having a history of irregular cycles. Now has presented to you with some vaginal spotting and severe pain in the right lower quadrant of abdomen. On her initial ultrasound scan in ER there is empty uterus with some collection in pouch of Douglas is reported. The most likely diagnosis in her case is.

Options:
  Ruptured appendix
  Acute cholecystitis
✓ Ruptured ectopic pregnancy
  Mesenteric lymphadenitis
  Cecal perforation

Explanation:
The combination of amenorrhea (implied by trying to conceive for 8 years and potential recent conception leading to spotting), severe unilateral lower abdominal pain, an empty uterus on ultrasound, and free fluid in the Pouch of Douglas (indicating internal bleeding) is highly indicative of a ruptured ectopic pregnancy.

================================================================================
Question 249 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 26 year old P1 who had a vaginal delivery 14 months back has been brought to emergency department with history of sudden fainting in kitchen. She is looking pale on examination with pulse rate of 120 beats per minutes, BP 80/60 mmHg. Per abdomen examination there is fullness in lower abdomen. On vaginal examination, cervical movements are very tender. The most appropriate management option for her would be.

Options:
  Conservative management with blood transfusion
✓ Preparation for urgent laparotomy
  Dilatation and curettage
  I/V Antibiotics
  Diagnostic laparoscopy

Explanation:
This patient is hemodynamically unstable (fainting, pale, tachycardia, hypotension) with signs of intra-abdominal bleeding (fullness, cervical motion tenderness). This clinical picture, even 14 months postpartum, suggests an acute gynecological emergency like a ruptured ovarian cyst or a delayed ruptured ectopic pregnancy (though less likely at this interval, but points to acute hemorrhage). Urgent laparotomy is indicated for diagnosis and control of hemorrhage.

================================================================================
Question 250 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 34 year old woman who was under investigation for primary infertility presented with history of amenorrhea for 14 days and urine pregnancy test is positive. Her ultrasound scan reports empty uterine cavity but presence of right sided adnexal mass about 4x4 cm with increased vascularity. There is no free fluid in pouch of Douglas. The most appropriate treatment option in her would be.

Options:
✓ I/M methotrexate with serial hCG
  Posterior colpotomy
  Diagnostic laparoscopy
  Exploratory laparotomy
  Serum progesterone levels

Explanation:
This scenario strongly points to an unruptured ectopic pregnancy (positive UPT, empty uterus, adnexal mass with vascularity, no free fluid). Given her stability and the size, medical management with intramuscular methotrexate and serial hCG monitoring is often the first-line treatment for suitable cases of unruptured ectopic pregnancy.

================================================================================
Question 251 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 36 year old patient has received an IM Methotrexate injection as medical line of management for her right sided ectopic pregnancy 8 days ago. She has now come for follow up with fresh hCG level reports. What levels of beta-hCG would be considered as satisfactory response of IM Methotrexate?

Options:
  Half the initial level
  2/3rd the initial level
✓ 25% or more below initial level
  5% or below the initial level
  Rise of 10% at this stage of insignificant

Explanation:
After methotrexate treatment for ectopic pregnancy, a satisfactory response is typically defined as a decrease in serum beta-hCG of at least 15% between Day 4 and Day 7, or a decrease of 25% or more from the baseline level by Day 7 post-treatment. Among the given options, '25% or more below initial level' represents a generally accepted decrease.

================================================================================
Question 252 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 22-year-old woman has been sexually assaulted. She requests a postcoital contraceptive. Which of the following usually Is the most appropriate drug, assuming no contraindications?

Options:
  Ergonovine (or methylergonovine)
✓ Mifepristone
  Raloxifene
  Ritodrine
  Tamoxifen

Explanation:
Mifepristone (an antiprogestin) is an effective emergency contraceptive, often used in cases of sexual assault. It can be used up to 120 hours after unprotected intercourse. Levonorgestrel (Plan B) is also a common option.

================================================================================
Question 253 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
We prescribe bromocriptine for a woman with primary amenorrhea. Normal menstruation returns about a month after starting therapy. Which of the following statements best described the mechanism by which bromocriptine caused its desired effects?

Options:
  Blocked estrogen receptors, enhanced gonadotropin release
  Increased follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) synthesis
✓ Inhibited prolactin release
  Stimulated ovarian estrogen and progestin synthesis
  Stimulated gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) release

Explanation:
Bromocriptine is a dopamine agonist that inhibits prolactin release from the pituitary gland. Hyperprolactinemia is a common cause of primary or secondary amenorrhea by suppressing GnRH release, thus inhibiting ovulation. By lowering prolactin, bromocriptine restores normal ovulatory function and menstruation.

================================================================================
Question 254 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A patient with a previously undiagnosed thyroid cancer presents with thyrotoxicosis (thyroid storm). One drug that is administered as part of early management, and may be lifesaving, is propranolol. Which of the following best summarizes why we give this drug, or what we want it to do?

Options:
  Block thyroid receptors
  Block thyroid hormone release by a direct effect on the gland
  Inhibit thyroid hormone synthesis
✓ Lessen dangerous cardiovascular symptoms of hyperthyroidism
  Lower TSH levels

Explanation:
Propranolol, a non-selective beta-blocker, is given in thyroid storm to rapidly control the severe cardiovascular symptoms of hyperthyroidism, such as tachycardia, palpitations, and tremor, which are mediated by sympathetic overactivity. It also has a minor effect on inhibiting peripheral conversion of T4 to T3.

================================================================================
Question 255 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A patient with Cushing's syndrome is being treated by X-irradiation of the pituitary. It may take several months of treatment for adequate symptomatic and metabolic improvement. Until that time, which of the following might be administered adjunctively to suppress glucocorticoid synthesis?

Options:
  Cimetidine
  Cortisol (massive doses)
  Fludrocortisone
✓ Ketoconazole
  Spironolactone

Explanation:
Ketoconazole is an antifungal agent that, at higher doses, inhibits several cytochrome P450 enzymes involved in adrenal steroid synthesis, including cortisol synthesis. It can be used adjunctively to suppress glucocorticoid production in Cushing's syndrome while awaiting the effects of pituitary irradiation.

================================================================================
Question 256 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 35-year-old woman has Graves' disease, a small goiter, and symptoms that are deemed "mild to moderate." Propylthiouracil is prescribed. Which of the following is the most serious adverse response to this drug, for which close monitoring is required?

Options:
✓ Agranulocytosis
  Cholestatic jaundice
  Gout
  Renal tubular necrosis
  Rhabdomyolysis

Explanation:
Agranulocytosis (a severe decrease in white blood cells) is a rare but life-threatening adverse effect of propylthiouracil (PTU) and other thionamides, requiring close monitoring and immediate discontinuation if suspected. Severe liver injury is also a serious concern with PTU.

================================================================================
Question 257 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 50-year-old woman at very high risk of breast cancer is given Tamoxifen for prophylaxis. Tamoxifen does which of the following in this situation?

Options:
✓ Blocks estrogen receptors in breast tissue
  Blocks estrogen receptors in the endometrium
  Increases the risk of osteoporosis
  Raises serum LDL cholesterol and total cholesterol, lowers HDL
  Reduces the risk of thromboembolic disorders

Explanation:
Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that acts as an estrogen receptor antagonist in breast tissue, thereby blocking estrogen's proliferative effects and reducing the risk of breast cancer.

================================================================================
Question 258 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Clinical study was performed on patients having Glomerulonephritis. One group was diagnosis with Crescentic glomerulonephritis and another group with Membranous glomerulonephritis. Which one of the following laboratory findings is most likely to be found in group with Membranous glomerulonephritis in the absence of other findings?

Options:
  Rapid onset
  Red blood cell casts
  Oliguria
✓ Albuminuria
  Hypertension

Explanation:
Membranous glomerulonephritis is a common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults, and its hallmark laboratory finding is significant proteinuria, primarily albuminuria, which often leads to hypoalbuminemia and edema. Rapid onset, red blood cell casts, oliguria, and hypertension are more characteristic of nephritic syndromes.

================================================================================
Question 259 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Hematuria is least likely to occur in:

Options:
✓ Minimal change disease
  Acute post-infectious glomerulonephritis
  Urinary lithiasis
  Renal tubular adenocarcinoma
  Membrano-glomerulo nephritis

Explanation:
Minimal change disease is characterized by selective proteinuria (leading to nephrotic syndrome) and is notable for the absence of significant hematuria, unlike most other glomerulonephritides or conditions causing urinary bleeding.

================================================================================
Question 260 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Urinalysis results showing proteinuria, many red blood cells, red blood casts and 1-2 white blood cells per high power field. Which of the following diseases best fits with these findings:

Options:
  Acute pyelonephritis
  Acute cystitis
  Minimal change disease
✓ Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis
  Polycystic kidney disease

Explanation:
The urinalysis findings of proteinuria, numerous red blood cells, and red blood cell casts are characteristic of a nephritic syndrome. Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis classically presents with these features.

================================================================================
Question 261 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
The majority of patients with acute post-streptococcal GN:

Options:
✓ Recovers completely
  Die from congestive heart failure in a few weeks
  Occurs in diabetes
  Die from renal failure in few weeks
  Progress through sub-acute phase to chronic glomerulonephritis

Explanation:
The vast majority of children and most adults with acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (APSGN) have a good prognosis and recover completely with supportive care, without progressing to chronic kidney disease.

================================================================================
Question 262 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A histopathological glomerular lesion that strongly suggests diabetes mellitus is:

Options:
  Absence of foot processes
  Extensive crescent formation
  Splitting of basement membrane
✓ Nodular glomerulosclerosis
  Linear IgG and C3 on immunofluorescence

Explanation:
Nodular glomerulosclerosis, characterized by the formation of Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules, is a highly characteristic and virtually pathognomonic histopathological lesion for diabetic nephropathy.

================================================================================
Question 263 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A patient presents with proteinuria, edema, and symptoms of renal insufficiency. There appears to be nodular hyaline masses in the glomerulus of the kidney. Tests indicate that the kidney has enlarged. The disease with the most similar presentation would be?

Options:
  IgA nephropathy
✓ Diabetic nephropathy
  Membrano proliferative GN
  Lipoid nephrosis
  Dense membrane disease

Explanation:
The clinical presentation of proteinuria, edema, renal insufficiency, enlarged kidneys (in early stages), and the presence of nodular hyaline masses in the glomeruli (Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules) is highly characteristic of diabetic nephropathy.

================================================================================
Question 264 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A child with strep infection, a week later develops hypertension, hematuria, edema and oliguria. Elevated levels of anti-streptolysin O antibodies are found in the serum. What is the key morphological features of this disease:

Options:
  Spike and doom appearance
✓ Humps
  Deposition of IgM and C3
  Ribbon like basement membrane
  Splitting of basement membrane

Explanation:
The clinical picture describes acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (APSGN). The key morphological feature seen on electron microscopy of a kidney biopsy in APSGN is the presence of discrete, subepithelial electron-dense immune deposits, often referred to as 'humps'.

================================================================================
Question 265 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A patient presents with hematuria, proteinuria on urinalysis, edema and recurrent episodes of gross hematuria. C3 levels are low and examination of the basement membrane reveals thickening of the glomerular loop or tram-tracking. He is diagnosed with the type 1 of MPGN. Electron dense deposition is most commonly seen in:

Options:
  Mesangium
  Glomerular basement membrane
✓ Sub-endothelial area
  Sub-epithelial side of basement membrane
  loop of Henle

Explanation:
In Type I Membranoproliferative Glomerulonephritis (MPGN), electron-dense immune complex depositions are most commonly found in the sub-endothelial space, which contributes to the characteristic 'tram-track' appearance on light microscopy due to mesangial interposition and GBM splitting.

================================================================================
Question 266 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
In a patient with a Tubulointerstitial nephritis, which of the following is true?

Options:
  The patient always has symptoms.
  Renal tubular acidosis may not be present.
  In chronic disease a rash is always present.
  Interstitial nephritis never impairs renal function.
✓ In acute disease there may also be a high blood eosinophil count (eosinophilia) and eosinophils in the urine (eosinophiluria)

Explanation:
In acute tubulointerstitial nephritis (ATIN), particularly drug-induced forms, a systemic hypersensitivity reaction is common. This can manifest as a peripheral eosinophilia (high blood eosinophil count) and the presence of eosinophils in the urine (eosinophiluria).

================================================================================
Question 267 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Which of the following statements is more relevant to renal tract stone formation?

Options:
  A low urine oxalate level.
✓ Repeated urinary tract infection and stasis.
  A low urine calcium level.
  A low urine Urate levels.
  High protein diet.

Explanation:
Repeated urinary tract infections (especially with urease-producing bacteria) and urinary stasis (impaired urine flow) are significant risk factors for the formation of certain types of renal stones, particularly struvite stones, by creating conditions favorable for crystal precipitation.

================================================================================
Question 268 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Which of the following is not typically a site of normal ureteral narrowing, where stones get caught?

Options:
  Iliac vessels
  Pelvic ureteric junction(PUJ)
✓ L4 level
  Vesico-ureteric junction (VUJ)
  Pelvic ureter

Explanation:
The three physiological narrowings of the ureter where kidney stones commonly become lodged are the ureteropelvic junction (PUJ), where the ureter crosses the iliac vessels, and the ureterovesical junction (VUJ). The L4 vertebral level is not typically a site of normal ureteral narrowing.

================================================================================
Question 269 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Which of the following most unlikely in Nephrotic syndrome?

Options:
  3g proteinuria per day.
  Associated with hyperlipidemia
  May be caused by drugs such as gold and ACEI
  Membranous glomerulonephritis is the most common cause of primary Nephrotic syndrome in adults.
✓ Hypertension is characteristic.

Explanation:
While hypertension can develop in some cases of nephrotic syndrome, particularly with co-existing conditions or progression to renal failure, it is not considered a *characteristic* feature of uncomplicated nephrotic syndrome. The hallmarks are massive proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, edema, and often hyperlipidemia.

================================================================================
Question 270 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
In 80% of cases, the primary hyperaldosteronism is caused by an aldosterone secreting adenoma. What is the name of this syndrome?

Options:
  Cushing syndrome
✓ Conn's syndrome
  Adrenogenital syndrome
  Addison disease
  Down syndrome

Explanation:
Primary hyperaldosteronism caused by an aldosterone-secreting adrenal adenoma is known as Conn's syndrome.

================================================================================
Question 271 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
The morphologic changes seen in primary hyperparathyroidism Include those in the parathyroid glands and in other organs affected by elevated levels of which of the following?

Options:
  Sodium
  Potassium
  Zinc
✓ Calcium
  Lead

Explanation:
Primary hyperparathyroidism is characterized by excessive secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH), leading to elevated levels of calcium (hypercalcemia) in the blood. The morphologic changes in other organs are due to this elevated calcium.

================================================================================
Question 272 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 31-year-old woman, who has two healthy children, notes that she has had no menstrual periods for the past 6 months, but she is not pregnant and takes no medications. Within the past week, she has noted some milk production from her breasts. She has been bothered by headaches for the past 3 months. An optometrist finds her lateral vision to be reduced. On physical examination she is afebrile and normotensive. Which of the following laboratory test findings is most likely to be present in this woman?

Options:
  Increased serum cortisol
  Lack of growth hormone suppression
  Increased serum alkaline phosphatase
✓ Hyperprolactinemia
  Decreased serum TSH

Explanation:
The combination of amenorrhea, galactorrhea (milk production), headaches, and visual field defects (reduced lateral vision, suggestive of bitemporal hemianopsia) is highly indicative of a prolactinoma (a pituitary tumor secreting prolactin). This would result in hyperprolactinemia.

================================================================================
Question 273 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 2-year-old child has failure to thrive since infancy. Physical examination shows that the child is short and has coarse facial features, a protruding tongue, and an umbilical hernia. As the child matures, profound intellectual disability becomes apparent. A deficiency of which of the following hormones is most likely to explain these findings?

Options:
  Cortisol
  Insulin
  Norepinephrine
  Somatostatin
✓ Thyroxin (T4)

Explanation:
The clinical features of failure to thrive, short stature, coarse facial features, a protruding tongue, an umbilical hernia, and profound intellectual disability are characteristic of congenital hypothyroidism (cretinism), which is caused by a deficiency of thyroxine (T4).

================================================================================
Question 274 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 50-year-old man with fasting blood glucose >140 mg/dL on two occasions is put on a restricted caloric diet and started on an oral hypoglycemic agent. Which of the following laboratory studies is most likely to afford the best method of monitoring disease control in this man?

Options:
  Cholesterol, total
  Fasting plasma glucose
✓ Glycosylated hemoglobin
  Microalbuminuria
  Random plasma glucose

Explanation:
Glycosylated hemoglobin (HbA1c) provides an average measure of blood glucose control over the preceding 2-3 months. It is the best method for long-term monitoring of disease control in diabetic patients.

================================================================================
Question 275 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 42-year-old woman presents with amenorrhea and emotional disturbances. You note upper truncal obesity and suspect Cushing syndrome. Laboratory studies reveal elevated serum levels of corticosteroids that can be lowered by administration of dexamethasone. Which of the following is the most likely cause of hypercortisolism in this patient?

Options:
  Adrenal cortical adenoma
  Adrenal cortical carcinoma
  Adrenal cortical hyperplasia
  Pheochromocytoma
✓ Pituitary adenoma (Corticotroph cells producing adenoma)

Explanation:
Cushing's syndrome characterized by elevated corticosteroids that are suppressible by dexamethasone is indicative of ACTH-dependent Cushing's syndrome. The most common cause of this is Cushing's disease, which is due to a pituitary adenoma secreting ACTH (corticotroph cell adenoma).

================================================================================
Question 276 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Which one is the most significant factor that leads to the metabolic derangements seen in type II diabetes mellitus?

Options:
  Lack of B cells in islets of Langerhans
  Chronic renal failure
✓ Peripheral insulin resistance
  Overproduction of amylin protein
  Development of autoantibodies to insulin

Explanation:
Peripheral insulin resistance is the hallmark and most significant underlying factor leading to the metabolic derangements observed in Type 2 diabetes mellitus. It results in reduced glucose uptake by tissues despite adequate insulin levels, leading to compensatory hyperinsulinemia and eventually beta-cell exhaustion.

================================================================================
Question 277 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 28-year-old woman has had difficulty concentrating at work for the past month. She is constantly getting up and walking around to visit co-workers. She complains that the work area is too hot. She seems nervous and often spills her tea. She has been eating more but has lost 5 kg in the past 2 months. On physical examination her temperature is 37.5 C, pulse 101/minute, respiratory rate 22/minute, and blood pressure 145/85 mm Hg. Which of the following laboratory findings is most likely to be present in this woman?

Options:
  Decreased catechol amines
  Decreased iodine uptake
  Decreased plasma Insulin
✓ Decreased TSH
  Increased ACTH

Explanation:
The patient's symptoms (difficulty concentrating, restlessness, heat intolerance, nervousness, weight loss despite increased appetite, tachycardia, hypertension) are classic for hyperthyroidism. In primary hyperthyroidism, the thyroid gland overproduces hormones, which then suppresses the release of TSH (Thyroid Stimulating Hormone) from the pituitary, leading to a decreased TSH level.

================================================================================
Question 278 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 29-year-old primigravida who received no prenatal care has marked vaginal bleeding after the onset of labor at 38 weeks gestation. Cesarean section is performed and a lacerated low-lying placenta is removed. She remains hypotensive for 6 hours and requires transfusion of 12 packed RBC units. Postpartum, she becomes unable to breastfeed the infant. She does not have a resumption of normal menstrual cycles. She becomes more sluggish and tired. Which of the following pathologic lesions is she most likely to have had following delivery?

Options:
  Bilateral adrenal hemorrhage
✓ Pituitary necrosis
  Subacute thyroiditis
  Metastatic choriocarcinoma
  Insulitis

Explanation:
The history of severe postpartum hemorrhage leading to prolonged hypotension, followed by inability to lactate (due to prolactin deficiency), amenorrhea (due to gonadotropin deficiency), and symptoms of sluggishness and fatigue (due to TSH and/or ACTH deficiency), is classic for Sheehan's syndrome (postpartum pituitary necrosis).

================================================================================
Question 279 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 49-year-old woman has had increasing cold Intolerance, weight gain of 4 kg, and sluggishness over the past two years. A physical examination reveals dry, coarse skin and alopecia of the scalp. Her thyroid is not palpably enlarged. Her serum TSH is raised with a low thyroxin level. A year ago, antithyroglobulin and anti-thyroid peroxidase autoantibodies were detected at high titer. Which of the following thyroid diseases is she most likely to have?

Options:
  DeQuervain disease
  Papillary carcinoma
✓ Hashimoto thyroiditis
  

Explanation:
The clinical symptoms of cold intolerance, weight gain, sluggishness, dry/coarse skin, alopecia, along with laboratory findings of raised TSH and low thyroxine (hypothyroidism), and the presence of high titers of antithyroglobulin and anti-thyroid peroxidase autoantibodies, are all characteristic features of Hashimoto's thyroiditis (chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis), the most common autoimmune cause of hypothyroidism.

================================================================================
Question 280 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 50-year-old man has episodic headaches for 3 months. On physical examination his blood pressure is 185/110 mm Hg, with no other remarkable findings. Laboratory studies show a normal sodium, potassium, and chloride levels, glucose 91 mg/dl. An abdominal CT scan shows a 7 cm left adrenal mass. During surgery, as the left adrenal gland is removed, there is a marked rise in blood pressure. Which of the following laboratory test findings most likely explains his findings?

Options:
  Decreased serum cortisol
  Decreased urinary homovanillic acid
  Increased serum ACTH
✓ Increased urinary free catechol amines
  Increased insulin levels

Explanation:
The episodic headaches, hypertension, adrenal mass, and the marked rise in blood pressure during adrenal gland manipulation are classic signs of a pheochromocytoma (a tumor of the adrenal medulla). This tumor secretes excessive catecholamines, which would be reflected by increased urinary free catecholamines and their metabolites (e.g., metanephrines).

================================================================================
Question 281 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 33-year-old previously healthy man has lateral visual field deficits, but his residual vision is 20/20. His facial features have changed over the past year. His shoe size has increased. A head CT scan reveals enlargement of the sella turcica. Which of the following hormones is most likely being secreted in excessive amounts in this man?

Options:
  Antidiuretic hormone
  Prolactin
  ACTH
✓ Growth hormone
  Luteinizing hormone

Explanation:
The symptoms of lateral visual field deficits (suggesting optic chiasm compression), changes in facial features, increased shoe size (acral growth), and enlargement of the sella turcica are classic signs of acromegaly, which is caused by excessive secretion of growth hormone (GH) from a pituitary adenoma.

================================================================================
Question 282 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
This is not an endocrine gland:

Options:
  Adrenal
  Pituitary
✓ Lacrimal
  Thyroid
  Pancreas

Explanation:
The lacrimal glands produce tears and are exocrine glands, not endocrine glands. Adrenal, pituitary, thyroid, and pancreas are all major endocrine glands.

================================================================================
Question 283 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
20yr old female presents with five years history of weight gain, Irregular periods and worsening facial hair what is most likely diagnosis.

Options:
  Hypothyroidism
  Hypopituitarism
  Cushing syndrome
  Diabetes mellitus
✓ Polycystic ovarian disease

Explanation:
The clinical picture of weight gain, irregular periods (oligomenorrhea/amenorrhea), and worsening facial hair (hirsutism) in a young woman are classic diagnostic features of Polycystic Ovarian Disease (PCOD) or Syndrome (PCOS).

================================================================================
Question 284 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
What is the investigation of the first choice for a 20-year-old girl who presented with a history of weight loss, sweating, palpitation, and diarrhea?

Options:
  Anti-tissue transglutaminase level
  Sputum acid fast bacilli
✓ Thyroid function test
  Liver function tests
  Duodenal biopsy

Explanation:
The symptoms of weight loss, sweating, palpitations, and diarrhea are highly suggestive of hyperthyroidism. A thyroid function test (TFTs) is the investigation of first choice to confirm or rule out this diagnosis.

================================================================================
Question 285 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
What is the most likely diagnosis for a young girl with cold intolerance, weight gain, menorrhagia and polymenorrhagia?

Options:
  Sheehan syndrome
  Addison disease
  Thyrotoxicosis
✓ Hypothyroidism
  PCOs

Explanation:
Cold intolerance, weight gain, menorrhagia (heavy menstrual bleeding), and polymenorrhagia (frequent menstrual bleeding) are all classic symptoms associated with hypothyroidism, reflecting slowed metabolism and menstrual irregularities.

================================================================================
Question 286 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 40 yr old male start complaining of increase in shoe size, change in complexion and widening of upper teeth. what is cause of it?

Options:
  Hypothyroidism
✓ Acromegaly
  Hyperthyroidism
  Syndrome (incomplete option)

Explanation:
Increased shoe size, changes in facial features (complexion, widening of upper teeth, prognathism), and other acral growth are classic signs of acromegaly, caused by excessive growth hormone secretion in adulthood.

================================================================================
Question 287 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
35 years old female with feeling of swelling in body severe constipation and hoarseness of voice for last 4 month she look pale with puffy face. best investigation is:

Options:
✓ TSH
  T3T4.
  SERUM PROLACTIN.
  FSH LH.
  Renal functional test

Explanation:
The symptoms of body swelling, severe constipation, hoarseness of voice, pale and puffy face are highly suggestive of hypothyroidism (myxedema). Thyroid Stimulating Hormone (TSH) is the most sensitive first-line test for diagnosing primary hypothyroidism.

================================================================================
Question 288 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Effects of hypothyroidism include all BUT this:

Options:
✓ Diarrhea
  Lethargy
  Anorexia
  Weight gain
  Vomiting

Explanation:
Hypothyroidism typically causes constipation due to slowed gastrointestinal motility, not diarrhea. Lethargy, anorexia, weight gain, and sometimes vomiting (in severe cases) can be associated with hypothyroidism.

================================================================================
Question 289 (KGMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 30 year old lady with primary infertility presented with hirsuitism. She gives history of irregular periods. Biochemical investigation are normal except blood sugar which is 180 mg%. Diagnosis?

Options:
  Type 1 diabetes
✓ Polycystic ovaries Syndrome
  Type 2 diabetes
  Pituitary tumour
  Hypothyroidism

Explanation:
