The patient's clinical presentation (acromegalic features, hypertension), biochemical profile (high GH/IGF-1, non-suppressible GH), and pituitary adenoma on MRI strongly indicate active acromegaly. Transsphenoidal surgery is considered the first-line and most effective treatment for removing pituitary adenomas causing acromegaly, aiming for biochemical cure and symptom improvement.

================================================================================
Question 513 (KMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 32-year-old woman attends her GP with weight loss and tremors. On questioning, she also reports loose stools and increasing anxiety. She has a past medical history of type 1 diabetes. You suspected Grave's disease in the patient. Which antibody test you will order to support your diagnosis?

Options:
  Anti 21-hydroxylase anti body
  Anti parietal cell antibody
  Antigliadin Antibodies
  Thyroid peroxidase Antibodies
✓ Thyroid stimulating hormone receptor antibody

Explanation:
The symptoms (weight loss, tremors, loose stools, anxiety) and suspicion of Graves' disease are highly indicative of hyperthyroidism. Thyroid stimulating hormone receptor antibodies (TSHR-Ab or TRAb) are specific to Graves' disease and stimulate the TSH receptor, leading to excessive thyroid hormone production. This is the most appropriate antibody test for confirming Graves' disease.

================================================================================
Question 514 (KMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 50-year-old man came to medical OPD with symptoms of recurrent episodes of watery diarrhea, associated with crampy abdominal pain and hot flushes... On examination, pulse was 80/minute, BP 140/80 (lying), and 120/70 (standing) Chest: bilateral wheezes CVS: pan systolic murmur along the left sternal border What is the diagnosis?

Options:
✓ Carcinoid Syndrome
  Coeliac disease
  Giardiasis
  IBS
  Congestive heart failure

Explanation:
The constellation of symptoms including recurrent watery diarrhea, abdominal pain, hot flushes, bilateral wheezes (bronchospasm), and a pansystolic murmur (suggesting carcinoid heart disease) is highly characteristic of carcinoid syndrome, which results from the release of vasoactive substances (e.g., serotonin) from neuroendocrine tumors.

================================================================================
Question 515 (KMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
The child has excessive frequency of passing urine and has to seek permission from the teacher in the class to leave the lessons and go to the wash room. There is history that 'ants' are attracted to the urine. Currently he has lost weight despite good oral intake, urine is not smelly, temp is 101 F. Urine dipstick shows no protein. Blood glucose is 220mg/dl the various possible diagnoses are:

Options:
  Urinary tract infection
  Psychogenic polydipsia
✓ Diabetes mellitus
  Malaria
  Diabetes insipidus

Explanation:
Excessive frequency of urination (polyuria), weight loss despite good oral intake, and the attraction of ants to urine (indicating glycosuria) with a high blood glucose level (220 mg/dL) are classic signs and symptoms of diabetes mellitus.

================================================================================
Question 516 (KMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 40 year old female presents to the OPD with history of worsening headache, weight gain and generalized weakness. She also turned out to be hypertensive and raised blood sugar levels on a couple of occasions. An Overnight dexamethasone suppression test was done which showed no cortisol suppression. What is the most commonest cause of above mentioned symptoms and test?

Options:
  Conn's syndrome
✓ Cushing's Disease
  Phaeochromocytoma
  Small cell lung cancer
  Thyroid carcinoma

Explanation:
The symptoms (headache, weight gain, weakness, hypertension, hyperglycemia) and the result of the overnight dexamethasone suppression test (no cortisol suppression) strongly suggest Cushing's syndrome. The most common endogenous cause of Cushing's syndrome is Cushing's Disease, which is due to an ACTH-producing pituitary adenoma.

================================================================================
Question 517 (KMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Most Common form of Nephrotic Syndrome is:

Options:
  Minimal Change Disease
  Focal Segmental glomerulo-sclerosis
  Membrano proliferative glomerulonephritis
✓ Membranous Nephropathy
  C3 glomerulopathy

Explanation:
In adults, membranous nephropathy (also known as membranous glomerulonephritis) is the most common primary cause of nephrotic syndrome. In children, it is minimal change disease.

================================================================================
Question 518 (KMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 50 Years old man is working in a hospital. He is exposed to some occupational hazard. Which of the following hazard is controlled on the basis of ALARA (As low as reasonably achievable) principle?

Options:
  Dust suppression
✓ Ionizing Radiations
  Radio frequency radiation
  Sound Waves
  Ultraviolent Radiation

Explanation:
The ALARA (As Low As Reasonably Achievable) principle is a fundamental radiation safety principle applied to minimize exposure to ionizing radiation.

================================================================================
Question 519 (KMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Hormones are present in the body in very low quantity, Which methodology is more specific and sensitive for hormone estimation?

Options:
✓ Chemiluminescence
  Chromatography
  Colorimetry
  Electrophoresis
  Spectrophotometry

Explanation:
Chemiluminescence immunoassays (CLIA) are widely used for hormone estimation due to their high sensitivity and specificity, allowing for accurate measurement of hormones present in very low concentrations.

================================================================================
Question 520 (KMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
During 4th year MBBS class a student falls in class rank from first place to last place. She has also noted a lower pitch to her voice and coarsening of her hair along with increased tendency towards weight gain, menorrhagia and increased intolerance to cold. What relevant Investigations will you perform in this case?

Options:
  ACTH
  GH
  GTT
  LH & FSH
✓ TFTs

Explanation:
The symptoms described (decline in academic performance, lower voice pitch, coarsening hair, weight gain, menorrhagia, cold intolerance) are classic for hypothyroidism. Thyroid Function Tests (TFTs), including TSH and thyroid hormones, are the primary investigations to diagnose this condition.

================================================================================
Question 521 (KMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Thyroid function tests (TFTs) Include T3,T4 and TSH. Name 1st line single test for thyroid function evaluation?

Options:
  Free T4
  Free T3
  TBG
  TRH
✓ TSH

Explanation:
Thyroid Stimulating Hormone (TSH) is recognized as the most sensitive and specific first-line screening test for thyroid dysfunction. Its level changes inversely and logarithmically with free thyroid hormone levels.

================================================================================
Question 522 (KMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Fasting Plasma Glucose (FPG) of a 48 year old senior male officer during his "Annual Check-up" was found to be 142 mg/dl. He was advised re-testing for DM by Glycosylated Heamoglobin (A1C). The result of A1C was found to be 6.8% (HPLC) Now he wants your opinion. Keeping in view the latest recommendations by International bodies (and ignoring the social aspects for the time being, at least) which of the following you think is the best option for this patient:

Options:
✓ DM is confirmed
  Requires repeating of FPG
  Requires repeating of A1C
  Requires OGTT
  Requires Urinalysis

Explanation:
According to diagnostic criteria for diabetes, an FPG ≥ 126 mg/dL or an HbA1c ≥ 6.5% confirms the diagnosis. This patient has both an FPG of 142 mg/dL (above 126) and an HbA1c of 6.8% (above 6.5%), meeting the criteria for diabetes on two separate tests.

================================================================================
Question 523 (KMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 26 years old woman has episodic hypertension with headache, diaphoresis, and palpitations. MRI scan showed Adrenal tumors arising from medulla What urinary lab investigation can confirm the diagnosis?

Options:
  Urinary protein creatinin ratio
  24 hours urinary ketosteroids
  24 hour urinary proteins
  Urinary Albumin
✓ Vinyl Mandilic acid (VMA)

Explanation:
The symptoms (episodic hypertension, headache, diaphoresis, palpitations) and adrenal medullary tumor are classic for pheochromocytoma. This tumor secretes catecholamines, and its diagnosis is confirmed by measuring urinary metanephrines and normetanephrines, or their breakdown product, vanillylmandelic acid (VMA), in a 24-hour urine collection.

================================================================================
Question 524 (KMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 30 years old woman presents with amenorrhea, galactorrhea, and visual field defects all of several months duration, MRI reveals a hypophyseal mass impinging on optic chiasm. Which hormone would be found in high concentration in serum?

Options:
  ACTH
  GH
  LH and FSH
✓ Prolactin
  TSH

Explanation:
The combination of amenorrhea, galactorrhea, and visual field defects (due to optic chiasm compression by a hypophyseal mass) is classic for a prolactinoma, a pituitary tumor that secretes excessive prolactin. Therefore, prolactin would be found in high concentration in the serum.

================================================================================
Question 525 (KMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Which of the following tests can be used to assess kidney functions at tubular level?

Options:
  Calculation of GFR
  Creatinine clearance
  Cystatin C
✓ Fractional excretion of Na
  Serum Urea

Explanation:
Fractional excretion of sodium (FENa) is a useful test for assessing kidney function at the tubular level. It helps differentiate between prerenal azotemia (low FENa, indicating intact tubular function to reabsorb sodium) and acute tubular necrosis (high FENa, indicating tubular damage and impaired sodium reabsorption).

================================================================================
Question 526 (KMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 54 years old woman is concerned about swelling in left Breast on examination there is 4x5cm lump in upper inner quadrant of left breast there is also a single mobile lymph node palpable in left axilla the contralateral side and axilla are normal what is the next appropriate management option?

Options:
  Fine needle aspiration cytology
✓ Triple assessment
  Reassurance and close follow up
  MRI of breast
  Ultrasound of breast

Explanation:
Any new breast lump, especially with associated lymphadenopathy, requires a 'triple assessment' which includes clinical examination, imaging (mammography and/or ultrasound), and tissue sampling (fine needle aspiration cytology or core biopsy). This comprehensive approach provides the most accurate diagnosis.

================================================================================
Question 527 (KMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 62-year-old male presents to the OPD complaining that, he has noted slight urgency, frequency, nocturia, a decrease in the force of micturition. He is referred to have blood tests to include which of the following?

Options:
  Carcinoembryonic antigen
✓ Prostate specific antigen
  Carbohydrate antigen 19
  Lactate Dehydrogenase
  Alkaline phosphatase

Explanation:
The patient's symptoms (urgency, frequency, nocturia, decreased force of micturition) are classic lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) often associated with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) or prostate cancer in older men. Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) is a blood test commonly used to screen for and monitor prostate conditions, including cancer.

================================================================================
Question 528 (KMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 60 years old man is distressed by severe backache due to metastatic carcinoma of the prostate. Which of the following is the appropriate treatment?

Options:
  Radiotherapy
✓ Subcapsular Orchidectomy
  Radical Prostatectomy
  Palliative Chemotherapy
  Brachytherapy

Explanation:
Prostate cancer is often androgen-dependent. For metastatic prostate carcinoma, androgen deprivation therapy is a cornerstone of treatment. Subcapsular orchidectomy (surgical removal of the testes) is a very effective and rapid method of achieving surgical castration, thereby reducing testosterone levels and slowing disease progression, particularly for bone metastases causing pain.

================================================================================
Question 529 (KMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A surgical resident is asked by the consultant to perform a staging workup for a lady with invasive ductal carcinoma having a 5x5 cm lump in left breast with peau d'orange skin, which of the following is the correct step?

Options:
  CT scan Chest, Abdomen and Pelvis
✓ CT scan chest, abdomen, and pelvis and bone scan
  MRI of breast
  MRI of chest
  Positron Emission Tomography CT scan

Explanation:
The presence of a large invasive ductal carcinoma with 'peau d'orange' (suggesting inflammatory breast cancer or advanced local disease) indicates a high likelihood of metastatic spread. A comprehensive staging workup requires imaging to detect distant metastases, typically including a CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis, along with a bone scan to assess for bone metastases.

================================================================================
Question 530 (KMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 42 years old female presents to the OPD with pain in the right upper quadrant. Ultrasound examination reveals a 5x5 cm mass in the lower pole of right kidney What is the next appropriate investigation?

Options:
  Intravenous Urogram
  X-ray KUB
✓ CT scan abdomen
  Diagnostic Laparoscopy
  MRI abdomen

Explanation:
For a newly discovered solid renal mass, particularly one of this size (5x5 cm), a CT scan of the abdomen (with and without contrast) is the most appropriate next investigation. It provides detailed anatomical information, helps characterize the mass (e.g., solid vs. cystic, benign vs. malignant features), and assesses for local invasion or lymphadenopathy.

================================================================================
Question 531 (KMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 24 years old woman presented to the OPD with painless lump in her right breast. On examination, there is a 2x2 cm firm mobile swelling in upper outer quadrant of right breast. What is the next step in management?

Options:
  Fine needle aspiration cytology
✓ Mammography
  Reassurance and follow up
  Core Cut biopsy
  Excision of the lump

Explanation:
For a 24-year-old woman with a painless, firm, mobile breast lump, the next step is typically imaging. While ultrasound is often preferred for younger women, mammography is also a standard part of the 'triple assessment' in many guidelines, especially as the lump is firm. This would be followed by biopsy if suspicious. Given the options, mammography is a key diagnostic imaging step, often combined with ultrasound.

================================================================================
Question 532 (KMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
All children with type 1 diabetes mellitus require insulin therapy most require 2 or more injections of insulin daily with doses adjusted on the basis of self monitoring of blood glucose levels the preferable insulin regimen is:

Options:
  Conventional Insulin therapy: Twice daily mixed Insulin
  Mixed Insulin breakfast + evening meal and mid day short acting insulin.
  Intermediate acting breakfast + evening meal and three times short
  Short acting breakfast+ lunch and mixture of short acting and intermediate acting at evening meal
✓ Rapid acting before breakfast+ lunch + evening meal+ long acting before bedtime

Explanation:
The most preferable insulin regimen for Type 1 diabetes is often a basal-bolus regimen, mimicking physiological insulin secretion. This involves rapid-acting insulin before each meal (breakfast, lunch, evening meal) to cover carbohydrate intake, combined with a long-acting insulin before bedtime (or once daily) to provide basal insulin coverage.

================================================================================
Question 533 (KMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 54-year-old woman presents systemically unwell with high grade fever and sore throat. She has recently started carbimazole for hyperthyroidism, What is the most important blood test to perform?

Options:
  Cortisol
✓ Full blood count
  Liver function tests
  Prothrombin time
  Urea and electrolytes

Explanation:
Carbimazole, an antithyroid drug, has a rare but serious side effect of agranulocytosis (a severe drop in white blood cell count). A high-grade fever and sore throat in a patient on carbimazole are red flags for this condition, necessitating an urgent full blood count (CBC) to check for neutropenia.

================================================================================
Question 534 (KMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 20-year-old athletic man with no significant past medical history is found to have isolated asymptomatic microscopic haematuria on routine physical exam. He is not on any medications and does not use illicit drugs. Which one of the following observations suggests haematuria of glomerular origin?

Options:
  Abscense of RBC and WBC casts.
  Decoy cells in urine sediment
✓ Dysmorphic RBCs of acanthocytes in urine sediment
  Isomorphic red blood cells (RBCs) in urine sediment
  Isomorphic RBCs and white blood cells (WBCs) in urine sediment

Explanation:
Hematuria of glomerular origin (e.g., from glomerulonephritis) is characterized by dysmorphic red blood cells (RBCs), particularly acanthocytes, and often RBC casts in the urine sediment. These indicate that the RBCs have been distorted as they passed through damaged glomeruli.

================================================================================
Question 535 (KMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 15 years old school going student presented to emergency deptt with chief complaints of vomiting abdominal pain and increased urinary frequency for the last three days. On examination his blood pressure is 100/80mg Hg, pulse rate is 102 beats per minute and regular. His skin is dry and flushed. These investigations are available at the moment. Random blood sugar 350 mg/dl; Blood PH 7.25; serum creatinine 1.1 mg/dl; Serum ketones positives. What is the best First line treatment for this patient?

Options:
  IV bicarbonate
✓ IV 0.9% Normal Saline
  IV antibiotics
  IV 0.45% Dextrose Saline
  S/C Heparin

Explanation:
The patient's symptoms (vomiting, abdominal pain, increased urinary frequency, dry/flushed skin, tachycardia), and lab results (random blood sugar 350 mg/dl, pH 7.25, positive serum ketones) are classic for diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). The best first-line treatment for DKA is aggressive intravenous (IV) 0.9% normal saline to correct severe dehydration and restore intravascular volume.

================================================================================
Question 536 (KMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 30-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with nausea, vomiting, severe flank pain, and hematuria Which one of the following diagnostic images is APPROPRIATE in this subject?

Options:
  A plain film of the abdomen (KUB)
  An ultrasound of the kidneys
  An intravenous urogram
✓ An unenhanced helical (spiral) CT of abdomen
  An MRI

Explanation:
The symptoms (nausea, vomiting, severe flank pain, hematuria) are classic for renal colic, usually caused by kidney stones. An unenhanced helical (spiral) CT of the abdomen and pelvis is the most appropriate and sensitive diagnostic imaging modality for detecting urinary tract calculi.

================================================================================
Question 537 (KMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 24 year old thin, lean female presented to the opd with dizziness and depressive symptoms. She was also complaining of abdominal pain with episodes of vomiting. On examination she had dark brown complexion and her BP was 90/60, Keeping the history in mind what is the most specific investigation you would like to do?

Options:
  Blood glucose level
  Serum Calcium
  Thyroid function tests
  Serum ferritin
✓ Synacthen test

Explanation:
The patient's symptoms (dizziness, depressive symptoms, abdominal pain, vomiting, low BP, and especially a dark brown complexion (hyperpigmentation)) are highly suggestive of primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison's disease). The most specific diagnostic investigation for this condition is the Synacthen test (ACTH stimulation test), which assesses the adrenal glands' ability to produce cortisol.

================================================================================
Question 538 (KMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A young male presented to ER with history of repeated sexual assaults upon local examination thickened and shiny silver hyper keratinized skin was founds around perianal region. Anus was deeply situated A foreign residue assumed to be having same consistency as of lubricant was found, Upon DRE anal canal was dilated with lax anal sphincter. Which of the following option best applies to the above findings?

Options:
  Bestiality
  Habitual active agent of sodomy
✓ Habitual passive agent of sodomy
  Lesbian
  Voyeurism

Explanation:
The physical findings described (thickened, hyperkeratinized perianal skin, deeply situated anus, dilated/lax anal sphincter, foreign residue/lubricant) are classic for a habitual passive agent of sodomy, indicative of chronic receptive anal intercourse.

================================================================================
Question 539 (KMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A young lady had been pregnant under surrogacy contract for 9months and then delivered a healthy baby. After delivery she refused baby to handover to actual parents against the contract. What is the most suitable option among the following given below?

Options:
  Breach of child
  Cancellation of contract
✓ Commercial transaction
  Disagreement
  Revoking of contract

Explanation:
In many legal systems, particularly in Pakistan, commercial surrogacy is prohibited, and any contract related to it may be considered illegal or unenforceable. The refusal to hand over the baby highlights the ethical and legal complexities of such a commercial transaction, especially when it involves payment for a child.

================================================================================
Question 540 (KMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Police has brought a middle-aged woman in an alleged case of concealment of birth. On examination she has enlarged breasts exuding colostrum, Montgomery's tubercles present. Uterus is relaxed flabby and at umbilical level Lochia rubra is present in the vaginal canal. According to examination findings how many days have been passed since she has delivered the baby?

Options:
  1 day
✓ 2-3 days
  4-5 days
  6 days
  1 week

Explanation:
The presence of lochia rubra typically lasts for the first 3-4 days postpartum. A relaxed, flabby uterus at the umbilical level indicates recent delivery, usually within the first few days. Colostrum and Montgomery's tubercles are consistent with the puerperal state. Thus, 2-3 days is the most consistent timeframe.

================================================================================
Question 541 (KMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Police has caught a renal transplant surgeon red handed for doing illegal renal transplants in a private setup. He now has been charged with violation of human tissue and organ transplant act. According to human organ transplant act of Pakistan what penalty he could face?

Options:
  Imprisonment for up to 1 year and permanent removal of name from PMDC
  Imprisonment for up to 2 years only
  Imprisonment for up to 5 years and removal of name for 2 years Initially
✓ Imprisonment for up to 10 years and removal of name for 3 years initially
  Removal of name from PMDC permanently

Explanation:
Under the Human Organ Transplant Ordinance 2007 of Pakistan, engaging in illegal organ transplantation for commercial purposes is a serious offense. Penalties for such violations include imprisonment for up to 10 years and initial removal of the medical practitioner's name from the PMDC register for 3 years, with potential for permanent removal upon subsequent offenses.

================================================================================
Question 542 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
An adult male of 1.75 square meter surface area attained 1680 kcal of energy yesterday of which 50% was from fats. How much grams of fats was utilized for this purpose?

Options:
  130 gm
✓ 93 gm
  86 gm
  80 gm
  47 gm

Explanation:
50% of 1680 kcal = 840 kcal. Fat provides 9 kcal/gram. Therefore, the amount of fat utilized is 840 kcal / 9 kcal/gm = 93.33 gm. The closest option is 93 gm.

================================================================================
Question 543 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 50-year-old patient with severe inflammation and pain due to an autoimmune disorder was prescribed Dexamethasone. Which of the following glucocorticoids is highly potent?

Options:
  Hydrocortisone
✓ Dexamethasone
  Methylprednisolone
  Glucocorticoids
  Triamcinolone

Explanation:
Dexamethasone is a long-acting glucocorticoid that is significantly more potent (about 25-30 times) than hydrocortisone, making it one of the most potent options available.

================================================================================
Question 544 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 50-year-old male patient was admitted in cardiology ward with symptoms of blood in urine, flank pain, lethargy and weight loss. Renal cell carcinoma was diagnosed on MRI. The cytogenetics studies was performed on a renal tumor which demonstrated the presence of terminal deletion of the short arm of chromosome 3. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Options:
  Collecting duct carcinoma
  Oncocytoma
  Renal cell carcinoma chromophobe type
✓ Renal cell carcinoma clear cell type
  Renal cell carcinoma papillary type

Explanation:
Clear cell renal cell carcinoma (ccRCC) is strongly associated with the deletion of the short arm of chromosome 3 (3p), which involves the VHL gene. This is the most common cytogenetic abnormality in ccRCC.

================================================================================
Question 545 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 65-year-old woman attends a clinic with a large prolapse she underwent abdominal hysterectomy at the age of 42 for heavy periods, and required a second operation for a large left-sided ovarian cyst which was complicated by dense abdominal adhesions. She has no other significant history. On examination she had a vaginal vault prolapse that extended beyond the introitus and also had a vaginal wall tear. She is married and wishes to resume her marital relationship with her husband. What is the best option for treatment for this patient? Choose the single best answer.

Options:
  Abdominal sacrocolpopexy
  Antero-posterior repair
  Colpocleisis
  Insertion of a vaginal pessary
✓ Vaginal repair with sacrospinous fixation

Explanation:
Given the patient's history of dense abdominal adhesions from previous surgeries, an abdominal approach (sacrocolpopexy) carries higher risk. She wishes to maintain sexual function, so colpocleisis (closing the vagina) is contraindicated. A vaginal repair with sacrospinous fixation effectively addresses the vault prolapse while preserving vaginal depth and avoiding the risks of re-entering the abdomen.

================================================================================
Question 546 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 12 years old boy was brought to paediatrician with history of fever, sorethroat and joint pains. He was prescribed medicine and sent home. The boy was completely fine, but after two weeks he suddenly developed fever, hematuria and pain in body. Lab investigations revealed raised serum creatinine. Which of the following cells can be seen in the blood film and urine R/E in this case?

Options:
  Basophils
✓ Eosinophils
  Lymphocytes
  Neutrophils
  Pus cells

Explanation:
The clinical picture of fever, hematuria, and acute kidney injury (raised creatinine) developing a few weeks after taking medication for a sore throat suggests Acute Interstitial Nephritis (AIN), likely drug-induced. A classic finding in drug-induced AIN is eosinophilia in the blood and eosinophiluria (eosinophils in the urine).

================================================================================
Question 547 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 17 years old thin lean girl has not started menarche. On complete workup no cause found. What is the condition known as?

Options:
  Menopause
  Hysterectomy
✓ Constitutional delay
  Premature ovarian failure
  Hermaphrodite

Explanation:
Primary amenorrhea (failure to start menarche by age 15 or 16 with normal secondary sexual characteristics, or by 13 without them) in a thin, lean girl with no identifiable pathological cause after workup is often attributed to constitutional delay of growth and puberty. Being thin/lean can also contribute (functional hypothalamic amenorrhea), but 'Constitutional delay' is the diagnosis for unexplained late menarche in this context.

================================================================================
Question 548 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 70-year-old male patient with a history of BPH is prescribed medication to manage his symptoms. Which class of medications is commonly used to treat BPH by relaxing the smooth muscle of the prostate and bladder neck?

Options:
  Antibiotics
✓ Alpha-blockers
  Anticholinergics
  Beta-blockers
  Antimuscarinics

Explanation:
Alpha-blockers (alpha-1 adrenergic antagonists) work by relaxing the smooth muscle in the prostate gland and bladder neck, thereby improving urine flow and reducing BPH symptoms.

================================================================================
Question 549 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A five year old girl has been passing urine frequently for the last 2 days and complaining of pain when doing so. She is febrile with temprature 39C and has shivering as well. She also complains of backache and has vomited 3 times today. On examination she looks unwell, febrile, and tachycardic. Her repiratory rate is 25/min and her O2 Saturaiorn is 99 % in room air. Her abdomen is soft, not distended but there is tenderness on palpating the right loin. Urine dipstick shows leucocytes ++, Nitrites +++, blood trace. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Options:
  Acute Cholecystitis
  Acute Pancreatitis
  Appendicitis
  Cystitis
✓ Pyelonephritis

Explanation:
The constellation of high fever, rigors (shivering), vomiting, flank pain/loin tenderness (backache), and urinary symptoms (frequency, dysuria) with positive urinalysis (leukocytes, nitrites) strongly points to acute pyelonephritis, an upper urinary tract infection.

================================================================================
Question 550 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 40-year-old patient is receiving a kidney transplant from a living donor, who is a close family member. What is this type of transplant called?

Options:
  Autograft
  Isograft
  Xenograft
✓ Allograft
  Heterograft

Explanation:
A transplant between genetically non-identical individuals of the same species (like family members or unrelated humans) is called an Allograft (or homograft). An Isograft is between genetically identical individuals (twins). The marked option 'B' in source might be incorrect if they are not identical twins.

================================================================================
Question 551 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 15-year-old girl presented to gynae OPD with no menses. Ultrasound confirms blind vaginal vault with absence uterus and cervix. What test would be most useful in this patient?

Options:
  B HCG
✓ Karyotyping
  Serum TSH
  Alpha fetoprotein levels
  Beta HCG

Explanation:
The findings of primary amenorrhea with an absent uterus and cervix and a blind vaginal pouch (Mullerian agenesis or Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser syndrome vs. Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome) require Karyotyping to differentiate between a genetic female (46,XX - MRKH) and a genetic male (46,XY - AIS).

================================================================================
Question 552 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 45 years old female has a negative metastatic workup for carcinoma cervix. Her local examination shows a growth in the cervix extending beyond the cervix and involving the vagina (but not lower third) and attaches the parametrium but not reaching the pelvic side walls. Her preliminary clinical stage is which of the following?

Options:
  IA
  IB
  IIA
✓ IIB
  IIIA

Explanation:
According to FIGO staging for cervical cancer: Stage II involves extension beyond the cervix but not to the pelvic wall or lower third of vagina. IIA involves the vagina (without parametrial invasion). IIB involves the parametrium but does not reach the pelvic wall. Since the tumor 'attaches the parametrium', it is Stage IIB.

================================================================================
Question 553 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 60 year man recently retired from fire proof textile industry developed dyspnoea while climbing stairs. On investigation, x ray showed ground glass appearance in lower two third of lung fields. Which of the following occupational disease the man suffered from?

Options:
✓ Asbestosis
  Silicosis
  Talcosis
  Siderosis
  Asbestosis

Explanation:
Asbestos exposure is common in fireproofing and textile industries. Asbestosis typically presents with dyspnea and interstitial fibrosis, often showing a ground-glass appearance or reticulonodular pattern predominantly in the lower lung zones.

================================================================================
Question 554 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 55 years old woman comes to surgical OPD with complaints of itching and scaling of the left breast nipple area. After taking biopsy, a 2 cm palpable mass was also noted under the skin of the nipple. The diagnosis was made to be Paget's disease. Which of the following is likely to be an association?

Options:
  Fibroadenoma
✓ Ductal carcinoma in situ
  Invasive lobular carcinoma
  Intraductal papilloma
  Tubular carcinoma

Explanation:
Paget's disease of the nipple is almost exclusively associated with an underlying breast malignancy, most commonly Ductal Carcinoma In Situ (DCIS) or invasive ductal carcinoma.

================================================================================
Question 555 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 21 year old presented to emergency department with history of vomiting and watery diarrhea for 2 days. His observations are BP 90/60 mmHg, pulse 105/72 mmHg, respiratory rate 14/min, temperature 36.9 Deg C. On examination, the patient is soft non-tender. Capillary refill is 2 seconds and his skin turgor is normal. His arterial blood gases show: pH 7.23, pCO2 15/15 and he is having a known chronic renal failure. The patient's blood test shows: K: 3.2, Ureas: 10.5, creatinine: 135 µmol/L (GFR: 45) and T.L.C: 14.8. K: 4.8 mmol/L (3.5 - 5.0). Ureas: 10.5 mmol/L (2.0 - 7.0). Creatinine: 135 µmol/L (55 - 120). With regards to this patient’s hyponatremia which of the following is the best approach?

Options:
  Encourage PO fluids
  Restriction to less than 1 litre a day
  IV 3% sodium chloride
  Oral antibiotics
✓ IV isotonic normal saline

Explanation:
Although sodium is not explicitly listed in the lab values provided in the text (likely missing data), the clinical picture of vomiting, diarrhea, hypotension, and tachycardia suggests hypovolemic hyponatremia. The appropriate treatment for hypovolemic hyponatremia is volume resuscitation with IV isotonic normal saline.

================================================================================
Question 556 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 60 years old male patient presents with sudden onset sharp pain in right flank and right side of scrotum. There is associated haematuria. Ultrasound examination showed a stone impacted in ureter. Stones were removed through surgical intervention and it was later found that the patient had gout and associated hyperuricemia. What is the prevalence of uric acid stones in general population?

Options:
✓ 1-2%
  50%
  75%
  80%
  90%

Explanation:
Uric acid stones account for approximately 5-10% of all kidney stones in the general population. In patients with gout, the prevalence is much higher. Among the options, 1-2% is low, but the other options (50-90%) are far too high for the *general population*. Often cited ranges are 5-10%, so '1-2%' is likely the intended low-end distractor or there is a specific context, but generally, they are the third most common type after calcium and struvite.

================================================================================
Question 557 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Turkey was recently struck with massive earthquake. The NDMA of Pakistan has prepared building codes to cope with the underlying risk of disaster due to earthquake. Which of the following term related to disaster does not apply?

Options:
  Mitigation
  Preparedness
  Recovery
  Rehabilitation
✓ Response

Explanation:
Developing building codes to withstand earthquakes is a proactive measure taken *before* a disaster occurs to reduce its impact. This falls under Mitigation (reducing risk) or Preparedness. Response refers to the immediate actions taken *during or immediately after* the disaster to save lives. Therefore, building codes do not fall under the 'Response' phase.

================================================================================
Question 558 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 37 years old woman came to opd with 3 months amenorrhea, now complaining of pv bleeding from last 4 hrs and cramping abdominal pain. She is vitally stable and afebrile. On pelvic examination uterus is 6 weeks size, os is open and mild per vaginal bleeding seen. What is the likely diagnosis?

Options:
✓ Inevitable miscarriage
  Missed miscarriage
  Incomplete miscarriage
  Threatened miscarriage
  Septic miscarriage

Explanation:
The presence of vaginal bleeding and abdominal pain with an *open* cervical os in a pregnancy < 24 weeks indicates that the miscarriage process has started and cannot be stopped, hence 'Inevitable miscarriage'. The uterus size (6 weeks) being smaller than dates (3 months) could suggest some products have passed or growth arrested, but the open os with ongoing bleeding/pain is the key for inevitable (or incomplete if products are passing). If products were actively passing or passed, it would be incomplete. With 'mild' bleeding and open os, Inevitable is a strong classification before expulsion.

================================================================================
Question 559 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 55-year-old woman was admitted as an inpatient with urosepsis and an acute kidney injury (AKI). Throughout her admission, she had recurrent severe hyperkalemia that only transiently improve with insulin and dextrose infusions. She takes no regular medications and has no significant past medical history. What would be an additional prescription to help prevent this recurrence?

Options:
  Calcium Gluconate
✓ Calcium resonium
  Furosemide
  Magnesium supplementation
  Spironolactone

Explanation:
For recurrent hyperkalemia that responds only transiently to shifting agents (insulin/dextrose), a potassium-binding resin like Calcium Resonium (or sodium polystyrene sulfonate) is needed to actually remove potassium from the body via the gut, preventing recurrence.

================================================================================
Question 560 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 29 years old primigravida presented in 35 weeks of gestational amenorrhea with the complaint of excessive nausea and vomiting, palpitations and restlessness. Her ultrasound shows complete hydatidiform mole with Bhcg of 3,50,000. Which endocrinological condition is associated with this patient?

Options:
✓ Hyperthyroidism
  Hypothyroidism
  Hyperparathyroidism
  Hypoparathyroidism
  Sheehan’s syndrome

Explanation:
High levels of beta-hCG, as seen in molar pregnancy (hydatidiform mole), can cross-react with the TSH receptor due to structural similarity, stimulating the thyroid gland and causing secondary hyperthyroidism (gestational transient thyrotoxicosis).

================================================================================
Question 561 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 38-year-old male patient presents to the family medicine clinic with complaints of heartburn and regurgitation of stomach contents into his throat, especially after meals and stress experienced during nocturnal shift and occasional hoarseness. His symptoms are relieved by antacids and proton pump inhibitors. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Options:
  GEAS
✓ GERD
  Esophageal varices
  Erosive esophagitis
  Gastric cancer

Explanation:
The symptoms of heartburn, regurgitation, and extra-esophageal symptoms like hoarseness (Laryngopharyngeal reflux), which are relieved by acid-suppressive therapy, are classic for Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD).

================================================================================
Question 562 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 48 years old woman comes to gyne OPD with complaints of abnormal bleeding per vaginum for the last one year. Biopsy of the endometrium sent for histopathology which revealed endometrial carcinoma. What is the risk factor for endometrial carcinoma?

Options:
✓ Polymenorrhoea
  Premenopausal years
  Premenopausal years
  Menstrual periods
  Early menopause

Explanation:
Risk factors for endometrial carcinoma are generally related to prolonged unopposed estrogen exposure. This includes nulliparity, obesity, late menopause, and irregular cycles like anovulation. Polymenorrhea (frequent cycles) could imply anovulatory cycles or hormonal imbalance contributing to risk, whereas early menopause is protective.

================================================================================
Question 563 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 33 years old woman came to the outpatient department with a lump in the left breast. The lump is soft but not mobile. There is no nipple discharge. What is the most appropriate screening test for the diagnosis of breast lump?

Options:
  Fine needle aspiration (FNA)
✓ Mammography
  MRI scan
  Core biopsy
  Self-examination

Explanation:
For a palpable breast lump in a 33-year-old, the diagnostic workup typically begins with imaging. While ultrasound is often first-line for women under 35/40, mammography is the standard 'screening' and diagnostic imaging modality mentioned in guidelines for characterizing lumps, often alongside ultrasound. Biopsy (FNA/Core) is for diagnosis, not screening.

================================================================================
Question 564 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A child of 3 years old presented with muscle wasting, loss of subcutaneous fat with no signs of edema and weight below 60% of WHO standard. The mother is unaware of not giving enough proteins and other nutrients to the child after six months. What is the likely diagnosis?

Options:
  Under nutrition
  Protein deficiency
  Marasmus & Kwashiorkor
  Under nutrition
✓ Marasmus

Explanation:
The clinical picture of severe muscle wasting, loss of subcutaneous fat, absence of edema, and very low weight (<60% standard) is the definition of Marasmus, a form of severe calorie and protein malnutrition.

================================================================================
Question 565 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 40 years old P5 has presented with excessive menstrual bleeding for the last 3 years. Clinically she is a case of anemia with Hb of 8gm/dl. You did pelvic ultrasound which shows fibroid in posterior uterine wall. Which one of the following will be expected to increase the amount of blood loss?

Options:
  Less than 50 ml
  More than 5 ml
✓ More than 80 ml
  More than 100 ml
  More than 150 ml

Explanation:
Menorrhagia (excessive menstrual bleeding) is clinically defined as menstrual blood loss exceeding 80 ml per cycle.

================================================================================
Question 566 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 13 years old girl is brought in Gynae OPD by her mother with the complaint of irregular heavy menstrual bleed. Which she has been experiencing for last 2 years. Her full blood count shows an hb of 8gm/dl with normal platelet count. Her pelvic ultrasound is normal. What is the most likely cause of her condition?

Options:
✓ Hypothyroidism
  Hyperthyroidism
  Thrombocytopenia
  Hypopituitarism
  Ovarian cyst

Explanation:
In an adolescent girl with heavy irregular menstrual bleeding and normal pelvic ultrasound/platelets, anovulatory cycles due to immature HPO axis are common (puberty menorrhagia). However, among the options provided, Hypothyroidism is a well-known systemic cause of menorrhagia and should be screened for.

================================================================================
Question 567 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
During your MBBS class a student falls in class rank from first place to last place. She has also noted a lower pitch to her voice and coarsening of her hair along with increased tendency towards weight gain, menorrhagia and increased intolerance to cold. What relevant investigation will you perform in this case?

Options:
  ACTH
  GH
  LH
  FSH
✓ TFTs

Explanation:
The symptoms of cognitive decline (falling rank), voice change, coarse hair, weight gain, menorrhagia, and cold intolerance are classic signs of hypothyroidism. Thyroid Function Tests (TFTs) are the primary investigation.

================================================================================
Question 568 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 60-year-old patient with history of diabetes for the last 3 years presents with abdominal mass. His serum creatinine on arrival was 1.2mg/dl. CT scan abdomen with contrast was done, 48 hours later repeat labs show a serum creatinine of 2.2mg/dl. His pulse is 86 beats per minute and BP is 110/80mmHg. What is the most likely cause of derangement?

Options:
  Acute interstitial nephritis
  Cholesterol emboli
✓ Contrast-induced nephropathy
  Hypovolemia
  Sepsis causing renal impairment

Explanation:
The acute rise in serum creatinine (AKI) occurring within 48 hours following the administration of iodinated contrast media for a CT scan, especially in a diabetic patient, is the classic presentation of Contrast-Induced Nephropathy (CIN).

================================================================================
Question 569 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 45-year-old known diabetic patient comes to the outpatient department with history of sudden onset of swelling at the symphysis for the last 5 weeks. The swelling is tense and non pitting. What is the most appropriate test for checking mean plasma glucose concentration?

Options:
  Fasting blood glucose
  Post prandial blood sugar
  Fructosamine test
✓ HBA1C
  Serum glucose

Explanation:
HbA1c (Glycated hemoglobin) reflects the mean plasma glucose concentration over the previous 8-12 weeks (2-3 months), making it the standard test for assessing long-term glycemic control.

================================================================================
Question 570 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A five year old female patient with a history of recurrent abortions (4/5) and she had 29 years of age. She was diagnosed with Chromosomal Abnormality. Which protein is likely to be found elevated in this patient?

Options:
  Anti-thrombin III
  Albumin
  Protein S
✓ Factor V Leiden mutation
  Factor II prothrombin gene mutation

Explanation:
While the question stem mentions 'diagnosed with Chromosomal Abnormality', it asks about a protein/factor often linked to recurrent abortions in the context of thrombophilia. Factor V Leiden mutation causes resistance to activated protein C, leading to a hypercoagulable state and recurrent pregnancy loss. (Note: Mutation itself is genetic, but leads to abnormal factor V function).

================================================================================
Question 571 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 40 years old woman was referred by her gynecologist with symptoms of blood in urine, flank pain, lethargy and weight loss. Renal cell carcinoma was diagnosed on MRI. The cytogenetics studies was performed on a renal tumor which demonstrated the presence of terminal deletion of the short arm of chromosome 3. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Options:
✓ Renal cell carcinoma clear cell type
  VHL gene mutation
  Hypoxia inducible factor gene mutation
  Renal cell carcinoma papillary type
  Renal cell carcinoma chromophobe type

Explanation:
Deletion of the short arm of chromosome 3 (3p) is the hallmark genetic abnormality in Clear Cell Renal Cell Carcinoma.

================================================================================
Question 572 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 65 years old woman has developed profuse, heavy, erratic and prolonged menstrual bleeding. She is having hypertension, diabetes, and obesity. Pelvic ultrasound shows a thickened endometrium. What is the most likely cause of her condition?

Options:
  Endometrial hyperplasia
  Endometrial polyp
  Uterine fibroids
✓ Endometrial carcinoma
  Ovarian Carcinoma

Explanation:
Postmenopausal bleeding, especially with risk factors like obesity, diabetes, hypertension (corpus cancer syndrome), and a thickened endometrium on ultrasound, is highly suspicious for endometrial carcinoma.

================================================================================
Question 573 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 32 years old woman who is a diagnosed case of Diabetes type 2 was diagnosed to have endometrial cancer. What is the most important staging investigation?

Options:
✓ Transvaginal ultrasound
  Chest x-ray
  Hysteroscopy
  Endometrial biopsy
  Pipelle

Explanation:
Endometrial cancer is surgically staged. However, for pre-operative assessment, imaging like MRI or Transvaginal Ultrasound can assess myometrial invasion. Among the options for 'staging investigation' (often implying imaging to assess extent), MRI is best, but TVS is useful. Biopsy confirms diagnosis. Chest x-ray screens for metastasis. Strictly, staging is surgical (FIGO). If forced to choose an imaging modality for local extent, TVS/MRI.

================================================================================
Question 574 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 72 years old female presents to OPD with a diagnosis of estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer. Which of the following medication is most appropriate for this purpose?

Options:
  Cephalexin
  Rifampicin
✓ Letrozole
  Danazol
  Tamoxifen

Explanation:
In postmenopausal women (72 years old) with ER-positive breast cancer, Aromatase Inhibitors like Letrozole are generally preferred over Tamoxifen as adjuvant therapy due to better efficacy.

================================================================================
Question 575 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Urodynamic testing is recommended in all of the following patients except?

Options:
  Pre operative assessment
✓ Stress incontinence
  Failed conservative measures
  All patients in urogynecology
  All patients in oncology

Explanation:
Routine urodynamic testing is NOT recommended for women with clearly demonstrable, uncomplicated stress urinary incontinence before primary surgery. It is reserved for complex cases, failed prior treatments, or mixed symptoms.

================================================================================
Question 576 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 50-year-old female presents with severe back pain & is suspected for spinal trauma?

Options:
  Immediate medical intervention
  Perform exploratory laprotomy
  Begin dialysis
  Intravenous fluids and blood transfusion
✓ Spinal immobilization

Explanation:
In any patient with suspected spinal trauma, the immediate priority to prevent further neurological injury is spinal immobilization.

================================================================================
Question 577 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Police brought a medico-legal case of an alleged case of concealment of birth. On examination she had enlarged breasts, lax abdominal muscles, and an old healed episiotomy scar. There are reddish-brown vaginal lochia rubra, is present in the vaginal canal. According to examination findings how many days have been passed since she has delivered the baby?

Options:
  1 day
✓ 2-3 days
  4-5 days
  6 days
  1 week

Explanation:
Lochia rubra (red/reddish-brown) typically lasts for the first 3-4 days postpartum. The description fits the early postpartum period (2-3 days).

================================================================================
Question 578 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 14-years-old girl came to ANE. She never had a menstrual period. She experiences severe lower abdominal pain every 28 days. On examination a bluish bulge was seen at introitus. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Options:
  Asherman's syndrome
✓ Imperforate hymen
  Congenital Adrenal hyperplasia
  Kallman's syndrome
  Transverse vaginal septum

Explanation:
Primary amenorrhea with cyclic abdominal pain (cryptomenorrhea) and a bluish bulge at the introitus (hematocolpos) is the classic presentation of an imperforate hymen.

================================================================================
Question 579 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 30 years old P2 has presented with the complaint of menorrhagia for the last 6 months with 3 fibroid in posterior uterine wall. She wants to preserve her fertility. What is the treatment option in her case?

Options:
✓ Myomectomy
  Tranexamic acid and NSAID
  Hysterectomy
  COCP
  Norethisterone

Explanation:
For a symptomatic patient with multiple fibroids who wishes to preserve fertility, myomectomy (surgical removal of fibroids) is the treatment of choice to treat the menorrhagia while sparing the uterus.

================================================================================
Question 580 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 60-year-old woman is found to have a renal anomaly where one kidney is significantly smaller and non-functioning, while the other kidney is normal in size and function. What is the medical term for this condition?

Options:
✓ Renal hypoplasia
  Horseshoe kidney
  Renal agenesis
  Multicystic dysplastic kidney
  Hepatic cystoma

Explanation:
Renal hypoplasia refers to a kidney that is congenitally small with a reduced number of nephrons but otherwise normal architecture, often leading to poor function.

================================================================================
Question 581 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 60 years old male patient was admitted to the chest ward for a very sick patient. He has a history of bladder cancer, hypertension and diabetes. Which of the following factors is the most important predisposing condition for the development of bladder cancer?

Options:
  Aromatic amines
✓ Cigarette smoking
  Cyclophosphamide treatment
  Human papilloma virus
  Chronic cystitis

Explanation:
Cigarette smoking is the single most important risk factor for bladder cancer, accounting for at least 50% of cases.

================================================================================
Question 582 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 45 years old woman presented with hard mass in cervix with restricted mobility. Her examination reveals a reddish area of mucosal irregularity over the surface of cervix. The cytogenetics studies was performed on a cervical tumor which demonstrated the presence of terminal deletion of the short arm of chromosome 3. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Options:
  Common types of cervical carcinoma
  Radiation exposure
  Pollution
✓ Human papilloma virus
  Smoking

Explanation:
The question stem contains conflicting information (chromosome 3p deletion is classic for RCC). However, for a cervical tumor/mass, Human Papillomavirus (HPV) infection is the overwhelming primary cause of cervical carcinoma.

================================================================================
Question 583 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 60-year-old female patient has a long history of kidney stones and complains of recurrent abdominal pain. On examination, she has mild abdominal tenderness on the right side. Which investigation would be most reliable for the diagnosis?

Options:
  Abdominal ultrasound
✓ CT scan abdomen
  Sinusitis visne
  Urethral ultrasound
  Retrograde ureteropyelography

Explanation:
Non-contrast CT scan of the abdomen/pelvis (CT KUB) is the gold standard and most reliable investigation for diagnosing kidney stones.

================================================================================
Question 584 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 32 years old woman came to a pelvic ultrasound with a mass in the pouch of douglas which contains calcification and septa. Left lateral aspect of the uterus showed a 'ground glass' appearance. She reports severe dysmenorrhea and dyspareunia. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Options:
✓ Endometriosis
  Ectopic pregnancy
  Functional ovarian cysts
  Adenomyosis
  Dermoid cyst

Explanation:
The combination of a pelvic mass (likely endometrioma) with 'ground glass' appearance on ultrasound, along with severe dysmenorrhea and dyspareunia, is classic for Endometriosis.

================================================================================
Question 585 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A patient is having a urinary tract infection. Pseudomonas is cultured. Which of the following waste must be collected in black bag?

Options:
✓ Waste collection
  Medical waste
  Catheters
  Body parts
  Urine sample

Explanation:
In hospital waste management color coding, black bags are typically used for non-infectious, general municipal waste (like paper, wrappers). Infectious waste goes in yellow or red. Urine samples or contaminated items would not go in black bags. The question might be asking what *type* of waste goes in black, or is a trick. Assuming standard coding, general waste is black.

================================================================================
Question 586 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
All of the following are treatment options for stress urinary incontinence except?

Options:
  Burch colposuspension
  Transvaginal mesh
  Pelvic floor muscle exercises
✓ Alpha-blocking agents
  Norethisterone

Explanation:
Alpha-blockers relax the urethral sphincter and are used to treat retention/BPH; they can actually *worsen* stress incontinence. They are not a treatment for it. Treatments include pelvic floor exercises, surgery (colposuspension, slings), and sometimes alpha-agonists (not blockers).

================================================================================
Question 587 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 50-year-old obese woman with type 2 diabetes is found to have inadequate control of her disease 2 months after using metformin alone, metformin and glyburide. The physician decided to add exenatide to her treatment regimen. Which of the following molecular actions most likely mediated the therapeutic effect of the added drug in the patient?

Options:
  Activation of adrenaline
  Activation of glucagon
  Activation of adenosine triphosphate (ATP)-sensitive K+ channels
✓ Inhibition of glucagon-like polypeptide
  Inhibition of alpha-glucosidase

Explanation:
Exenatide is a GLP-1 receptor agonist (incretin mimetic). It works by mimicking the action of Glucagon-Like Peptide-1 (GLP-1), stimulating insulin secretion and suppressing glucagon. The option D is worded as 'Inhibition of glucagon-like polypeptide' which is incorrect mechanistically (it mimics/activates the receptor), but 'Activation of glucagon-like polypeptide (receptors)' is the intended mechanism. If D implies 'Inhibition of glucagon', that is a correct effect.

================================================================================
Question 588 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 2 months old child is brought to pediatric emergency with complaint of urinary obstruction. Ultrasound reveals a large cystic mass in the lower right abdomen which grossly distorted kidney. Biopsy specimen shows ducts and tubules lined by epithelial cells and surrounded by cuffs of cellular mesenchyme. What is the most probable diagnosis on the basis of history and morphology?

Options:
  Carcinoma pelvis
✓ Multicystic dysplasia
  Renal agenesis
  Ectrophy of bladder
  Renal hypoplasia

Explanation:
The findings of a large cystic mass replacing/distorting the kidney in an infant, with histology showing primitive ducts/tubules surrounded by undifferentiated mesenchyme, are characteristic of Multicystic Dysplastic Kidney (MCDK).

================================================================================
Question 589 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 60-year-old man was admitted as an inpatient with urosepsis and an acute kidney injury (AKI). Her Potassium level is 6.8 mg/dL. The trainee medical officer on duty asks you to give calcium gluconate to this patient. What's the role of calcium gluconate the management of hyperkalemia?

Options:
  Decrease potassium levels by unknown mechanism
  Increase gastrointestinal loss of potassium
  Increase renal excretion of potassium
  Intracellular shift of potassium
✓ Stabilization of cardiac membrane

Explanation:
Calcium gluconate does not lower potassium levels. Its specific role in severe hyperkalemia is to stabilize the cardiac cell membrane potential, reducing the risk of life-threatening arrhythmias.

================================================================================
Question 590 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 30 years old woman with history of Pelvic Inflammatory Disease presented to the emergency department with sudden onset right lower quadrant pain with nausea and vomiting. On examination, her abdomen is tender and her heart, pulse and blood pressure shows right sided ovarian mass and fluid collection in Douglas. What is primary treatment for ectopic pregnancy in this patient?

Options:
✓ Surgical removal of ectopic pregnancy
  Bed rest
  Hormonal therapy
  No treatment, it resolves on its own
  Transvaginal ultrasound

Explanation:
Given the acute presentation with pain, fluid in the pouch of Douglas (suggesting rupture/bleeding), and history of PID (risk factor), this is likely a ruptured ectopic pregnancy or one at high risk. Surgical management (salpingectomy or salpingostomy) is the primary treatment for acute/unstable ectopic pregnancy.

================================================================================
Question 591 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 6 months old baby has low weight. History of bottle feeding and low birth weight. The father of the baby is tall, educated and has 5 more siblings. They are living in a small house. You have done Mid upper Arm Circumference that was 10.5 cm. Of which of the following malnutrition will you label this child?

Options:
  Acute malnutrition
  Chronic malnutrition
✓ Severely acute malnutrition
  Stunting
  Wasting

Explanation:
A Mid-Upper Arm Circumference (MUAC) of less than 11.5 cm (115 mm) in a child aged 6-59 months indicates Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM).

================================================================================
Question 592 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
As a part of clinical workup for infertility which of the following set of investigation you will advise?

Options:
  Chest X-ray, observation
  Husband semen analysis, observation
  Thyroid ultrasound, follicular biopsy, urine culture
✓ Husband semen analysis, ultrasound, hormonal profile
  Hormonal profile

Explanation:
A basic infertility workup includes assessing the male factor (Semen Analysis), ovulation/ovarian reserve (Hormonal profile), and uterine/tubal anatomy (Ultrasound/HSG).

================================================================================
Question 593 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
You are working as a medical officer in a remote area of Chitral. Many children presented to you with dental fluorosis, brown, black or some with yellow discoloration of teeth. The Public health authorities have taken samples of water of the area and have showed excess of a trace element. Which of the following concerns can you address with dental fluorosis?

Options:
  Calcium carriers
✓ Fluorine
  Lead
  Iodine
  Dental fluorosis

Explanation:
Dental fluorosis is caused by the excessive ingestion of fluoride (fluorine) during tooth development.

================================================================================
Question 594 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Which of the following can be used to assess kidney functions at tubular level?

Options:
✓ Fractional excretion of Na
  Creatinine clearance
  GFR
  B-2 microglobulin
  Insulin clearance

Explanation:
Fractional Excretion of Sodium (FENa) measures the percentage of filtered sodium that is excreted in the urine. It is a useful test to differentiate between prerenal azotemia (low FENa, intact tubular function) and acute tubular necrosis (high FENa, tubular dysfunction).

================================================================================
Question 595 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 48 years old woman is smoking with increasing frequency, urgency and nocturia despite limiting caffeine intake, bladder re-training and quitting smoking. Which of the following drugs can be used as second line of management?

Options:
  Tolterodine
✓ Solifenacin
  Topical estrogen creams
  Darfenacin
  Trospium

Explanation:
For overactive bladder (OAB) symptoms (frequency, urgency) that fail conservative measures, antimuscarinics like Solifenacin are a standard second-line pharmacological treatment.

================================================================================
Question 596 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 28years old female presented with severe abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. She reports missed menstrual period 2 weeks ago. On physical examination, there is tenderness in right iliac fossa. What is the likely diagnosis?

Options:
  Acute appendicitis
  Urinary tract infection
✓ Ectopic pregnancy
  Peritonitis

Explanation:
The triad of missed period, vaginal bleeding, and abdominal pain in a woman of reproductive age is ectopic pregnancy until proven otherwise. RIF tenderness could be appendicitis, but the missed period/bleeding strongly points to ectopic.

================================================================================
Question 597 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
An 18 years old girl presented with a round, painless, and very mobile lump in her right breast that she noticed about a week ago. What would be the radiological investigation of choice?

Options:
✓ Ultrasound
  Mammogram
  CT Scan
  MRI
  Chest X-ray

Explanation:
In women under 35 years of age with a breast lump, breast ultrasound is the radiological investigation of choice because dense breast tissue makes mammography less sensitive.

================================================================================
Question 598 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 48 year old school teacher, presents with symptoms of leaking urine on coughing, sneezing and while exercising. She is not obese, has no co-morbidities. On examination she has moderate cystocele and minimal rectocele. What is the best first line of treatment for this patient?

Options:
  Vaginal estrogen creams
✓ Supervised pelvic floor exercises
  Anticholinergic medications
  Burch Colposuspension
  Insertion of mid urethral tape

Explanation:
For stress urinary incontinence (leaking with cough/sneeze), conservative management with supervised pelvic floor muscle training (PFMT) is the recommended first-line treatment.

================================================================================
Question 599 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 50 years old patient with long standing features of anorexia, nausea, generalized weakness and depressive symptoms. On examination, his blood pressure 180/100. Lab results show Hb 8 gm/dl, SGPT 42, S Creatinine 6 gm/dl (0.5 -1.5 mg/dl), S calcium 12 gm/dl (8.5-10.5 mg/dl), S PTH 400 pg/ml (10-65 pg/ml). What is the most likely cause of hypercalcaemia in this patient?

Options:
  Parathyroid Adenoma
  Parathyroid Carcinoma
✓ Tertiary Hyperparathyroidism
  Renal Cell Carcinoma
  Pagets Disease

Explanation:
The patient has chronic renal failure (Creatinine 6.0). Secondary hyperparathyroidism develops in CRF. When the parathyroid glands become autonomous and secrete high PTH (400) leading to hypercalcemia (Ca 12) despite renal failure, it is called Tertiary Hyperparathyroidism.

================================================================================
Question 600 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 60 years old P3 presented with the complaint of gestational amenorrhea and weight loss despite vomiting and vaginal bleeding. Ultrasound examination shows new snow storm appearance, the uterus was 28 weeks. What is the most appropriate treatment modality in this patient?

Options:
  Dilatation and curettage
✓ Suction curettage
  Miniprostal
  Prostaglandin E1
  Norethisterone

Explanation:
The ultrasound finding of 'snow storm appearance' and uterus larger than dates (28 weeks size vs gestational amenorrhea not specified but implied mismatch) indicates a Molar Pregnancy (Hydatidiform Mole). The treatment of choice is Suction Curettage.

================================================================================
Question 601 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A renal biopsy specimen of a 58 year old male with a history of uncontrolled hypertension was send to hospital lab, for a histopathologist. Which while performing gross examination of the renal biopsy, he reported that the capsule was intact and the cortical surface showed areas of hemorrhage. The histopathologist reported that the capsule was intact, and the cortical surface showed areas of hemorrhage. What is the possible cause of these findings?

Options:
  Granulomerulonephritis
✓ Malignant hypertension
  Hyperuricemia
  Amyloidosis
  Perinephric hematoma

Explanation:
Malignant hypertension causes characteristic 'flea-bitten' kidney appearance due to petechial hemorrhages on the cortical surface.

================================================================================
Question 602 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 20 years old P3 have presented with the complaint of amenorrhea and post coital bleeding. Go per speculum examination, her cervix is red and inflamed. She is advised pop smear and cautry cervix. Screening pop smear who should be screened?

Options:
  15 to 20 years girls
  Young women under 25 years
✓ Women aged 25 to 45 years
  Older women 45+ years
  All women

Explanation:
Cervical cancer screening (Pap smear) guidelines vary, but generally, screening starts at age 21 or 25. Women aged 25 to 49 are the primary target group for routine screening (e.g., every 3 years).

================================================================================
Question 603 (KMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Police caught a renal transplant surgeon and charged for doing illegal renal transplants in a private setup. He has been charged with Human Organ Transplant Act of Pakistan. The penalty he could face is?

Options:
  Imprisonment up to 1 year
  Imprisonment up to 3 years
  Imprisonment for up to 5 years and removal of name for 2 years only
✓ Imprisonment up to 5 years and removal of name for 3 years
  Removal of name from PMDC

Explanation:
According to the Human Organ Transplant Ordinance (Pakistan), penalties involve imprisonment (up to 10 years in some sections) and fine. Removal of name from the medical register is also a penalty. Option D (Imprisonment up to 10 years and removal of name for 3 years) reflects common legal penalties for such offenses.
