While morning sickness, lethargy, and malaise are presumptive symptoms of pregnancy, a urine pregnancy test (detecting hCG) is a highly reliable and widely used diagnostic tool for confirming pregnancy.

================================================================================
Question 1085 (WMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Which instrument is use to examine the victim of homosexuality:

Options:
  Tooth forcep
  Scalpel
  Scissors
✓ Proctoscope and colonoscope
  Knife

Explanation:
In cases of alleged sodomy or sexual assault involving the anal region, a proctoscope (or anoscope) would be used for internal examination of the anal canal and rectum to look for injuries or other evidence.

================================================================================
Question 1086 (WMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 30 years male old patient has a road traffic accident half hour ago, he is presented in emergency department with gross haematuria, his BP is 100/80, his pulse is 100/min. On examination he had bruise in his right flank. What will be next step of management?

Options:
  Exploratory Laparotomy
✓ CT Scan Abdomen + Pelvis
  Blood Transfusion
  Right Nephrectomy
  X-ray erect Abdomen

Explanation:
Given the history of trauma, gross hematuria, flank bruise, and stable but borderline vital signs, a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis is the most appropriate next step. It provides detailed imaging of the kidneys and other abdominal organs to assess for renal injury or other intra-abdominal trauma.

================================================================================
Question 1087 (WMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 60 years old patient presented e Gross haematuria e his CT Scan showed right renel mass which is 4 cm and confined to kidney there is no metastasis what is the stage of disease?

Options:
✓ T1a N0M0
  T2a N0M0
  T1b N0M0
  T2b N0M0
  T3 N0M0

Explanation:
According to the TNM staging system for renal cell carcinoma, a tumor confined to the kidney and ≤ 7 cm in greatest dimension is classified as T1. A tumor ≤ 4 cm is T1a. No lymph node involvement (N0) and no distant metastasis (M0) classify it as Stage T1a N0M0.

================================================================================
Question 1088 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A water sample was taken from a source that was supplying Nathiagali .On analysis it was declared unfit for human consumption on account of raised concentration of a chemical. What is the likely chemical which has resulted in making this water unfit?

Options:
  Calcium
  Chlorides
  Iodine
✓ Nitrite
  Zinc

Explanation:
The presence of nitrites in water is a strong indicator of recent organic pollution, usually from sewage or agricultural runoff. High concentrations render water unfit for consumption due to the risk of methaemoglobinaemia (blue baby syndrome) and the potential presence of pathogenic organisms.

================================================================================
Question 1089 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A well in a rural area was contaminated with an unhygienic source nearby. What is the disease more likely to be transmitted through drinking this well water?

Options:
  Dental fluorosis
  Goitre
  Leishmaniasis
  Trachoma
✓ Typhoid

Explanation:
Typhoid fever is a waterborne disease caused by Salmonella Typhi, commonly transmitted through water contaminated with fecal matter. The other options are vector-borne (Leishmaniasis), contact/hygiene-related (Trachoma), or deficiency/excess related (Goitre, Fluorosis).

================================================================================
Question 1090 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A family of four members in a village was using coal fire. One day they were brought to the hospital with memory loss, breathing difficulty and unconsciousness. What is the most probable diagnosis?

Options:
✓ CO poisoning
  CO2 poisoning
  Nitrogen dioxide poisoning
  Nitrous oxide poisoning
  Sulphur dioxide poisoning

Explanation:
Incomplete combustion of coal produces Carbon Monoxide (CO). In an enclosed space, this odorless gas causes hypoxia, leading to symptoms like memory loss, confusion, dyspnea, and unconsciousness.

================================================================================
Question 1091 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 30 years old woman had symptoms of of vaginal itching and discharge. On examination she had white cheesy discharge adherent to walls of vagina with vaginal inflammation. The most likely causative organism is:

Options:
✓ Candida albicans
  HIV infection
  Neisseria gonorrhea
  Treponema pallidum
  Trichomonas vaginalis

Explanation:
White, cheesy (curd-like) vaginal discharge accompanied by itching and inflammation is the classic presentation of Vulvovaginal Candidiasis, caused by Candida albicans.

================================================================================
Question 1092 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
STDs are on the rise all over the world. A young woman presented to a doctor in the emergency with bilateral conjunctivitis and high grade temperature. On examination she had swelling of eyelids and conjunctiva and copious purulent discharge. On laboratory smear diplococcic were seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Options:
✓ Gonococci
  H. influenzae
  Meningococci
  Staphylococci
  Streptococci

Explanation:
Hyperacute purulent conjunctivitis with the presence of intracellular diplococci on smear is characteristic of Gonococcal conjunctivitis (caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae).

================================================================================
Question 1093 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
The two important waste disposal methods include sullage as well as sewage. What does sullage consist of?

Options:
  Inorganic waste
  Organic waste
  Solid vegetable waste matter
  Waste containing human excreta
✓ Waste water from kitchen

Explanation:
Sullage is the wastewater generated from households (kitchens, bathrooms, laundries) that does not contain human excreta. Sewage includes wastewater containing human excreta.

================================================================================
Question 1094 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Pakistan generates 0.5—2 kg hospital waste /bed/day. . What is the color code of plastic bag for disposing of microbial laboratory culture waste?

Options:
  Black
  Blue
  Red
  White
✓ Yellow

Explanation:
According to standard hospital waste management guidelines (including in Pakistan), yellow bags are used for infectious waste, which includes microbial laboratory cultures.

================================================================================
Question 1095 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Amena, Gravida 2 with 32 weeks of gestation visited OPD for routine checkup. Her BP was found to be 170/95 mm Hg. What advise did the doctor give her to report immediately if she has:

Options:
  Backache
  Lower abdominal pain
  Swelling of feet
  Tinnitus
✓ Vomiting

Explanation:
The patient has signs of severe pre-eclampsia (BP 170/95). Warning signs of impending eclampsia or severe complications include severe headache, visual disturbances, epigastric pain, and vomiting. Vomiting can be a sign of increased intracranial pressure or HELLP syndrome.

================================================================================
Question 1096 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A child of 1 year presents with muscle wasting, loss of subcutaneous fat with no signs of edema . His weight is below 60% of WHO standard. The mother gives history of not giving enough proteins and other nutrients to the child after six months of age. What is the likely diagnosis?

Options:
  Kwashiorkor
✓ Marasmus
  Marasmus & kwashiorkor
  Protein deficiency
  Vitamin B12 deficiency

Explanation:
Marasmus is characterized by severe energy and protein deficiency, leading to gross muscle wasting, loss of subcutaneous fat, weight <60% of standard, and importantly, the absence of edema (which distinguishes it from Kwashiorkor).

================================================================================
Question 1097 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A child aged 2 years presented with cough and difficulty in breathing. On examination the child had lower chest in drawing. According to IMNCI classification in which category will he be placed?

Options:
  Cough /cold only
  No Pneumonia
  Pneumonia
✓ Severe pneumonia
  Very severe disease

Explanation:
According to traditional IMNCI guidelines typically used in exams, lower chest indrawing in a child aged 2 months to 5 years is classified as 'Severe Pneumonia' requiring referral. (Note: Updated WHO guidelines might classify this as Pneumonia managed at home, but Severe Pneumonia is the standard answer for indrawing in this context).

================================================================================
Question 1098 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 55-year-old female with chronic kidney disease (CKD) is undergoing her first hemodialysis session. During the session, she starts to feel nausea and complains of a headache. Her blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her symptoms

Options:
  Hypokalemia
✓ Dialysis disequilibrium syndrome
  Hypercalcemia
  Hypoglycemia
  Fluid overload

Explanation:
Dialysis Disequilibrium Syndrome (DDS) is a neurological complication that can occur during or after the first few hemodialysis sessions due to rapid removal of urea from the blood, creating an osmotic gradient that causes cerebral edema. Symptoms include nausea, headache, and confusion.

================================================================================
Question 1099 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 45-year-old woman with a history of chronic NSAID use presents with fever, rash, and hematuria. She complains of generalized malaise and joint pain. Lab results show elevated eosinophils, increased creatinine, and BUN levels. Urinalysis reveals white blood cell casts. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis

Options:
  Acute tubular necrosis
  Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis
✓ Acute interstitial nephritis
  Pre-renal azotemia
  Nephrotic syndrome

Explanation:
The classic triad of fever, rash, and eosinophilia, along with renal impairment (elevated BUN/Cr) and sterile pyuria (WBC casts) in the context of drug use (NSAIDs), is diagnostic for Acute Interstitial Nephritis (AIN).

================================================================================
Question 1100 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
What is the primary cause of hypernatremia

Options:
  Excessive sodium intake
✓ Excessive water loss
  Adrenal insufficiency
  Hypothyroidism
  Excessive water intake

Explanation:
Hypernatremia is most commonly caused by a net loss of water (dehydration) that is not replaced, leading to a relative excess of sodium.

================================================================================
Question 1101 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 14 years old patient presents with black coloured urine puffiness and oliguria. He had sore throat about two weeks ago. On examination pulse 80/min Blood pressure 160/100 and pedal edema. What is the likely diagnosis

Options:
  Henoch schonlein syndrome
  IgA Nephropathy
  Minimal change disease
✓ Post streptococcal glomerulonephritis
  SLE

Explanation:
The clinical presentation of nephritic syndrome (hematuria/black urine, hypertension, oliguria, edema) occurring 1-2 weeks after a sore throat is characteristic of Post-Streptococcal Glomerulonephritis (PSGN).

================================================================================
Question 1102 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 40 year old male after head injury secondary to RTA sustained extradural hematoma which was managed by neurosurgeon. On third day of admission his electrolytes report Sodium: 125 mmol/L Potassium: 3.8 mmol/ L calcium: 98 mmol/L What could be most likely cause of Hyponatremia

Options:
  Cerebral Metastasis
  Hypoxemia
✓ SIADH
  Pulmonary infection
  Hypothyroidism

Explanation:
The Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone (SIADH) is a common cause of hyponatremia following head injury, due to the unregulated release of ADH.

================================================================================
Question 1103 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 46-year-old male with a history of obesity and physical inactivity presents with a 04-month history of polyuria, polydipsia, and weight loss His fasting blood glucose is 195 mg/dL HbA1c is 9% What would be the most appropriate initial management step for this patient

Options:
✓ Metformin 500 mg orally twice daily
  Insulin glargine 10 units subcutaneously once daily
  Lifestyle modifications (diet and exercise) alone
  Gliclazide 30 mg orally twice daily
  Pioglitazone 15 mg orally once daily

Explanation:
Metformin is the first-line pharmacological therapy for Type 2 Diabetes. Although the HbA1c is high (9%), guidelines typically recommend starting Metformin while considering combination therapy or insulin if catabolic symptoms are severe. However, as an 'initial management step' oral medication choice, Metformin is the standard first line unless there is severe metabolic decompensation (DKA).

================================================================================
Question 1104 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 35-year-old female with a known history of Graves’ disease presents to the emergency department with fever, palpitations, and altered mental status. On examination, she is found to have a heart rate of 140 bpm, a temperature of 39°C, and a blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg. Laboratory tests reveal elevated free T4 and suppressed TSH levels. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management step for this patient

Options:
✓ Administer intravenous propranolol
  Start oral methimazole
  Administer intravenous hydrocortisone
  Perform an urgent thyroidectomy
  Start oral radioactive iodine therapy

Explanation:
This patient is presenting with Thyroid Storm. The immediate priority is to control the severe adrenergic symptoms (tachycardia) which can be life-threatening. Beta-blockers like Propranolol are the first line for symptom control, followed by antithyroid drugs (PTU/Methimazole), steroids, and iodine.

================================================================================
Question 1105 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 45-year-old male with chronic kidney disease (CKD) presents with fatigue and generalized bone pain. Laboratory findings show elevated PTH, low calcium, and high phosphate levels. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for his elevated PTH

Options:
  Primary hyperparathyroidism
✓ Secondary hyperparathyroidism
  Tertiary hyperparathyroidism
  Vitamin D deficiency
  Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia

Explanation:
In CKD, decreased phosphate excretion and reduced activation of Vitamin D lead to hypocalcemia and hyperphosphatemia. This stimulates the parathyroid glands to secrete excessive PTH, a condition known as Secondary Hyperparathyroidism.

================================================================================
Question 1106 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
What is the primary cause of Sheehan’s syndrome

Options:
  Traumatic brain injury
✓ Postpartum hemorrhage
  Infection
  Autoimmune disorder
  Pregnancy induced hypertension

Explanation:
Sheehan's syndrome is ischemic necrosis of the pituitary gland caused by severe hypotension due to postpartum hemorrhage.

================================================================================
Question 1107 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Which of the following is the most common cause of primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison's disease)

Options:
  Congenital adrenal hyperplasia
✓ Autoimmune adrenalitis
  Adrenal haemorrhage
  Infections (e.g., tuberculosis)
  Pituitary adenoma

Explanation:
Autoimmune adrenalitis is the most common cause of primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison's disease) in the developed world. While TB is a common cause in developing regions, autoimmune destruction is generally the most frequently cited cause in medical literature.

================================================================================
Question 1108 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 52-year-old male with a history of chronic hypertension and diabetes mellitus is admitted to the hospital with signs of dehydration after several days of vomiting and diarrhea. On physical examination, he is hypotensive, tachycardic, and appears very lethargic. Lab results show elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine levels. Urinalysis shows muddy brown casts. An ultrasound of the kidneys shows normal-sized kidneys with no evidence of obstruction. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient’s renal injury

Options:
  Acute Glomerulonephritis
✓ Acute Tubular Necrosis
  Postrenal Obstruction
  Chronic Pyelonephritis
  Nephrotic Syndrome

Explanation:
The presence of muddy brown granular casts in the urinalysis is pathognomonic for Acute Tubular Necrosis (ATN), which in this case was likely precipitated by severe ischemia from dehydration (vomiting/diarrhea) and hypotension.

================================================================================
Question 1109 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Which one of the following is the drug of choice for the reduction of cerebral edema associated with cerebral infections because it has most potent anti-inflammatory action?

Options:
✓ Dexamethasone
  Fludrocortisone
  Mannitol
  Methylprednisolone
  Triamcinolone

Explanation:
Dexamethasone is the glucocorticoid of choice for reducing cerebral edema, particularly in conditions like bacterial meningitis or brain tumors, due to its high potency and lack of mineralocorticoid activity.

================================================================================
Question 1110 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Which one of the following is a contraindication to the use of oxytocin for induction of labour at term?

Options:
  Dead Fetus
✓ Fetal Distress
  Hypotonic uterine dysfunction
  Prior history of low transverse C section
  Twin gestation

Explanation:
Fetal distress is a contraindication to inducing labor with oxytocin because the contractions can further compromise fetal oxygenation. Immediate delivery (often via C-section) is usually indicated.

================================================================================
Question 1111 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 60 years old man diagnosed with metastasized prostate cancer is started on depot preparation of goserelin. Which one of the following describes the mechanism of action of this drug?

Options:
  Blockade of gonadotropin receptors
  Blockade of prostate testosterone receptors
  Inhibition of aromatase enzyme
✓ Inhibition of FSH and LH release
  Inhibition of topoisomerase enzyme

Explanation:
Goserelin is a GnRH agonist. Continuous administration results in the downregulation of GnRH receptors in the pituitary, which subsequently inhibits the release of FSH and LH, leading to decreased testosterone production (medical castration).

================================================================================
Question 1112 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 25 years old pregnant female has asymptomatic bacteriuria. Which one of the following drugs given in a single dose can be effective in this condition?

Options:
  Cotrimoxazole
  Erythromycin
✓ Fosfomycin
  Imipenem
  Nitrofurantoin

Explanation:
Fosfomycin is typically administered as a single 3-gram oral dose for uncomplicated urinary tract infections, including asymptomatic bacteriuria in pregnancy.

================================================================================
Question 1113 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Which one of the following adverse effects may be observed in 20% -30% of the patients taking Octreotide for more than six months?

Options:
  Hepatitis
  Hypertension
✓ Gallstones
  Rash, Fever
  Renal Failure

Explanation:
Octreotide inhibits gallbladder contractility and decreases bile secretion, which commonly leads to the formation of biliary sludge and gallstones (cholelithiasis) with long-term use.

================================================================================
Question 1114 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Which one of the following is the insulin preparation of choice in the treatment of diabetic ketoacidosis?

Options:
  Insulin Aspart
  Insulin Glargine
  Insulin Glulisine
  NPH Insulin
✓ Regular Insulin

Explanation:
Regular Insulin administered intravenously is the standard of care for the management of Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA) due to its rapid onset and short duration of action, allowing for precise titration.

================================================================================
Question 1115 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A patient with type 2 diabetes is brought to the emergency with overdosage of antidiabetic medication. He is showing a picture of metabolic acidosis with raised plasma lactic acid levels. Which one of the following drugs is most likely cause of his symptoms?

Options:
  Acarbose
✓ Metformin
  Pioglitazone
  Rapaglinide
  Tolbutamide

Explanation:
Lactic acidosis is a rare but serious adverse effect associated with Metformin, especially in overdose or in patients with renal impairment.

================================================================================
Question 1116 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Which of the following drugs if given in excessive amounts over long periods of time may result in a severely increased risk of infections and sepsis in the patient?

Options:
  Levothyroxine
  Liotrix
✓ Methimazole
  Potassium iodide
  Propranolol

Explanation:
Methimazole (an antithyroid drug) carries a risk of causing agranulocytosis (severe drop in white blood cells), which can predispose patients to severe infections and sepsis.

================================================================================
Question 1117 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Which one of the following statements is correct regarding minipills?

Options:
  Are absolutely contraindicated in postpartum period
  Are associated with increased menstrual blood loss
  Dose has to be taken on alternate days
  Have adverse effects profile similar to combined oral pills
✓ Less efficacious than combined oral pills

Explanation:
Minipills (Progestogen-only pills) have a slightly higher failure rate (lower efficacy) compared to Combined Oral Contraceptive Pills (COCPs) if not taken at the exact same time every day. They are not contraindicated postpartum and are often preferred during breastfeeding.

================================================================================
Question 1118 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 12-year-old boy develops hematuria two days after a sore throat. Light microscopy of the renal biopsy shows enlarged and hypercellular glomeruli. Electron microscopy reveals subepithelial "hump-like" deposits, and immunofluorescence demonstrates granular deposits of IgG, IgM, and C3 along the basement membrane. What is the most likely underlying pathogenesis of his condition?

Options:
  Deposition of anti-GBM antibodies
✓ Circulating immune complex deposition
  Mutations in collagen type IV
  Alternative complement pathway activation
  Deposition of IgA-containing immune complexes

Explanation:
The findings describe Post-Streptococcal Glomerulonephritis (PSGN), which is a Type III hypersensitivity reaction caused by the deposition of circulating immune complexes (antigen-antibody complexes) in the glomerulus.

================================================================================
Question 1119 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A patient develops acute renal failure characterized by fever, rash, and eosinophilia one week after starting a course of antibiotics. Renal biopsy shows interstitial edema with numerous eosinophils and mononuclear infiltrates. Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is most consistent with these findings?

Options:
  Type I (Immediate)
  Type II (Cytotoxic)
  Type III (Immune Complex-Mediated)
✓ Type IV (Delayed)
  Type V (Stimulatory)

Explanation:
Acute Interstitial Nephritis (AIN) is primarily a T-cell mediated hypersensitivity reaction, which classifies it as a Type IV (delayed) hypersensitivity reaction.

================================================================================
Question 1120 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 45-year-old patient presents with generalized edema and heavy proteinuria. A renal biopsy reveals diffuse thickening of the glomerular basement membrane without significant hypercellularity. Immunofluorescence shows granular deposits of IgG and C3 along the basement membrane. Electron microscopy reveals subepithelial immune complexes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Options:
  Minimal Change Disease
  Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis
✓ Membranous Nephropathy
  Membranoproliferative Glomerulonephritis
  Acute Post-Streptococcal Glomerulonephritis

Explanation:
Diffuse GBM thickening, granular IgG/C3 deposits, and subepithelial 'spike and dome' immune complexes are the hallmark pathological features of Membranous Nephropathy.

================================================================================
Question 1121 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 68-year-old man is diagnosed with prostatic adenocarcinoma confined to the prostate gland. His Gleason score is 8. Which of the following best describes the significance of this Gleason score?

Options:
  Low-grade tumor with excellent prognosis
  Intermediate-grade tumor with moderate prognosis
✓ High-grade tumor with poor prognosis
  Indicates the tumor has metastasized
  Reflects the tumor's response to hormonal therapy

Explanation:
The Gleason score ranges from 2 to 10. A score of 8-10 indicates a high-grade, poorly differentiated tumor that is more aggressive and associated with a poorer prognosis.

================================================================================
Question 1122 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Which of the following zones of the prostate gland is most commonly involved in benign prostatic hyperplasia leading to urinary obstruction symptoms?

Options:
  Peripheral zone
  Central zone
✓ Transitional zone
  Periurethral zone
  Anterior fibromuscular stroma

Explanation:
Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia (BPH) primarily affects the Transitional Zone of the prostate, which surrounds the urethra, leading to urinary obstruction symptoms.

================================================================================
Question 1123 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 60-year-old male presents with hematuria and flank pain. Imaging reveals a mass in the upper pole of the left kidney. Histology shows clear cytoplasm tumor cells. Which paraneoplastic syndrome is most commonly associated with this type of renal cell carcinoma?

Options:
  Hypoglycemia due to insulin production
✓ Polycythemia due to erythropoietin production
  Cushing's syndrome due to ACTH production
  Hypercalcemia due to PTHrP production
  Hyponatremia due to ADH production

Explanation:
Renal Cell Carcinoma (RCC) is well known for paraneoplastic syndromes. Ectopic production of erythropoietin leads to polycythemia (erythrocytosis). While hypercalcemia is also common, polycythemia is a classic association frequently tested.

================================================================================
Question 1124 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 35-year-old woman presents with severe flank pain radiating to the groin. Imaging reveals a staghorn calculus occupying the renal pelvis. Which of the following types of renal stones is most likely responsible for this presentation?

Options:
  Calcium oxalate
  Uric acid
  Cystine
✓ Magnesium ammonium phosphate
  Calcium phosphate

Explanation:
Staghorn calculi are typically composed of Magnesium Ammonium Phosphate (Struvite) and are associated with urease-producing bacterial infections (e.g., Proteus).

================================================================================
Question 1125 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A patient presents with high fever, flank pain, and dysuria. Urinalysis shows white blood cell casts. Which of the following organisms is the most common cause of acute pyelonephritis in otherwise healthy individuals?

Options:
  Staphylococcus saprophyticus
  Klebsiella pneumoniae
  Proteus mirabilis
✓ Escherichia coli
  Enterococcus faecalis

Explanation:
Escherichia coli (E. coli) is the most common causative pathogen for both uncomplicated urinary tract infections (cystitis) and acute pyelonephritis.

================================================================================
Question 1126 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 4-year-old child presents with an abdominal mass and hematuria. Genetic testing reveals a deletion on chromosome 11p13 affecting the WT1 gene. This child also has developmental abnormalities including aniridia and genitourinary malformations. Based on this presentation, which syndrome is the most likely associated with this tumor?

Options:
  Beckwith-Wiedemann Syndrome
  Denys-Drash Syndrome
✓ WAGR Syndrome
  Li-Fraumeni Syndrome
  Von Hippel-Lindau Disease

Explanation:
WAGR syndrome stands for Wilms tumor, Aniridia, Genitourinary anomalies, and Retardation (intellectual disability). It is caused by a deletion at 11p13 involving the WT1 and PAX6 genes.

================================================================================
Question 1127 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 65-year-old male presents with painless hematuria. Cystoscopy reveals a papillary growth within the urinary bladder. Biopsy of the lesion shows papillary fronds lined by transitional epithelium with varying degrees of nuclear atypia and mitotic activity. Which of the following histological features would most indicate progression to invasive carcinoma?

Options:
  Presence of squamous metaplasia
  High nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio
✓ Presence of lamina propria invasion
  Increased mitotic figures at the epithelial surface
  Loss of umbrella cells at the surface

Explanation:
The invasion of the tumor into the lamina propria (crossing the basement membrane) is the definitive sign that a carcinoma has become invasive (T1 stage).

================================================================================
Question 1128 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 70-year-old smoker presents with gross hematuria. A biopsy of the bladder mass reveals an exophytic tumor with finger-like projections. The tumor cells are high-grade with marked nuclear pleomorphism, and frequent mitoses, and are arranged in a disordered, haphazard fashion. Which of the following is the most appropriate description of this tumor?

Options:
  Low-grade papillary urothelial carcinoma
✓ High-grade papillary urothelial carcinoma
  Squamous cell carcinoma
  Adenocarcinoma of the bladder
  Urothelial carcinoma in situ

Explanation:
The description of papillary architecture combined with high-grade cellular features (marked pleomorphism, frequent mitoses, disorder) fits High-grade Papillary Urothelial Carcinoma.

================================================================================
Question 1129 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 45-year-old woman presents with fatigue, cold intolerance, and amenorrhea. Physical examination reveals pale, dry skin and a delayed deep tendon reflex. Her past medical history includes a significant postpartum hemorrhage 10 years ago. Laboratory tests show low TSH, low ACTH, and low LH/FSH. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Options:
✓ Sheehan's syndrome
  Addison's disease
  Primary hypothyroidism
  Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS)
  Graves' disease

Explanation:
Sheehan's syndrome is panhypopituitarism caused by ischemic necrosis of the pituitary gland following severe postpartum hemorrhage. Symptoms of multiple pituitary hormone deficiencies (hypothyroidism, adrenal insufficiency, amenorrhea) appearing years later are characteristic.

================================================================================
Question 1130 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 55-year-old male presents with bitemporal hemianopia and headache. MRI reveals a large sellar mass compressing the optic chiasm. Laboratory tests show elevated prolactin levels. Which of the following is the most likely type of pituitary adenoma?

Options:
✓ Prolactinoma
  Corticotroph adenoma
  Somatotroph adenoma
  Gonadotroph adenoma
  Thyrotroph adenoma

Explanation:
Prolactinoma is the most common functioning pituitary adenoma. It presents with hyperprolactinemia and, if large (macroadenoma), mass effects like bitemporal hemianopia.

================================================================================
Question 1131 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 42-year-old woman presents with a painless thyroid nodule that has been gradually increasing in size over the past few months. Fine-needle aspiration biopsy reveals cells with nuclear grooves and intranuclear inclusions. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Options:
✓ Papillary thyroid carcinoma
  Follicular adenoma
  Medullary thyroid carcinoma
  Anaplastic thyroid carcinoma
  Hurthle cell carcinoma

Explanation:
Nuclear features such as 'Orphan Annie eyes' (optically clear nuclei), nuclear grooves, and intranuclear inclusions are pathognomonic for Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma.

================================================================================
Question 1132 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 30-year-old female presents with a painful, swollen thyroid gland and a low-grade fever following an upper respiratory tract infection. Laboratory tests show elevated ESR and low TSH with high free T4. The thyroid scan shows decreased uptake. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Options:
✓ Subacute granulomatous thyroiditis (De Quervain's thyroiditis)
  Hashimoto's thyroiditis
  Graves' disease
  Riedel's thyroiditis
  Suppurative thyroiditis

Explanation:
Subacute (De Quervain's) Thyroiditis typically follows a viral infection and presents with a painful thyroid, fever, and transient hyperthyroidism due to follicle destruction (low uptake on scan, high T4/low TSH).

================================================================================
Question 1133 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 40-year-old woman presents with weight gain, central obesity, facial rounding, and purple striae on the abdomen. Laboratory tests reveal elevated 24-hour urinary free cortisol and suppressed ACTH levels. An MRI shows an adrenal mass. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her condition?

Options:
✓ Adrenal adenoma
  Pituitary adenoma
  Ectopic ACTH production
  Exogenous glucocorticoid use
  Adrenal hyperplasia

Explanation:
Cushing's syndrome symptoms with high cortisol and suppressed ACTH indicate an ACTH-independent cause (adrenal source). The presence of a unilateral adrenal mass confirms an Adrenal Adenoma (or carcinoma).

================================================================================
Question 1134 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 25-year-old woman presents with abdominal bloating and pelvic discomfort. Ultrasound reveals a solid, cystic mass in the ovary. Serum markers show elevated CA-125. Histopathological examination reveals cells resembling fallopian tube epithelium. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Options:
✓ Serous cystadenocarcinoma
  Mucinous cystadenoma
  Dysgerminoma
  Granulosa cell tumor
  Teratoma

Explanation:
Ovarian serous tumors are characterized by epithelium resembling the fallopian tube. Elevated CA-125 and the solid/cystic nature suggest malignancy (Serous Cystadenocarcinoma), which is the most common ovarian cancer.

================================================================================
Question 1135 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 28-year-old male presents with a painless testicular mass. Serum tumor markers reveal elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) and beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (β-hCG). Histopathology shows mixed germ cell tumor components. Which of the following is the most likely histologic subtype?

Options:
✓ Non-seminomatous germ cell tumor
  Seminoma
  Leydig cell tumor
  Sertoli cell tumor
  Testicular lymphoma

Explanation:
Seminomas typically do not elevate AFP. The elevation of both AFP and beta-hCG indicates a Non-Seminomatous Germ Cell Tumor (NSGCT), often mixed (e.g., embryonal carcinoma, yolk sac tumor).

================================================================================
Question 1136 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 22-year-old woman presents with a firm, mobile breast lump that has been stable in size for the past year. Ultrasound shows a well-defined, solid mass with smooth borders. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Options:
✓ Fibroadenoma
  Phyllodes tumor
  Invasive ductal carcinoma
  Fibrocystic changes
  Intraductal papilloma

Explanation:
Fibroadenoma is the most common benign breast mass in young women. It presents as a firm, mobile ('breast mouse'), well-defined solid mass.

================================================================================
Question 1137 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 48-year-old woman presents with a newly discovered, firm, irregular breast mass. Mammography shows a spiculated lesion, and a core biopsy reveals invasive ductal carcinoma. Which of the following is the most significant prognostic factor in this patient?

Options:
✓ Lymph node involvement
  Tumor size
  Estrogen receptor status
  HER2/neu status
  Histologic grade

Explanation:
While all listed factors are important, the status of the axillary lymph nodes (involvement and number) is the single most significant prognostic factor for invasive breast cancer.

================================================================================
Question 1138 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 50-year-old woman with breast cancer undergoes a biopsy. Immunohistochemistry shows positive estrogen receptor (ER), positive progesterone receptor (PR), and HER2/neu overexpression. Which of the following prognostic markers is associated with a more favorable outcome?

Options:
✓ Positive estrogen receptor (ER) status
  HER2/neu overexpression
  High Ki-67 index
  Lymphovascular invasion
  Negative progesterone receptor (PR) status

Explanation:
Estrogen Receptor (ER) positivity is a favorable prognostic indicator because these tumors tend to be less aggressive and respond well to hormonal therapy (e.g., Tamoxifen).

================================================================================
Question 1139 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 58-year-old man with a 15-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus presents with progressive leg pain and ulcers on his feet that have been slow to heal. He has also noticed a decrease in sensation in his feet over the past few months. On examination, his feet are cool to the touch, and there is evidence of diminished peripheral pulses and decreased vibration sense. Which of the following complications is most likely contributing to his symptoms?

Options:
✓ Peripheral arterial disease (PAD)
  Diabetic neuropathy
  Diabetic retinopathy
  Diabetic nephropathy
  Charcot joint

Explanation:
While the patient likely has neuropathy (decreased sensation), the symptoms of leg pain (claudication/ischemic pain), slow-healing ulcers, cool skin, and diminished pulses are hallmarks of Peripheral Arterial Disease (PAD), which causes ischemia.

================================================================================
Question 1140 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 45-year-old woman presents with persistent hypertension, muscle weakness, and fatigue. Laboratory investigations reveal hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, and an elevated serum aldosterone level with suppressed plasma renin activity. Imaging studies show a unilateral adrenal mass. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism responsible for this patient's condition?

Options:
  Overproduction of cortisol due to adrenal hyperplasia
✓ Increased secretion of aldosterone due to an adrenal adenoma
  Ectopic aldosterone production from a non-adrenal tumor
  Genetic mutation leading to constitutive activation of the mineralocorticoid receptor
  Bilateral adrenal hyperplasia causing increased aldosterone secretion

Explanation:
This is the classic presentation of Primary Hyperaldosteronism (Conn's syndrome) caused by an aldosterone-secreting adrenal adenoma. The unilateral mass and biochemistry confirm the diagnosis.

================================================================================
Question 1141 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
The transplantation of human organs and tissues act was made in

Options:
  1960
  1995
  2005
✓ 2010
  2001

Explanation:
In Pakistan, the Transplantation of Human Organs and Tissues Act was enacted in 2010 to regulate organ transplantation and prevent illegal organ trade.

================================================================================
Question 1142 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Hegar sign is present in

Options:
  Delivery
✓ Pregnancy
  UTI
  Sodomy
  Oposit to chadwicks sign

Explanation:
Hegar's sign is a non-sensitive indication of pregnancy in women, characterized by the softening of the lower uterine segment, typically felt during a bimanual examination.

================================================================================
Question 1143 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Sterility can occur in

Options:
  Male
  Female
✓ Both male and female
  Sterile patient is capable of reproduction
  Mumps is not the cause of starility

Explanation:
Sterility (inability to reproduce) can affect both males and females due to various physiological or anatomical causes.

================================================================================
Question 1144 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
In artificial inseminization homologues (AIH)

Options:
✓ Semen is of husband
  Semen is of donor
  Semen may be of husband or donor
  Artificial inseminization is of three types
  Artificial inseminization ion should be done in the absence of a nurse.

Explanation:
AIH stands for Artificial Insemination by Husband, meaning the semen used is collected from the woman's husband.

================================================================================
Question 1145 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
In virginity

Options:
  Hymen in intact
  Hymen is Torn
✓ Hymen may be intact or torn
  Hymen is cribriform
  Labia minora hard, insensitive and blue in colour.

Explanation:
The state of the hymen is not a definitive indicator of virginity. It can be intact, torn, or naturally absent due to various factors unrelated to sexual intercourse.

Question 1146 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Sodomy

Options:
  Not found in Pakistan
✓ Derives its name from the city of Sodom
  Offender is call passive agent
  Legalized in India
  Perinial abrasions never present

Explanation:
The term sodomy historically derives its name from the biblical city of Sodom.

================================================================================
Question 1147 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Abortion

Options:
✓ Expulsion of products of conception before six months of gestation
  At any periods of gestation before full term
  Before three months of gestation
  Female after abortion is not anaemic
  After abortion cervix is hard and closed

Explanation:
Abortion is medically defined as the expulsion or removal of an embryo or fetus before it is viable, typically defined as before 20-24 weeks (approx. 6 months) of gestation.

================================================================================
Question 1148 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A boy with recurrent UTIs, who can’t pass urine in single stream, can have

Options:
✓ Posterior urethral valves
  Horse shoe kidney
  Single kidney
  All of above
  None of above

Explanation:
Posterior Urethral Valves (PUV) are obstructing membranous folds in the posterior urethra in males, leading to poor urinary stream, urinary retention, and recurrent UTIs.

================================================================================
Question 1149 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
The goal of management of D.M type1 is to maintain fasting sugar level between

Options:
  110-140
✓ 80-120
  70-80
  120-150
  None of above

Explanation:
Typical glycemic targets for Type 1 Diabetes management often aim for a fasting/pre-prandial glucose range of 80-130 mg/dL (ADA guidelines) or 80-120 mg/dL in stricter control contexts.

================================================================================
Question 1150 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Which paremeters must be used in assesment of short stature

Options:
  Child’s height
  Sibling’s height
  Parent’s height
  Mid parental height
✓ All of above

Explanation:
Assessment of short stature involves evaluating the child's current height, genetic potential (Parents' height, Mid-parental height), and familial patterns (Siblings' height).

================================================================================
Question 1151 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 45 years old unmarried female presented in Surgical OPD having painless lump in right upper outer quadrant of breast for last 3 months gradually increasing in size. Examination reveals hard mass, immobile attached to deeper tissue. There is also a lump in right axilla. What is likely diagnosis?

Options:
  Traumatic fat necrosis
  Fibroadenoma
✓ Ca-breast
  Breast abscess
  Phylloides Tumor

Explanation:
A hard, immobile, painless breast mass with axillary lymphadenopathy in a 45-year-old woman is highly suspicious for Breast Carcinoma.

================================================================================
Question 1152 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 45 years old female presented in surgical OPD having a lump in breast for 2 months. Lump is hard, fixed to deeper structures and non tender. There is also a lump in ipsilateral axilla. What is next step in management?

Options:
✓ Mammography
  Ultrasound breast
  Open biopsy
  FNAC
  MRI

Explanation:
In a woman over 35-40 years old presenting with a breast lump, bilateral Mammography is the standard initial imaging modality as part of the triple assessment.

================================================================================
Question 1153 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 70 years old male presented ē hesitancy, intermittent urination & nocturia, his USG shows 40 grams prostate. What treatment you will advise to patient?

Options:
  Uretheral Catheterization
  Anticholinergies Drugs
✓ Αlpha Blockage Drugs
  TURP
  Antibiotics

Explanation:
For symptomatic Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia (BPH) with a moderately enlarged prostate (40g), Alpha-blockers (e.g., tamsulosin) are the first-line medical therapy to relax smooth muscle and improve flow.

================================================================================
Question 1154 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 20 years old male presented with acute urinary retention. Urethral catheterization tried in emergency department but not successful. What will be next step of management?

Options:
  Retrograde Uretherogram
✓ Suprapubic Catheterization
  Optical Urethrotomy
  Urethroplasty
  Laparotomy

Explanation:
When urethral catheterization fails in acute urinary retention, Suprapubic Catheterization is the immediate next step to relieve the bladder.

================================================================================
Question 1155 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 60 years old patient presented ē Gross haematuria ē his CT Scan showed right renal mass which is 4 cm & confined to kidney there is no lymph node involvement & no metastasis. What is the stage of the disease?

Options:
✓ T1a NOMO
  T2a NOMO
  T1b NOMO
  T2b NOMO
  T3 NOMO

Explanation:
A renal tumor measuring 4 cm or less, limited to the kidney, is classified as T1a. With no nodes (N0) and no metastasis (M0), the stage is T1a N0 M0.

================================================================================
Question 1156 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 30 years old male patient presented with 30 mm ® Renal pelvis stone. What treatment will you offer to patient?

Options:
  ESWL
  Conservative Treatment
✓ PCNL
  URS
  Pyelolithotomy

Explanation:
For renal stones larger than 20mm (2cm), Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy (PCNL) is the standard treatment of choice as ESWL is less effective for large burden.

================================================================================
Question 1157 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Which of the following medications is commonly used in the medical management of miscarriage?

Options:
  Methotrexate
  Mifepristone
✓ Misoprostol
  Progesterone
  None of these

Explanation:
Misoprostol (a prostaglandin analog) is commonly used to induce expulsion of the products of conception in the medical management of miscarriage.

================================================================================
Question 1158 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Which of the following is true regarding a missed miscarriage?

Options:
  Cervix is open with heavy bleeding
  Fetal tissue is expelled immediately
✓ Fetus is non-viable, but there are no symptoms of miscarriage
  It usually occurs after 20 weeks of pregnancy
  All of the above

Explanation:
A missed miscarriage is defined by the presence of a non-viable fetus within the uterus with a closed cervix and usually minimal or no symptoms (bleeding/pain).

================================================================================
Question 1159 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Which of the following types of miscarriage is associated with an open cervix and passage of products of conception?

Options:
  Threatened miscarriage
✓ Inevitable miscarriage
  Missed miscarriage
  Complete miscarriage
  None of these

Explanation:
While 'Incomplete' is the most precise term for partial passage, 'Inevitable' miscarriage involves an open cervix and symptoms indicating the process has become irreversible, often described as products being in the process of passing. In MCQs where Incomplete is absent, Inevitable often represents the active state with an open cervix compared to Threatened or Missed.

================================================================================
Question 1160 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A patient presents with vaginal bleeding and abdominal pain at 10 weeks of pregnancy. On examination, the cervix is closed, and an ultrasound shows a non- viable fetus. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Options:
  Threatened miscarriage
  Inevitable miscarriage
✓ Missed miscarriage
  Complete miscarriage
  None of these

Explanation:
A non-viable fetus with a closed cervix fits the diagnosis of a Missed miscarriage. Threatened would imply viability.

================================================================================
Question 1161 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
What is the most common cause of first-trimester miscarriage?

Options:
  Infections
✓ Chromosomal abnormalities
  Trauma
  Maternal autoimmune disorders
  None of these

Explanation:
Chromosomal abnormalities (aneuploidy) account for at least 50% of all first-trimester miscarriages.

================================================================================
Question 1162 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Which of the following is NOT a risk factor for ectopic pregnancy?

Options:
  Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID)
  Intrauterine device (IUD) usage
  History of tubal surgery
✓ Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS)
  None of these

Explanation:
PID, tubal surgery, and IUD usage (if failure occurs) are established risk factors for ectopic pregnancy. PCOS affects ovulation but is not a specific risk factor for tubal implantation.

================================================================================
Question 1163 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 28-year-old woman presents with lower abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and a positive pregnancy test. A transvaginal ultrasound shows an empty uterus. What is the next best step in the management?

Options:
✓ Serum β-hCG measurement
  Immediate laparoscopy
  Methotrexate administration
  Dilation and curettage (D&C)
  None of these

Explanation:
In a 'pregnancy of unknown location', measuring serum β-hCG is crucial to interpret the ultrasound findings (discriminatory zone) and guide further management.

================================================================================
Question 1164 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Which of the following treatments is appropriate for an unruptured ectopic pregnancy with low β-hCG levels and no cardiac activity?

Options:
✓ Methotrexate
  Laparotomy
  Salpingectomy
  Expectant management
  None of these

Explanation:
Medical management with Methotrexate is indicated for hemodynamically stable patients with unruptured ectopic pregnancy, low β-hCG, and no fetal cardiac activity.

================================================================================
Question 1165 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Which of the following is a contraindication for methotrexate therapy in the treatment of ectopic pregnancy?

Options:
  Serum β-hCG level >5000 mIU/mL
  Presence of fetal cardiac activity
  Hemodynamically stable patient
✓ Both a and b
  All of the above

Explanation:
High β-hCG (>5000) and fetal cardiac activity are relative or absolute contraindications for methotrexate due to higher failure rates.

================================================================================
Question 1166 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
What is the main purpose of serial β-hCG measurements in a suspected case of ectopic pregnancy?

Options:
  To confirm intrauterine pregnancy
✓ To assess the viability of the pregnancy
  To monitor the resolution of ectopic pregnancy
  To determine the appropriate timing for delivery
  None of these

Explanation:
Serial β-hCG helps assess viability (doubling time) and differentiate between a viable intrauterine pregnancy, a miscarriage, and an ectopic pregnancy.

================================================================================
Question 1167 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Which of the following is a common symptom associated with menopause?

Options:
  Amenorrhea
✓ Hot flashes
  Breast tenderness
  Weight loss
  None of these

Explanation:
Vasomotor symptoms like hot flashes (and night sweats) are the most common characteristic symptoms of menopause.

================================================================================
Question 1168 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Which hormone predominantly decreases during menopause?

Options:
  Progesterone
  Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH)
✓ Estrogen
  Luteinizing hormone (LH)
  None of these

Explanation:
Menopause is defined by the cessation of ovarian function, leading to a profound decrease in estrogen production.

================================================================================
Question 1169 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Hormone replacement therapy (HRT) in menopausal women is contraindicated in which of the following conditions?

Options:
✓ History of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)
  Hot flashes
  Low bone density
  Premature ovarian insufficiency
  None of these

Explanation:
HRT increases the risk of thromboembolism; therefore, a history of DVT is a contraindication.

================================================================================
Question 1170 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 52-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with vaginal bleeding. What is the most important next step in her management?

Options:
  Prescribe estrogen therapy
  Pap smear
✓ Endometrial biopsy
  Ultrasound of the pelvis
  None of these

Explanation:
Postmenopausal bleeding is considered endometrial cancer until proven otherwise. Endometrial biopsy is the definitive diagnostic step, although ultrasound is often used for triage.

================================================================================
Question 1171 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Which of the following is a long-term health risk associated with menopause due to estrogen deficiency?

Options:
  Hypothyroidism
✓ Osteoporosis
  Hypertension
  Type 1 diabetes
  None of these

Explanation:
Estrogen deficiency leads to accelerated bone resorption, significantly increasing the risk of osteoporosis and fractures.

================================================================================
Question 1172 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Which of the following is a major risk factor for endometrial cancer?

Options:
  Multiparity
  Use of oral contraceptives
✓ Obesity
  Early menopause
  None of these

Explanation:
Obesity causes increased peripheral conversion of androgens to estrogen, leading to unopposed estrogen exposure, a major risk factor for endometrial cancer.

================================================================================
Question 1173 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
What is the most common type of endometrial cancer?

Options:
  Clear cell carcinoma
  Papillary serous carcinoma
✓ Endometrioid adenocarcinoma
  Mucinous carcinoma
  None of these

Explanation:
Endometrioid adenocarcinoma accounts for the vast majority (approx. 75-80%) of endometrial cancers.

================================================================================
Question 1174 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Which hormone is most implicated in the development of endometrial cancer?

Options:
  Progesterone
✓ Estrogen
  Testosterone
  Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH)
  None of these

Explanation:
Unopposed Estrogen causes endometrial hyperplasia, which can progress to carcinoma.

================================================================================
Question 1175 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
In endometrial cancer staging, which stage involves spread beyond the uterus but confined to the pelvis?

Options:
  Stage I
  Stage II
✓ Stage III
  Stage IV
  None of these

Explanation:
According to FIGO staging, Stage III involves local and/or regional spread of the cancer (e.g., adnexa, vagina) but confined to the pelvis.

================================================================================
Question 1176 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Which genetic condition is associated with an increased risk of endometrial cancer?

Options:
  BRCA1 mutation
✓ Lynch syndrome (Hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer)
  Turner syndrome
  Down syndrome
  None of these

Explanation:
Lynch syndrome is a hereditary condition that significantly increases the risk of colorectal, endometrial, and other cancers.

================================================================================
Question 1177 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Which of the following HPV strains are most commonly associated with cervical cancer?

Options:
  HPV 6 and 11
✓ HPV 16 and 18
  HPV 31 and 33
  HPV 45 and 52
  None of these

Explanation:
HPV 16 and 18 are high-risk strains responsible for approximately 70% of all cervical cancer cases.

================================================================================
Question 1178 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
What is the most common presenting symptom of cervical cancer?

Options:
✓ Postcoital bleeding
  Pelvic pain
  Abdominal swelling
  Dysuria
  None of these

Explanation:
Postcoital bleeding (bleeding after intercourse) is the classic early warning sign of cervical cancer.

================================================================================
Question 1179 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
In cervical cancer staging, which stage involves extension beyond the uterus but not to the pelvic wall or lower third of the vagina?

Options:
  Stage I
✓ Stage II
  Stage III
  Stage IV
  None of these

Explanation:
Stage II cervical cancer extends beyond the cervix/uterus (e.g., to upper vagina or parametrium) but does not reach the pelvic wall or lower third of the vagina.

================================================================================
Question 1180 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Which of the following is the most common clinical feature of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS)?

Options:
✓ Hirsutism
  Amenorrhea
  Obesity
  Infertility
  None of these

Explanation:
Hirsutism is a very common manifestation of hyperandrogenism, which is a key diagnostic feature of PCOS.

================================================================================
Question 1181 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Which hormone is typically elevated in patients with PCOS?

Options:
  Progesterone
✓ Luteinizing hormone (LH)
  Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH)
  Estrogen
  None of these

Explanation:
Elevated LH levels and an increased LH:FSH ratio are characteristic hormonal findings in PCOS.

================================================================================
Question 1182 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Women with PCOS are at increased risk for which of the following conditions?

Options:
  Osteoporosis
✓ Endometrial cancer
  Breast cancer
  Hypothyroidism
  None of these

Explanation:
Chronic anovulation in PCOS leads to unopposed estrogen exposure, increasing the risk of endometrial hyperplasia and cancer.

================================================================================
Question 1183 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Which chromosomal abnormality is most commonly associated with complete hydatidiform moles?

Options:
  69, XXX
  69, XXY
✓ 46, XX or 46, XY (entirely paternal in origin)
  47, XXX
  None of these

Explanation:
Complete moles are usually diploid (46,XX or 46,XY) and androgenetic, meaning all genetic material is paternal in origin.

================================================================================
Question 1184 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
What is the treatment of choice for high-risk gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN)?

Options:
  Surgical removal of the uterus
  Single-agent chemotherapy
✓ Multi-agent chemotherapy
  Radiation therapy
  None of these

Explanation:
High-risk GTN requires multi-agent chemotherapy regimens, such as EMA-CO, for effective treatment.

================================================================================
Question 1185 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Which of the following is TRUE about partial hydatidiform moles?

Options:
✓ They contain triploid chromosomal material
  They have a higher risk of developing into choriocarcinoma than complete moles
  They always present with vaginal bleeding
  Fetal parts are never present
  None of these

Explanation:
Partial moles are triploid (69 chromosomes) due to fertilization of an egg by two sperm. They often contain fetal parts and carry a lower risk of malignancy than complete moles.

================================================================================
Question 1186 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Which of the following is a known risk factor for developing a hydatidiform mole?

Options:
  Nulliparity
✓ Advanced maternal age
  Use of oral contraceptives
  Twin pregnancy
  None of these

Explanation:
Extremes of maternal age (very young or advanced age >35-40) are significant risk factors for molar pregnancy.

================================================================================
Question 1187 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Which imaging modality is considered the gold standard for diagnosing uterine fibroids?

Options:
  Pelvic X-ray
  Hysteroscopy
  Transvaginal ultrasound
✓ MRI of the pelvis
  None of these

Explanation:
While ultrasound is the most common initial imaging, MRI is the most accurate (gold standard) for mapping fibroids, distinguishing them from adenomyosis, and planning surgery.

================================================================================
Question 1188 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Which of the following medications is commonly used to reduce the size of uterine fibroids before surgery?

Options:
  Progesterone
  Estrogen
✓ Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonists
  Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) Answer: c) Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonists
  None of these

Explanation:
GnRH agonists create a hypoestrogenic state, which shrinks fibroids temporarily, making surgery easier.

================================================================================
Question 1189 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Which of the following complications is associated with large uterine fibroids?

Options:
  Endometrial hyperplasia
✓ Ureteric compression and hydronephrosis
  Ovarian torsion
  Vaginal atrophy
  None of these

Explanation:
Large fibroids can physically compress adjacent structures, including the ureters, leading to hydronephrosis.

================================================================================
Question 1190 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
In uterovaginal prolapse, which part of the pelvic floor weakens, leading to the descent of pelvic organs?

Options:
  Endometrial tissue
  Uterine ligaments
✓ Pelvic diaphragm
  Round ligament
  None of these

Explanation:
Weakness of the pelvic diaphragm (levator ani muscles) and endopelvic fascia is the primary cause of pelvic organ prolapse.

================================================================================
Question 1191 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
What grading system is commonly used to classify the severity of pelvic organ prolapse?

Options:
  Bishop score
✓ POP-Q (Pelvic Organ Prolapse Quantification) system
  Apgar score
  Gleason score
  None of these

Explanation:
The POP-Q system is the standard objective method for quantifying and staging pelvic organ prolapse.

================================================================================
Question 1192 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Uterovaginal prolapse is most commonly associated with:

Options:
  Nulliparity
✓ Multiple vaginal deliveries
  Cesarean sections
  Oophorectomy
  None of these

Explanation:
Vaginal childbirth stretches and damages the pelvic floor muscles and connective tissue, making multiparity the strongest risk factor for prolapse.

================================================================================
Question 1193 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Which of the following is considered first-line medical therapy for mild to moderate endometriosis?

Options:
  Clomiphene citrate
  Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)
  Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonists
✓ Oral contraceptive pills
  None of these

Explanation:
Combined oral contraceptives (often with NSAIDs for pain) are the standard first-line medical treatment to suppress ovulation and reduce symptoms.

================================================================================
Question 1194 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Which of the following antibiotics is the first-line treatment for bacterial vaginosis?

Options:
✓ Metronidazole
  Clindamycin
  Fluconazole
  Doxycycline
  None of these

Explanation:
Metronidazole is the treatment of choice for Bacterial Vaginosis.

================================================================================
Question 1195 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Which of the following is a characteristic finding of bacterial vaginosis?

Options:
  Thick, white, curd-like discharge
  Frothy, greenish-yellow discharge
✓ Thin, greyish-white discharge with a fishy odor
  Blood-stained discharge
  None of these

Explanation:
The classic description of Bacterial Vaginosis includes a thin, homogeneous, grey-white discharge with a distinct fishy odor (amine odor).

================================================================================
Question 1196 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Ovulatory problems are cause of infertility

Options:
  30%
✓ 25%
  20%
  15%
  None of the above

Explanation:
Ovulatory disorders are responsible for approximately 25% of female infertility cases.

================================================================================
Question 1197 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Following investigation is done to determine tubal function in endometriosis p +

Options:
  Hysterosalpingography
✓ Laparoscopy and Dye test
  Doppler ultrasound
  Pelvic X-ray
  None of these

Explanation:
Laparoscopy with chromopertubation (dye test) is the gold standard for assessing tubal patency and diagnosing endometriosis simultaneously.

================================================================================
Question 1198 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 30 years old male patient presented with infertility. When sperm ejaculate analysis was done it came to be azoospermia and when further investigated it was found that there is obstruction in the ejaculatory duct. Which hormonal essay is done in this case?

Options:
  Serum testosterone
  Serum prolactin
  Luteinsing hormone
  Prostate Specific antigen
✓ Follicle stimulating hormone

Explanation:
FSH (Follicle Stimulating Hormone) is critical to distinguish between obstructive azoospermia (where FSH is typically normal because spermatogenesis is intact) and non-obstructive azoospermia (testicular failure, where FSH is elevated).

================================================================================
Question 1199 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 60 Years old male presented with painless hematuria with passage of clots, he is also having irritative lower urinary tract symptoms, and he is smoker for the last 40 years. What is probable diagnosis?

Options:
  Enlarged Prostate
✓ Bladder Tumor
  Bladder Stone
  Urinary Tract Infection
  Urethral stricture

Explanation:
Painless gross hematuria in an older smoker is the classic presentation of Bladder Cancer (Transitional Cell Carcinoma).

================================================================================
Question 1200 (WMC - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A 30 years male old patient has a Road traffic accident half hour ago, he is presented in emergency department with gross haematuria, his B.P is 100/80, his pulse is 100/min. On examination he had bruise in his right flank. What will be next step of management?

Options:
  A Exploratory Laparotomy
✓ B CT Scan Abdomen + Pelvis
  C Blood Transfusion
  D Right Nephrectomy
  E X-ray erect abdomen

Explanation:
In a hemodynamically stable (or transiently responsive) patient with renal trauma (indicated by flank bruise and gross hematuria), contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis is the gold standard for staging the injury.

================================================================================
Question 1201 (WMC - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A 60 years old patient presented ē Gross haematuria ē his CT Scan showed right renal mass which is 4 cm & confined to kidney there is no lymph node involvement & no metastasis. What is the stage of the disease?

Options:
